Posted: July 16, 2015
												Scene: The Duke of Edessa, finally recovering from a recent Muslim invasion and the wounds suffered from it, invaded by the neigboring Byzantine Empire. His armies are crushed and his son is captured and castrated. He loses the war and is left as a one provice minor. He catches the plague and goes insane. He vows his revenge. 100 years later another Duke of Edessa and Antioch, now a vassal of Byzantium, begins revenge for the misfortunes of his ancestor. First he weasles his way into the current Emperor's inner circle and gains his trust. He then seduces all of his daughters and has a child with one of them. He then kills all of the sons of the Emperor, while luckily not being caught. He then recognizes the illegitimate child as his own. He then kills his wife and marries the byzantine emperor's daughter, who promptly dies of syphilis. He then  marries the daughter of the HRE thus forming an alliance with them. He then bides his time until the Empire is at its weakest point. The wait was not long, since 5 years later the Caliph of the Sunni faith called a Jihad for Anatolia. The emperor won the Jihad, but at the expense of most of his armies. The Duke, after waiting patiently for so long struck at the rival family. He raised all of the men of the land and used every last coin enlisting the help of mercenary bands. They marched towards Constantinople to meet the Imperial forces. After winning the battle the duke laid siege to the city. Just as the war was about to be won, syphilis struck again not only killing the duke, but his sons as well, leaving the fate of the dynasty and the war in the hands of a 62 year old, possessed, insane and childless relative. All hope was beginning to fail as the war took a turn for the worst. Then in final attempt at survival he sent the last of his armies to face the larger byzantine force. Then in a stroke of luck during the battle, his troops we able to capture the emperor and his last surviving son. He then in a bout of madness castrated all of his prisoners including the emperor and his son. The war ended and the emperors daughter took the throne, the 62 year old then attempted to seduce woman multiple times until finally it suceeded after his 65th birthday. A sickly, clubfooted, imbicile child was born, who the duke legitimized. He then killed the childs mother and himself leaving the young 1 year old as emperor. The duke's revenge finally seemed complete, until the one year old died from syphilis. (I have no idea how he got syphilis)10/10 would syphilis again

number of helpful: 20 of 20 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												The first thing I did as the King of England was assassinate the King of Scotland. It wasn’t for any particular reason. I had just started running the game for the first time, and wanted to check out the King of where I actually lived. But then I saw the assassinate button. I pressed the assassinate button. There was suddenly a dead Scottish monarch and a massive civil war.Crusader Kings II is a ‘Grand Strategy Game’ by Paradox Entertainment, a lovingly created, complex board game of Europe, where you play as historical character. Unlike other strategy games, where you’re the godly hand that guides a country or force, here you’re a Count, Duke, King or Emperor, with all the extra complexities and joys that brings. You have to handle your lineage – marry, have children, assassinate children, change succession laws – so that the game continues. It is the only must in CKII: create an heir, or on death without one, it’s game over. The rest is really up to you. You could try and forge the Empire of Hispania as one of the Spanish Catholic kings, unifying the other catholic nations there and driving out the Muslim rulers. You could play peacefully as the King of Scotland in a different game, only stooping to war when vassals rebel for their own claims on your kingdom. With certain DLC, you could play as Muslim rulers in Africa and Saudi Arabia, Pagan rulers, or even as a patrician, vying for control of the sea highways and port to get the most profit possible.The board deserves some explanation also: unlike many other strategy games, which use hexagonal or square tiles, here real counties are used, such as Gowrie, Cumberland, Middlesex, Badajoz, Leon, and Maine. And they aren’t just bits of land to get to make your Kingdom look bigger: they hold cities, castles and religious buildings that will increase the size of you or your vassal’s levies (army) when annexed and your income, from tax. You can even improve and build new holdings in these counties, to increase both of these. This is one of the many ways you spend your gold, along with creating kingdoms and duchies, hiring mercenaries, bribing the pope (yup!), assassinations, ect.Though out the game, you will be collecting this gold from the taxes, which is the commodity you will be using most often. Also throughout your characters life, he’ll gain Prestige and Piety: both add to your end game score, which you can use to measure just how well you’ve done after playing all those hundreds of years. Both also act like currencies, with you gaining prestige and piety from certain wars and events, but losing them with other events such as destroying kingdom titles (prestige), creating empire and kingdoms (piety) and reforming pagan religions (piety). Upon your characters death, they add to your score – not, however, a reason to die early.War is enjoyable in Crusader Kings II, but possibly not as important as in other strategy games. You can’t declare war, willy nilly. You must have a cause for war, the ‘cassus belli’. This at first feels very restrictive, as in some catholic countries, the only clear way to expand into neighbouring catholic nations is through the slow fabrication of a claim on the county. But eventually it blossoms into the complex strategy, as you juggle where to war with, with what cassus belli, to what end. It becomes delightfully full of opportunities. The Catholic Kingdoms can declare Holy Wars against Pagans and Muslims and claim their land, along with participating in the Crusades the Pope occasionally calls. You also have ‘De Jure Claims’, where you can conquer counties and land that belongs to the predefined ‘de jure’ duchies, kingdoms and empires, depending if you are a Duke, King or Emperor. Pagans can conquer any bordering counties, or subjugate entire kingdoms once in a life time. There is a treasure trove of reasons to war. And with your army, you can choose who leads the armies, and whether to engage them in battles against other armies, or to siege enemy provinces in the war. But it isn’t the only way to gain land: ensuring you’re the heir to the kingdom through assassinations and plots; through offering vassalization to the weaker, smaller independent rulers nearby. But wars are one of the more enjoyable points in the game, as long as you know how to handle them. There really is no better feeling than slowly building your independent duchy into a sprawling Empire over the years.It is important to say that all the rulers on the map are actively acting towards their own goals, with the games superb AI letting hundreds of characters act and change Europe, even in places far from where you are playing. It is sometimes enjoyable to pause the game, and just look around the map, at what’s happening far away. Seeing distant kingdoms fracture, far of empires grow, really gives the game a sense of scale that is great.And in multiplayer, you can have friends play in any of the Kingdoms, replacing one of the AI rulers. It can be incredible fun, with you playing as different Kingdoms, competing as you expand. You can choose whatever way you want to play with friends – you can assassinate them, declare war on them, or offer to join their wars. If they play as the same culture or religion, you may want to help them, to spread it, or fulfil goals that will help you all. With me and a friend playing Norse Pagans (Old Gods DLC), we started trying to expand my kingdom so that it controlled enough holy sites to reform the religion and grant us much needed security for successions. We’ve also had to aid each other during widespread civil and international war and bail each other out. It’s incredibly satisfying to bail your friends’ kingdom out of an independence war, and know they owe you one when you want to take over a nearby kingdom.The downsides of the game is the initial bafflement due to the complexities of how to combine all the systems for your own benefit, and the occasionally irritation caused by wars for the kingdom after succession. Multiplayer also requires all other players must download the host save file every time they play, which can be a slow, but is thankfully all handled in game.This game is one for those who wish to carve a story and a kingdom out of Europe, and are willing to learn through all the complexities and systems to do so. Once the game finally clicks and you’re away with it, it really is a magnificent game. Whole heartedly recommended.

number of helpful: 18 of 19 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is something of a Gateway game to take people into the genre of Grand Strategy games in my opinion, starting you in the place of a feudal lord, merchant republic patrician or as a pagan seeking to reform their faith. I think variety is one of the most important aspects in a game and this game provides hells amount of variety and then some. The scenario is constantly changing, and I literally mean constantly changing as feudal lords die, and new rulers take their place and wars coming from the thin of air to turn the balance in their favor.The game is complicated to grasp at first, and requires some dedication and willpower to see through the initial shock of all the concepts, but it can very much be compared to team fortress and all the new weapons and learning things bit by bit. Same concept of learning, and if you ever master this game there will always be Europa Universalis IV to move onto with the save converter, or if you're feeling bold, Victoria 2.Start your character fresh with ruler designer with only yourself to expand it, and in two hundred years it could become THE leading dynasty. Pick up the Old gods and take the Norse sons of Ragnar and conquer Scandanavia and maybe even Britannia, France and the Holy Roman Empire. This is the game where you aren't restricted by anything, and in a series where alternate history is the norm.Edit: My only concern is that much of the game is locked away under DLC. While I love supporting a developer like Paradox I think I should also offer warning that playing without any expansions will limit much of your variety. I started playing the game when it originally came out and bought the DLC as they came out, but the price will seem daunting to those coming into the game. If you're just coming into the game without knowing anything, I'd recommend grabbing two DLCs in particular: "The Old Gods and The Legacy of Rome."

number of helpful: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Coming from games like the Total War series or the Civilization games, you might notice similarities to both at once. Think Medieval Total War played completely on the overview map but injected with a touch of Civs intrigue and a lot more provinces/factions. But that is barely, if ever scratching the surface. If you are a fan of Game of Thrones court politics or a history buff interested in having his own alternate timeline sandbox to play in, you are right at home.Want to be an English duke who sleeps with the king's wife and then assassinates said king to inherit his realm? You can do that.Want to start as a Hindu Indian raja and expand all the way to the Mediterranean while crushing the Arab Empire? You can do that.Want to be an ambitious Norse pagan in Scandinavia who amasses enough men to conquer Britain and impose the worship of Odin on all of Europe? You can do that too.Want to be a Zoroastrian prince in the Asian steppes who marries the princess of another khan but also has a b:astard son he got with his own sister? Guess what? Fair game. Before said description drives you to buy everything, be forewarned. 1.If this is your first grand strategy game, you have a bit of a steep learning curve in the beginning that, once surpassed, simply makes the game "click".  I absolutely recommend a must watch tutorial by Arumba on Youtube that does a far better job explaining stuff than the otherwise solid in game tutorial. You also might want to start as an Irish count in 1066 to get a hang of the game mechanics. 2. The base game has come a long way since launch and you can have a solid amount of fun with just it in your library. But the meat of the game and the huge range of choices is locked behind DLC. That wouldn't be too much of an issue if there weren't so many of them. I would absolutely not recommend paying full price for everything - sales are your friends as they usually group a bunch of DLC together for a fair price. You also don't need many of the flavour DLC. If you do buy the base game and decide to get the DLC gradually and later, for the safety of your wallet and for the biggest wealth of content, two are a must and are not expensive in sales - Sword of Islam and the Old Gods. Both unlock previously unplayable factions (aside from India) and Old Gods gives you an earlier starting date in the 9th century which many consider the best one (I tend to agree as Charlemaigne, while starting even earlier, isn't well balanced or pretty to look at). The rest you will get will be mostly based on your interests as each expansion tends to target one group of factions and mechanics.If you do have all or most of its content, you might agree with me that this is the most content packed and interesting role playing experience you have or will play in a long time. Simply for the amount of fun, investment and character immersion it is as of now my absolute favorite game of all time, faults and all. If the two points above don't scare you off, give it a chance and you will be heavily rewarded. What is more, the game is probably the best intro to grand strategy games you can find. Europa Universalis IV is another game from the same developer focusing on the Early Modern Era and it has an interesting feature where you can continue your CKII saves in a new time period, potentially making your game last for over 1000 in game years.Join in and welcome to CKII! Deus Vult!

number of helpful: 17 of 18 people (94%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												It's just awesome!This is one of the best game I've ever played so far. It's a strategy game in real time with the pause button :-)It's a sandbox game though there aren't specific targets, but you have to set your own goals, but you'll find yourself reviewing them continously adapting your strategy to either planned or unexpected events.In the game it's well represented the feudal system of the middle age, though you can start playing as Count, Duke, King or Emperor and therefore ramp up and grow your domain size caring about relationships within your own realm, your vassals and the court members, but also building alliances with other rulers via weddings.When you start a new campaign, you pick a ruler between 1066 and 1421 (Christians in vanilla, other rulers unlockable via DLCs like muslims, sea republics and pagans) and the target is to make your dinasty becoming more and more powerful. It's possible to start from 867 with "The Old Gods" DLC.You're noble then you should manage only castles or county having a castle in the capital (you could play as mayor if you have The Republics DLC).There are 3 types of character in the game nobles, religious and mayors which manage different types of holding and contribute to their liege's economy and armies in different ways. You can't have under your direct control all your lands, because any ruler has a limited number of holdings (demesne limit), beyond that you get huge penalty in relationships. You can earn other titles in many ways: you can inherit some lands if you're the heir of the relative title;you can speed up when this happens via plotting or assassination of the title holder or why not all the line of succesion before of you;you can push claim raising war, or even fabricate some or use claims of your vassals or relatives to raise the war and expand your realm;or why not decide to have your own antipope, which you can install, therefore having a really thankful pope, and in some conditions it will be even your vassals.For catholics the pope plays an important role, because it can excomunicate you or others, call for crusades, conceding divorces or granting you possibility to invade and therefore seize some other title.The game has also elements from RPGs, indeed any characters has 5 skills: diplomacy, martial, stewardship, intrigue and learning. And many traits either phisical traits or behaviour ones.  You can try to change skills and traits via proactive actions (ambition and plotting) or via casual events.Each ruler has a council of 5 people which helps them with specific matters: chancellor for diplomacy, marshall for armies, steward for the finance, spymaster for the intrigues and court chapelan for religious issues.There are other aspects in the game like buildings, technology research and ... All of these can be done either in single player or mutiplayer!So I've just tried to mention the most important to give an idea of what game you'll play, you're advised that this game has a steep learning curve.I warmly suggest to read the manual, see some let's play and then expirementing, and look for advices, but once you start mastering the game you'll get all the satisfaction and you'll find yourself sinking hours playing without even notice it.

												Crusader Kings II.  If I could choose only one strategy game to bring with me to a lonely desert island it would be this one.  The amount of content is insane (with new content being offered every few months), the updates are frequent, and the game play itself is extremely deep and rewarding.  There are time when I get the urge to play and I refuse to allow myself to because I know that if I start up another game I'll be playing it for the vast majority of my free time for the next several weeks.The game has so much to it that I couldn't even begin to do it justice without writing a ten page paper so I'll leave it at this: if you're a fan of strategy games, get this one!

content:
Posted: March 25
												I just started playing CK2 and cannot believe how much I've been missing over the years.  I love history. I love strategy games.  And I love roleplaying.  This game scratches every itch that I have as a result of those fascinations.  And it's the only game that I have ever played that can do that.This game tells a story unlike any other game that I've ever played - while also providing a good dose of strategy and challenge. Admittedly, due to the extensive amount of information provided, it requires a good bit of imagination to keep up with the story - but the game comes in at just the right level of abstraction so that new things can happen every game.  Paradox clearly understands emergent gameplay - which so many modern developers fail to understand.I own the vast majority of DLC and do not mind purchasing it.  If this keeps the game relevant and growing, then keep it coming.  I do not expect developers to work for me for free after I buy their initial product.  (Plus, many of the free patches added so much to the game by themselves.  Negative reviews seem to ignore this fact.) Anyways, I've been gaming for over 30 years and have not encountered a phenomenon like CK2 before.Count me in for as long as the developers keep pushing this wonderful game forward.

number of helpful: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Was playing online with friend. Seduced friends wife but got caught in the act. Friend castrated me as a punishment. 10/10 would give friends wife syphilis again.It should be called Walder Frey simulator 2014. Seriously everyone seems to get assassinated at weddings, your spy master is constantly telling you that people are homosexual and you should execute them, your wife is trying to kill you for no reason at all, your 4 year old daughter is married to a 62 year old dwarf from northern Africa, everyone is in incestuous relationships, and you have no idea what is going on. 10/10 game!At first a lot of people are put off by the presentation of this game (those who don't play Paradox Grand Strategy Games that is). The closest the majority of gamers (apologies for the generalisation) have gotten to a strategy game is Total War, Age of Empires or Civilisation; games that keep their audiences interested by dumbing down the complexities and keeping audiences hooked with visual entertainment through battle sequences (Please note, I am not criticising; I am a huge fan of these games).CK2 on the other hand is a colourful map, on first viewing, at best. This is a game that, at first glance - and I'm extending that time period out to your first 2-4 hours with it - seems like a cold, number-driven strategy game. Something only grognards can enjoy, in between tabletop wargame sessions and forum arguments over the finer points of Napoleon's invasion of Russia.And to be fair to first glances, it is. This is a Paradox grand strategy game, one that doesn't just crunch numbers, it grinds them to dust, sprinkles them across 11,715 buttons and menu options and feasts on them. It's an intimidating game to come to grips with, in no small part because Paradox are so terrible at tutorials, and almost as bad at creating intuitive user interfaces.Stick with it, though, and my. Oh my. What begins as a blind exercise in clicking things and getting your♥♥♥♥♥kicked all over Europe slowly begins to blossom. You start to realise what those little "lustful" and "deceitful" character traits on every character mean. You realise that the marriage system is an entire mechanic built into the game, not some pointless piece of window dressing. It clicks that, outside you own little fiefdom, the game is populated by every single noble, religious figure and courtier across Europe (and most of the Middle East).In short, you realise that this isn't a game about war, or empires, or money, or some pre-anointed goal you must achieve to be the "winner".It's a game about people. And the relationships between them.So why is it so addicting? That's simple, because it's the only game to have ever been developed (successfully) that's about sex and politics.Most others are about killing. And don't get me wrong, as head of a medieval dynasty, there will be the blood of thousands on your hands when your game is done.But in Crusader Kings II, unlike most other games - its strategy brethren especially - the wholesale murder of your enemies is but a sideshow. A diversion. The hammer you break out when all other approaches to victory have failed.You don't play Crusader Kings II as some disembodied hand, guiding the fate of a people. You play as, literally, a character within the world, part of a medieval dynasty. You can marry. Have kids. Send them off to be educated. Educate them yourself. Choose your own council. Assassinate people. Arrest people. Chop the head off the people you arrested. Arrest their kids, who revolt after you chopped their father's head off. Ask the Pope to excommunicate them. Arrange your kid's marriages. You can even invite people over for dinner.Every time you do one of these things, your relationships with people change, sometimes for the better, sometimes for the worse. They'll remember your past betrayals, and respect your past achievements. So aside from juggling the economy and the military of a Kingdom, you'll be spending as much (if not more) of your time juggling politics.And it's amazing. It's not until you're knee-deep in♥♥♥♥♥kissing and horse-trading (well, daughter-trading) that you realise, in all likelihood, you've never done something like this before. At least not something like this that works. And it really does work. Sure, it's based on numbers - quite literally, with each character screen giving you two numerical values, one reflecting another's opinion of you, the other, your opinion of them - but those numbers are just the game's way of communicating the complexity of the relationships, and you soon overlook them, reading past the values and seeing the overall feelings and sentiments driving them.From the mightiest empire to the lowliest county, you'll need to keep tabs on those closest to you, lest someone sneak in one night and poison you. Or stab you. Either or. If they do, well, it's game over.Oh, wait, it's not. Because this is Crusader Kings II we're talking about here, and it's smarter than that.When I said you're playing as part of a dynasty, that was only partially true. You are, but you're actually in control of the dynasty itself. So when your first character dies, provided they have a dynastic heir - whether that be a child or close family member - you take over as them, assuming control of not only a new character, but all their own personality traits, history, family and, most important of all, relationships.Say you're the King of England. You're loved in all corners of the land. But then, one day, you fall from your horse and are suddenly killed. Your son takes over, you think everything is gravy, but then... oh dear. Turns out your son is a homosexual, something jealous enemies can blackmail him (well, you, now) over. You're a coward. A weak ruler. Your wife, probably because of the whole sexual orientation thing, won't give you heirs.Before you know it, a once-happy Kingdom is in turmoil as power-hungry nobles attempt to overthrow you. You scrape your armies together, begin to crush the rebellion, advance on the final enemy, and then... you're killed on the battlefield. Your combat statistics weren't as good as your dad's, you see. You take control of your sole heir (who you suspected was someone else's kid anyway, since he was born while you were off fighting), a kid whose regent is even more incompetent than the last King, and before you know it, the throne is lost. You've gone from control of one of the mightiest Kingdoms in Europe to lording it over a few crummy towns.This should be game over. Or at least the point where you chuck it in, realising that there's no hope of victory from here. Only... remember, there is no victory. And there's 400 years of history to play through. It's entirely possible - and I know, because I've done it - to go from a King to a nobody and back to a King again in a few hundred years, courtesy of a slow and methodical game of revenge, of marrying the right people, cutting the right people's throats, climbing your way slowly up the ladder of political power.That scenario I just described? With heroism, tragedy, intrigue and scandal? It's just one story. From one game. In a complete playthrough of 400 years of European history, from the Norman invasion of England through to the 15th century, you'll encounter dozens more. Start your next game, even if it's in the exact same place, and it'll be a whole new experience. Start it somewhere else on the map and it'll be even more different still.The clashes of armies are just as important as clashes in the court or the bedroom, and by pinning a grand strategy game on your relationships with people, Crusader Kings II does just as good a job as George R R Martin has.Happy gaming!

content:
Posted: March 9
												So right out the gate: Crusader Kings II is a good game. It's got scope and range in spades. The kind that you can get lost in for a dozen hours, whatever kind of gamer you might be. The mechanics are pretty versatile, fitting the sort of playthrough you're looking for. If you're one of those gamey, tournament-style players and you just 'have' to minmax to take over half the world before that turn of the century... the tools are there. More power to you.There's also some meat in here for us slow rolling guys. Come up with a neat historical premise and work it through to completion. Or get caught out and castrated by angry rivals. It's your oyster.There's also a whole lot of story going on in this completely emergent simulation. If you're like me and the thought of creating your own alternate histories gets your rocks off, then you're in luck because CKII has by far the most in-depth alt-history game out there. One start date you can create a lasting Catholic Kingdom from within the belly of the Byzantine Empire... another you can fight off William the Conqueror and retain a truly Anglo-Saxon England... or maybe you want play as Poland and take a lesson from your Slavo-Russian cousins and carve an Empire out of the Holy Roman one... Pretty grand stuff and damned rewarding in their own right. The roleplay elements are pretty slick too. The characters you play as (Moreover, their dynastic line) can get as convoluted and involved as your HBO fantasy series. The cool thing about CKII's minimalist style is that it reads a lot like a book, painting a picture in your head of vast fleets of ships and clashing armies. You start to root for these little characters as you aim for a lasting Kingdom/Empire of their very own.But this segues neatly into the game's major shortcoming. If you want a fuller experience, you'll almost HAVE to dig into DLC. It's how Paradox operates. My advice? Your best bet is to take a look at which packs are on offer and nab the ones you can see yourself getting into. Myself, I immediately went for The Old Gods expansion because I'm nuts for Vikings. As you expand your repertoire with the game, you'll know exactly where to branch out. (I also suggest getting Charlemagne if you want the ability to create your own 'original' 'new' kingdoms: like any good Alternate History buff would wanna do) It almost goes without saying that you should wait for a Steam sale if you don't want to fork over your life's savings.In the end, Crusader Kings II is far and away one of the best strategy games on the market. It's also a gateway drug for learning more about medieval history. You'll get to know everything from the Mongols to the Magyars like the back of your hand. Impress all the folks with your grasp of that sort of worldly stuff.Like I said, it's broad. You can dig into this one for 400 hours and still be surprised by the next hundred. Thumb is up.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												This game's learning curve is not just steep... the tutorial is garbage and only slightly grazes the major aspects of the game (it doesn't go into any of the in-depth mechanics that the game so notably advertises about, and it definetly doesn't do a good job at teaching how to play).I play all genres of games and am used to learning strange and odd game mechanics.  I am 30 years old and have been gaming since the original Atari console.  When I read reviews about this game I wasn't phased by everyone saying the learning curve was steep.  I have owned mostly every major game console released, as well as have played a few years worth of game hours in PC games.  On top of that, I have played dungeons and dragons (the dice version with a DM/GM), I have played text-based games such as the original kings quest... I have played many board games, book games, card games... etc... What I am trying to allude to is that I am an experienced gamer with above-average technical and troubleshooting abilities; usually I am the one my friends go to when they need help with figuring something out.I have spent close to 3 hours in the game and still feel I have no control over what is going on within the game, nor do I feel I have a solid grasp on how to gain control over what is going on within the game.  I understand not being able to just pick up a game and master it... but 3 hours is too long to spend in a game to still be constantly feeling at a loss in trying to do something and not being able to do it.  I can play the game, but I in-no-way enjoy constantly feeling frustrated because I'm trying to do something that I can not do.I no longer have the time I had when I was younger to play games, so when I play a game, I want to enjoy it.  I feel I would need to invest a minimum of 10 hours into this game, just to have a solid grasp on how to play it.  That is too much for me, considering most modern non-rpg games can be beaten in less than 10 game-hours.I'm not saying I'm not willing to invest hours into a game, as I've invested close to 120 game-hours into some of my games... but I have searched for more reviews and people, like me, have also had major difficulties in understanding how to manipulate the game (even when some people who are experienced in playing the game helping them).For me... with the horrible tutorial... the insanely large amount of "buy in" time required to learn the game... this game just isn't worth it.  There are many easier-to-play and more in-depth games out there similar to this.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												I love this game. The systems and mechanics seem to be balanced perfectly for emergent narrative. While the strategy is awesome, I find the best part of this game is the stories that develop from those systems.The depth is amazing. I’ve played over 100 hours now and have only really played one full game, and 2 half games. My first Ironman game (no loading saves) I started as Denmark. I managed gained Norway, but lost it despite assassinating tens of people in the succession line ahead of my heir. I made inroads into Sweden before taking it entirely (after the then King got taken down by a mercenary army), then married my way onto the throne of Lotharingia and used my new power to take Pomerania - in the process becoming the most powerful ruler in the Holy Roman Empire. I demanded independence from the Holy Roman Emperor who buckled before me, splitting the Empire in two. I basked in glory for several decades (holding several feasts and tournaments) before a massive continental war spanning over ten years, during which my successor lost control of Lotharingia and Pomerania. Once the dust cleared, I had to settle for being Queen of Sweden and Denmark. But you don't mind stuff like that happening - playing a count or a duke can be as much fun (and way less stressful) than being a King or an Emperor. I held onto those two kingdoms while gaining Finland, before marrying the Kaiserin of the Holy Roman Empire! Everything was coming up Chris, but then she sadly died in childbirth - leaving my son as the Kaiser. Comparisons to game of thrones in game form are not far off, in fact there is a mod (I haven't tried) and like GOT there is absolutely no guarantees of a happy ending. In my game I managed to become the Kaiser and clung grimly to the throne until the end of the game. All that in just one game - and I haven't even got the latest expansion yet, which adds India. The multiplayer is great too, playing with a friend means you can work together and there is someone there to enjoy the narrative with you, and leads you to great stuff like marrying your buddy (in the game) and then cheating on them. Or making them your Master of the Hunt. One complaint would be the learning curve, in that I had no idea what I was doing for the first 20 or so hours. Also periods (years sometimes) can go by with not a lot happening, but I just speed it up in those instances. Once you invest 25 or so hours into learning the game, the rewards are amazing.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												TL;DR: Crusader Kings II takes a long time to learn, so don't buy it expecting it to be something you can just jump into unless you play a lot of strategy or Paradox titles. If you have a lot of time to kill, are imaginative, and love character oriented games then this will probably be a good fit for you. There is a wide range of mechanics from choosing a spouse to trying to assassinate anyone (in the entire game, no essential characters). The DLC isn't as money-grubbing as it may appear at a glance. Not all the DLC may fit any one person's preferences, so I recommend researching what the expansions are and what they contain. I approve of this game!   Crusader Kings II is the game that I absolutely must review (133 hours and growing playtime). I will do my best to remain impartial throughout this review and to address the game as it is, while offering some opinions on things such as DLC, despite being somewhat biased. The game is rather difficult to learn at first, so if you are not a patient person or do not have the time to learn the game and want something you can just jump into, then Crusader Kings II probably isn't the game for you (it took me 8 hours to learn how to play).  On the other hand, if you like strategy titles, participating in assassination plots, conquering lands and have a lot of time to kill, then this might be a game that you'll enjoy. For the most part, I think Crusader Kings II has something to offer everyone, even the strategically challenged (like me. I'm awful at this game and therefore use console commands, but it doesn't hamper my enjoyment at all). At it's core, Crusader Kings II is more about the characters than conquering everything. Indeed, the game ends at a certain date (1453) rather than when everything is under one's thumb or certain conditions are met (excluding the date being reached). Characters have their own randomized events (often fun and quirky) that can shape their stats and relationships with each other. Events can range from having an affair to being possessed. Some events have choices, while others do not. In addition to events and the obvious fighting, there are also plots which allow you to do things like try and arrange someone's death through assassination, go on hunts, or hold a feast. I know I'm really starting to beat a dead horse here, but nearly everyone that has played multiple games of Crusader Kings II has that ONE character that sticks in their mind (mine was a guy that adopted a cat, lost an arm in battle, held a massive funeral for said cat when it passed of old age, and then died of an infection shortly after the cat's funeral). The characters of the player's and game engine's creation are something so wonderful.Some other mechanics include: Marriage (anyone of opposite gender can be married if conditions are met), Lovers (same-sex or otherwise), dungeons with prisoners that can be executed, ransomed, or released, fabricating claims on land to go to war, going to war, hiring mercenaries, converting areas to your religion, and whatever mods may add. The mod community for this game is really awesome, variety-filled and big!  One thing that I rather dislike, but makes sense, is that you have to have a Casus Belli (cause for war) to be able to declare war and go out to fight. This is either achieved by being of a certain culture, having differing religions, or a claim (fabricated or legitimate). On the bright side, this does prevent the AI from ganging up on you.Something rather off putting to a newcomer of the game, at least it was to me, is the large number of DLC. Most of the DLC is cosmetic in nature, while a few do add some changes to the game (improvements or otherwise, I'm looking at you Conclave). The really neat thing, in my opinion, about   the DLC that adds functions is that some of those functions are patched into the game for free. One such example would be India's landmass was patched into the game for free so that players may fight and conquer India, but to play as an Indian you must own the DLC. In terms of which DLC to buy, I'd say use the search engine of your choice, figure out what the expansions are, and then what they contain (if that strikes your fancy, of course). I will say that while amazing, I don't feel the DLC are necessary and that the base game provides more than enough entertainment, but they certainly are fun!

Posted: January 18, 2014
												Crusader Kings II is a great starting point for anyone who's been looking to get into the grand strategy genre but has been overwhelmed by Paradox's previous titles. Fairly easy to learn, and with all the gameplay improvement and alternative history mods, you'll get plenty of time for your money.As someone who's played over 500 hours in Deus Vult, I did find it a little disappointing that Ck2 didn't inflict the same amount of ungodly punishment that the previous games did; One of the best experiences in Deus Vult was getting beat down constantly and getting back up, but I'll be the first to admit it was probably for the best. Ironman is a very interesting feature that suffers slightly from the constant autosaving disrupting gameplay, but this may not be such a big issue if you have a good computer that autosaves quickly.Now one major concern is the unending horde of DLC. I really don't approve of the direction Paradox Interactive is going with their DLC for Ck2, paying for historical dynasty shields? Ehhhh.The game is priced at $40To get all the major DLC's (Expansions) alone costs $55As It stands, CK2 is not worth buying full price. Wait for a sale where the collection is 75% off and grab it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Starting as Byzantine Emperor in the Viking Age in Ironman mode, I promptly began fighting off the Muslims on the border of my Empire and reclaimed several small islands. Given my huge income of 100+ gold from all my vassals, I decided to upgrade Constantinople and many of my holdings. Hours later, I mended the Great Schism by conquering Holy Lands and declaring them mine. Most of Europe became Orthodox and I removed the Pope from his seat, leaving no Christian rulers. I was then known as "The Saint", and gave birth to a long line of Byzantine Emperors who ruled with iron fists, seeking to return the Legacy of Rome.After years of crusading and aggressive expansion into Italy and the Middle East, I reclaimed the old Roman Borders. The Roman Empire was once more established, but Rome was not done. All the land from Constantinople to Egypt, Egypt to Spain, Spain to France, Germany, parts of Russia, and all of Scandinavia were to be conquered. I gained the S.P.Q.R achievement for restoring all that belonged to Rome and more. Much of the Middle East was conquered and pushed back. With an income of 500+ gold a month and trading posts spanning around the entire Empire, I was set.Until it all changed, the Golden Horde formed and attacked me after I just finished off the 10th civil war to lower crown authority. The Khan stole a great chunk of land, and I was seriously low on man power. The Golden Horde continued to push foward, while my army was busy fighting off civil wars and religious rises. I finally managed to win my civil wars, and was left with a few years time to rebuild my army. 600K+ troops later with a personal levy of 80K retinues, I took back what was mine and destroyed the Golden Horde. With less than 30 years left until end game, I was looking forward to saying I conquered most of the world without cheating. Yeah, not so much. My cousin forms the Kingdom of France and fights for independance, and somehow most of my Empire flocks towards him to rebel against me. My army is cut in half, and I am busy trying to fend off France while also being attacked by mysterious figures that start assassinating my bloodline. I eventually murder all of my cousins children, excommunicate him, and then murder him. I am victorious, the Great Emperor Buoso II. Little did I know, I had a falling out with the rest of my bloodline for killing a family member. My title is usurped, and I am forced to watch as my Uncle begins to lose Kingdoms worth of land to vassals rebelling against their liege. I assassinate him and try to marry my child into power, but before I can do that his son is also killed by that mysterious assassin. This leaves no rightful hier to the Empire of Rome, and it splits apart again.Every duchy, county, kingdom, and what have you in the entire world splits up into over 500+ independant states. Everyone starts fighting for power, and I sit there having just lost a game I spent over 50+ hours on. My jaw drops. My computer couldn't handle the entire world fighting and I eventually just gave up on that game. Crusader Kings II can change in the blink of an eye.10/10. I'd play that♥♥♥♥♥♥again.I have some pictures here (not of my final result, but showing much of the progress).http://i.imgur.com/2I9JmLT.jpg?1http://i.imgur.com/REBviYv.jpg?1http://i.imgur.com/5nLhLny.jpg?1http://i.imgur.com/pYaMvOg.jpg?1http://i.imgur.com/UHs9d9a.jpg?1http://i.imgur.com/Xcqa26M.jpg?1http://i.imgur.com/Iy0Tsj8.jpg?1

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												The title Crusader Kings 2 falls under the so-called grand-strategy games. The term is well-earned in this case and before you start the game be warned that there is a steep learning curve. Do not pick up this game if long-winded games that requires hours of hours to finish is not your thing. Do pick it up if you like games like Civilization, Alpha Centauri, or Europe Universalis. Having said that, and perhaps you do not know these titles, lets get into what Crusader Kings 2 actually is.Like all grand-strategy games Crusader Kings 2 is (but need not be, I will get back to this) for instance about creating a dukedom, kingdom, or empire, keeping those under you happy less they revolt, and creating a proper army. Unlike many other grand strategy games (outside of other Paradox titles) this game is actually historically correct for medieval europe, the middle east, and India. That is right, did you ever want to play as William the Conquerer? This game gives you that opportunity.That immediatly leads to 'need not be' clasule I said before. Unlike other grand strategy games you do not play a 'faction' or a 'nation', but you play as an individuel e.g. Ghengis Khan. The game doesn't end when you die, however, no it follows the rise (and fall) of your family as your dominion grows on the map. Depending on your succesion laws you might be playing as your oldest, youngest, or even a random family member. You might even go super modern and have daughters rule on purpose, not 'just because' the male line ended as was more the case in the time period between 769-1452 AD (which how long the games played out assuming you have two DLCs).The game features cultures (e.g. German, Anglo-Saxon, Berber, Russian, Visigothic, and Tamil) as well as religions (e.g. Hindu, Catholic, Coptic, Karasite, Tengri, Sunni, and Germanic) and this including with recently conquered, traits of a person, your history with them perhaps, can all influence what people think of you. Wil you marry out a daughter for an alliance, or perhaps with that genius of a man so you can get him to court and get a good advisor? This is all dependent upon you.Thanks to all these features, as well as the fact that once the game starts randomness kicks in and the historical accurate timeline is lost, means that you will never(!) play the same game ever again. Mechanics wise yes, but give it enough time and the map will look quiet different from last time, different kings and emperors, and perhaps e.g. the Byzantine empire might have fallen by 1100. What will you do? How will you influence medieval Europe? I say it is time to find out and play Crusader Kings 2 for yourself.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Backstab, fight, talk and murder your way to victory.Wow, just wow. Another hit title by Paradox, an almost certain must buy! Launch yourself into an immersive, and ever changing campaign, spanning over 500 years (providing you have the Old Gods DLC). Ever wanted to be King of England? Kaiser of the Holy Roman Empire? Or simply wanted to be a low-lying Baron? Look no further, Crusader Kings II is for you! Crusader Kings II is certainly one of the best Paradox games out there, with a whole new gameplay interface. If games like Victoria II and Europa annoyed you because the lack of character interaction, Crusader Kings II is perfect to settle that fetish of yours.Dive into the famous Godwin family in 1066, and try fight of the Norse hordes, and the Norman aggressors, or make your own House (with the ruler designer DLC), and help it rise into the anals of history. CKII has an in-depth system of character interaction, where you can do anything from sending them a gift, assassinating them, offering them vassalage, or organising a marrage, anything is possible in CkII.Buy this game, all it's DLCs, and get lost in the (almost) never-ending and ever-changing campaign, which will get you hooked from day 1, to the end-day.Enjoy!

Posted: May 7, 2016
												This game is awesome. Start out as a little guy in Ireland and become the Emperor of the British Isles, and then lose it all in a generation and you're a count again. Except this time you're a count somewhere in Germany because on a previous character you married some German count's daughter, and he had a feud with someone who murdered all of his sons and you ended up inheriting it. Well now I guess you're in Germany so you start all over again. You fabricate some claims, and invite some claimants and land them, allowing you to take land for them that will be added to your overall realm. Eventually you're big enough and you've bribed enough people that you manage to get yourself elected Holy Roman Empire. Now the might of the Reich is going to go down upon that upstart Duke who thought he could overthrow you as Emperor of Britain.Every game can be this interesting. Try it.

												-Plays multiplayer as king of Denmark with a buddy as king of Sweden. We unite Scandinavia and reform the faith. I basically become the Pagan Pope.-The King of both France and Germany (Charlemagne's empire before the creation of Holy Roman Empire) dies... last and only heir is a guy exiled in muslim Spain who converted to Allah.-King of France and germany is now muslim zealot, refuses to convert to christianity, forces most aristocrats to convert to Islam and uses them to convert the people too.-Allies himself with Muslim Spain and proclaims Jihad after Jihad on us because the Pagan holy sites we captured used to be Frankish lands. Muslims form the most powerful alliance in Europa. We hold our ground, losing and taking back Saxon lands. We pillage neighbouring lands to invest into the army when the onslaught begins anew.-Catholic brits and italians send crusade after crusade to try and retake Catholic lands to no avail. They slow the Andalus down but they keep coming to die in the frozen wastes... It has been 5 Jihads now. Around 20.000/30.000 soldiers thrown at us...EACH TIME.-We manage incredible victories due to clever strategy. We counter-attack with our own holy wars because they cannot declare war on us at their leisure during truce. I take the lands of Flanders. My friend takes Germany, I crown him Emperor of the Germanic people, bulwark of the faith.-Most of France is converted now. The holy wars still rage on, though the muslim threat is being contained by a clever use of Pagan and Christian Holy wars during muslim internal struggles in order to even the odds.-The last king of Italy dies and the Byzantine Emperor inherits the title. A new challenger joins the fray. Stronger than ever. Catholic Aquitaine revolts and with our indirect help, becomes independent.-Yet it does not end... I can already hear the warcry of the faithful heathens coming to spill our blood. Allahu Ackbar... Allahu Ackbar...Ragnarok, the end times, are coming and it's symbol is a golden crescent.10/10 Would create nightmarish dystopian far-right propaganda by accident again.

number of helpful: 134 of 235 people (57%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14
												Thought I'd do a proper review of this game because there are none, most are just an event description or part of someones playthrough with no information about the actual game. Or something lame like "best game ever played. the end" Thanks for the really helpful info guys.This is a grand strategy game similar to classics like Civilization. It's set during the Middle Ages to the High Middle Ages. You take control of (or create your own) dynasty/family and try to survive. How does it play? Slowly... very slowly.The game is essentially just a huge map with a few single soldiers dotted about representing armies. You have a few menu's with options such as changing laws (which you have to wait for 10 years to change) and there is your council who can do a few things on the map such as fabricate claims, train troops, plot etc.Conquest is not easy especially if you're catholic, as its full of realistic mechanics such as the pope in his pointy hat telling you ya can't invade good christians willy nilly. But these mechanics and the random events that pop up are what make the game shine, it makes it a much more realistic and satisfying experience and some are just plain funny but they do need to be made more flexible to make the game more playable. In order to conquer someone you need to justify it, so for example you could have your son marry a local lords daughter and when they have children they will have a claim to the lords land, that's the 3rd generation! So you spend a lot of time waiting around for events to pop up and people to do the things you assign them to, building up armies, waiting to get pregnant, waiting for the children to grow up, waiting for someone to kill the other heir ect.It's like a song of ice and fire or game of thrones the game (and not that telltale♥♥♥♥♥♥ this has real freedom to create the imbred zealot dwarf family of your dreams, pushing kids out of windows and capturing concubines, smothering babies and that classic poisoned wine, each playthrough tells a unique story (if the events randomly pop up) but its in a realistic medieval setting (no targaryens but theres a good mod out there), history buffs should enjoy this game, especially if you're into that particular part of history. But like I warned you everything takes a VERY long time to do and most of the time you are sitting twiddling your thumbs which some will find boring.I've played this game for well over 300 hours on and offline and I do like it, in fact it can be addictive and the soundtrack is great too but unfortunately Paradox are well aware of how much of a gem this game is and do an EA - The Sims franchise style dlc system where they sell you the game in chunks and each time they bring out a new DLC they update the base game to balance it out so if you don't have the DLC I would imagine this would alter gameplay in a negative way. But at least with those sims games you get actual content. But what is the DLC in this? Not much really, they just add new functionality to the game which affects game play a bit and they can be fun but you don't really get a lot for your money. The game is just a huge map with a few crude single soldiers representing an army, all adding functionality does is create a new sub menu or events which are just text, so really you shouldn't have to pay for them and they should be in a free update as they are just a few lines of code or maybe Paradox should finish the game with the holes filled... I mean with the DLC options included in the base game instead of behaving like subscribed early access but everything is about money so what do you expect, this is why I don't recommend this game. Sorry fanboys the truth hurts and not all of us have loads of money. Wait for a sale or until Paradox have bled it dry and everyones bored of it and pick it up at a more realistic price, this game is definitely NOT worth £122.99 (14/02/2017). If you cannot wait until then this game is not for you, it's all about waiting.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Where do I start. This game is addictive as all hell. It is a pure character role play orientated game where you play generation from generation of your family throughout the dark ages with everything revolving around how YOU as the player mould your character and his/her successors. This does mean that a single playthrough from just 1066 to 1453 can take in the excess of sevral days.Have you ever wanted to play as a Spaniard with Russian culture who is a staunch believer of the Zoroastrian faith and conquer Germany? In this game, you can! That is just the tip off the iceberg of insanity. I have had a succession war with my 1st born son who was also the SPAWN OF SATAN, literally a hell baby.Now understand this game can be daunting to new players especially because there are no real good tutorials provided by the game. That is definitely a shortfall and has to be made up with Youtube tutorials or experienced friends who play the game. The other problem is how random some events can be which can royally screw over a fresh game. I wont go into details but I am sure many of my fellow players can recount situations the destroyed their games. Also It pretty much a requirement to get game mechanic DLC such as Old Gods and the Republic to get the most out of the game. That is the only real problems I can think of with the game. Otherwise its an excellent game with challenges and character driven role play. Fantastic modding community always re-inventing the game and extending the hours of life this game has. I don’t think this game can be adequately compared to any other just because how unique it is.I rate this game 11/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
THE MEDIEVALSIMSFeatures:+++ HISTORY/GEOGRAPHY CLASSES WHILE PLAYING!+++ Community Driven DLCs and MODs.++ Grand Strategy of medieval europe sim.++ Tons of thousands of features and highly moddable.++ GAME OF THRONES MOD.+- Gets boring after reaching empire from scratch (but they will revolt, surely).Grand strategy political micromanagement game, you will understand that Arbitrary Rulers can do whatever the hell they think they want. Sending roses for a neighbor, ending up taking care of the garden.Marriages for political reasons, alliances because the enemy of my enemy is my friend, duchies stronger than kingdons, kingdons that might rise out of nowhere, you will learn that family members are actually your worst enemies (not that different from nowadays I think) and you will lose battles, win wars, learn how grateful you were for making friends, and how stupid you were for not realizing someone else's friends are really powerful.Educate your brood, rule over the vulnerable, offer protection and prey on the weak, intrigue and plot over claims, create claims with your court, become a paragon of virtue and control a religion, call holy wars on infidels, kill your enemy on battle, kill your enemy on an ambush, become friends with your fellow neighbors, walk the lands as looters for money and supplies.Spread your dynasty around the world, spread your seed around, deal with invasions from the west, invasions from the east, revolts, religious zealots with massive armies spreading havock over your lands, learn that the real use of religion is for politics, learn that children can be conditioned.Change history, create empires, destroy mighty foes, rise the ladder of the prestige, be envied by your enemies, die in the annals of nowhere, if you become incapable watch as your regent push laws and change things as he sees fit.Play online with your friends, same kingdom or different kingdoms, be kind and deceitful, be cruel but just, be a jerk, be a leader, be yourself, be your character but always remember: Real world will never be the same once the feudal knowledge affects your judgement.This game is a training for fatherhood.Also, watch out for the Game of Thrones MOD.

content:
Posted: April 2
												The best way to describe CK2 is with the stories you create. So here's a tale that happened a long time ago in the far away land of the domains of the Wendish Empire. Once upon a time, there was this Emperor of the Slavs, called Grozscon, who was a magnanimous person, a true born leader and a great military strategist. He arose to power in the age of 22, after his father and elder brother died in a battle against rebels.  At the age of 30, he already had conquered most part of the Holy Roman Empire, the Balkans, Scandinavia and most part of Russia. When he completed his 55, he started a great campaign to conquer England. In one of the battles, his youngest son, Dobieslaw, died. But that did not distracted the old emperor and finally the war was won.  As we grow old, our health start to fail us, and this was no different with Grozscon. He was diagnosed with leprosy, the purgatory in earth, so they say. And at the age of 81, the old emperor passed away, leaving 4 sons and 3 daughters.  Hir heir, Boleslaw, also had leprosy and was at the final stage of the disease and died with only 4 months of ruling. The Empire was in the hands of the grandson of the great emperor Grozscon, who was called Mieszko, The Effeminate, Duke of Silesia.   Mieszko was a poor ruler, a cruel and sloth person, which made him very unpopular with his vassals. Therefore, rebellions started to appear in every corner of the Wendish Empire, leading to great civil wars between Mieszko and his uncles. While the empire was in great chaos, the marvelous Empire of the Greeks flourished and grew strong and eventually took many provinces from the Wendish Empire. The Holy Roman Emperor, ever the opportunist, also invaded and at the last the Pope in Rome called for a Crusade against the Wendish Empire.    Mieszko now finds himself deposed, with only a count title in a god forsaken province and watches in despair as the Empire is thorn apart by endless wars and new rumours comes from the east, were a man controls many riders and conquers everything his set his eyes. 10/10 Would play again and kill all the sons except the perfect heir

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I learned a lot of geography from this game and EU IV.Seriously, come trivia night, my geography is really on point. Capitals, country locations, rivers, I know that stuff.Which is nice.This may be the most complete and well rounded historical simulator available, and its mechanics are unique without being gimmicky. You see CK2 is about forging a dynasty, which is a fancy way of saying a rules heavy family. It's technically sandbox and you can have quite a bit of fun with it. You can roleplay as the traits that you have, or just try to make every character into Julius Caesar, or just keep assasinating popes, forever and ever. When your character dies, whether it be at 4 or 88, the play goes to the direct heir, whether he or she be 4 or 88, and you are given control over their decision making process. As long as your dynasty has not died out in terms of inheritance laws, and someone in your dynasty has a sufficient title the game will continue until it stops after maybe dozens or a hundred hours of game play. You manage titles under your realm. Count is the lowest, than Duchy, than King, than Emperor, with some variety on the names depending on your culture. The key here is feudalism, that is vassalage. The standard is to pledge fealty to someone of the next higher title, who then pledges fealty to the title above them. This standard is never reached unless you conquer the world and make it be reached. In general, there will be sovereign Dukes, Counts pledged directly to Kings, and Emperors often forgo vassal kings. You have advisers which are assigned from your court,  which is a pool of loyal or disloyal followers whom you can consider for various roles, and to accomplish various tasks. These advisers assist you in running the operations of your feifdom, and allow religious, educational, espionage, stewardship, and martial decisions. Each character has an RPG style stat for each of these, and these along with a portion of your wife's stats and your advisers stats creates the stats used in game for you.Key decisions in this game are marriage, and war. Marriage is the influence you have over your dynasty, and you can get good traits, titles, claims on titles, or political alliances in exchange for the matrimony. Wars allow you to cement alliances and shape the geopolitical landscape. There is much more to the game, as it has surprising complexity, but this is not to be a guide.The game is visually very appealing, despite largely being a giant map. The music is nice, and even after several hours you may not be bored. There is also a ton of DLC for this, for better or worse. These are largely all expansive on the game, and most will be on for most games. Some like the Sunset Invasion are cheesy alternative history which you likely will not want on at all times. There are an absurd number of starting rulers at any of a number of initial scenarios, and a bit of imagination makes all interactions fun as you write your own story of world history amongst the players who have interesting personalities derived from their traits. This game remains an absolute treasure, and is still updated from time to time.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												As I'm coming closer to the 300 hour mark I think it's my obligation to honor this game with a short review.Crusader Kings 2 is one of those games that just provide you with everything you personally ever wanted in a strategy game, though you never knew that you wanted that before you tried it out. How could I have known my weakness for arresting and torturing christian priests wandering the plains of Russia?Sure, getting started can be rough and frustrating, as the tutorial barely scratches the surface of the ocean of possibilities that is CK2. And even now, after burning more than an entire week of my precious life time with this game I still learn new mechanics and features every time.But once you understand the main aspects it's pretty easy getting completely absorbed in this medieval reality show where you are both director and protagonist.And after I fought the emperor in an open revolt, trapped him in the Alpes where his great army died of starvation, and then duelled him in personal combat on the highest mountain surrounded by thousands of frozen corpses, stroke him down with my Damascus Steel sword, spilled his blood on the snowy plains, and then took the emperor's crown from his dead, cold hands, while ... simultaneously seducing his wife - I knew I would love this game. If you also want to spend your nights creating your own historical BBC documentary I'm the last person to stop you.All you need is a strong imagination to fill the ugly text boxes with life and perhaps a full wallet if you intend to participate in their crazy DLC policy. Which I would only adivice you to do if you already know that you're addicted anyway.

Posted: February 21, 2015
												While truly there are lots of things to enjoy about CK2, and everyone finds his own most favourite part in this game, I personally find the stories it creates the most exciting part about it. For example, this story happened just yesterday.One day my character was chilling in a carriage in his old family lands in Hungary when suddenly he was ambushed and taken prisoner by some weirdo in Brittany. The freak tortured my character with rats. What is worse, I had no money to buy my way out of the prison. At the same time, my lovely new wife became pregnant, and, for obvious reasons, this could not be my character's child. After the first daughter came the second and only then my unwitty spymaster uncovered that the weird guy and my unfaithful wife had an affair! Sadly, due to my liege's incompetency in managing the realm, my lands were constantly pillaged by vicious pagan tribes, leaving me with almost no income. Moreover, the regent that was installed to rule in my character's place was a nice and a charitable guy. He shared all of my petty income with the starving and underprivileged. He did not like my character either and never agreed to anything I have asked him to do. My poor character ended up in a dark and cold oubliette after his friend tried to rescue him and failed. He soon passed away, betrayed by everyone. He only needed 20 more gold coins to buy his way out...Soon after the news reached Hungary, king's brother was selected as the new king. Being an envious, lustful and ambitious fellow, he always found his brother's wife to be prettier and more attractive than his own. He immediately divorced and married the unfaithful widow. A few months later, the new king decided to relieve his stress by embarking on a carriage trip to his old family's lands, when suddenly they were stopped on a road by a group of french-speaking hoodlums...

												This is essentially Game Of Thrones: the game.In my first game, I played as an Irish ruler, and got him married to an English lady to cement an alliance, allowing me to begin a conquest of Ireland. My wife proceeded to bear me daughter after daughter, which due to the country's male inheritance laws left my vassals unhappy.Then, her father dies and she is left as his heir - she returns to her home county in England. I realise I need a new wife if I'm to ever have a male heir, yet I can't divorce her or I'll end up making enemies of the English. So, I start a plot to assassinate her.The very first person who offers their help with killing her? The bishop she was sleeping with! And he'll be most valuable, having lots of "access" to her! content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												If you are buying this game, remember that you are not buying a complete product. You are buying a platform for DLCs which are the vast majority of the game. Paradox restricts you very tightly as to whom you can play, and when you can play, and what you can do if you do not buy hundreds of dollars of DLC. I personally think Paradox's DLC model on this is very unethical and would not reccomend this game to anybody who wanted a full game for a reasonable price. You can only play as western christian rulers from a relatively narrow timespan if you do not have dlc. Paradox seems to have gotten better with this, as EUIV has a DLC model that allows a full gameplay experience without DLC, but the DLC enhance it, but this is just a demo to make you want to buy dlc.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												This game basically runs like a diplomacy simulator, enabling the player to build their own dynasty the way they want it to be. With an array of different options at your disposal, and a citizenry to keep happy, Crusader Kings can present a challenge. Using Historical time periods and even historical heads of state, The appeal of Crusader Kings 2 moves beyond lovers of Diplomacy games. Dealing with Heir's, Vassals, and underhanded siblings, Crusader Kings allows you to micromanage your dynasty, enabling a player to give their line a personal touch. I don't typically go for these types of games, but in fairness, it is fairly well done and offers a lot of playability options so I have to recommend it if that is the kind of game you enjoy.
