content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I used to ship this game and with over 800 hours (I have a lot of offline time, trust me) I believe I can say that I’ve played through the majority of what this game has to offer. I won’t even lie, I have enjoyed this game immensely throughout most of my hours played and I think it is a good game everyone should experience at some point during a sale. However, that all changed when the updates attacked.*proceeds to stare at the DLC using peripherals* He whispers solemnly, “I’ll be seeing you in a minute”. I have played this game for the better part of two years and I have to say that I absolutely hate the direction of the updates placed upon this game. Even though you can opt for old versions of the game in beta, I feel as though the game has moved backwards at times. 	My most recent issue with the game stems from some bull crap I got during a war I started with Norway in Scandinavia. I attack and completely decimated their army, I also managed to take their capital and 80% of their fiefs (got like 1/100 percent for it). Even so, the war percent dropped form 80% to 30% in a second for no reason, I wasn’t even attacked. Long story short, other countries attacked me after like 30 years of holding all their counties and I lost. The game has some serious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to work out and I’m tired of sitting in a game for hours on end strategizing for it to all crumble away due to unexplainable ♥♥♥♥ery. I’ve seen a lot of crap in my days playing this game (Believe it) but boy does this♥♥♥♥♥♥takes the cake. Nothing close has ever happened to me like this before the recent updates (At least not at this scale). I even summoned 7500 troops using my massive prestige and I was still defeated out of some form of broken attrition.	Now for my biggest gripe about the game *Walks over to DLC and whispers in its ear* “Its’ time”. Holy crap this game has more DLC then fricking Total war games. I bought the vanilla version of this game on sale for what I though was a reasonable price. However, shortly after I bought it, they released a “complete” edition of the game which I thought was all of the DLC. WRONG! I’ve never been angrier about making a video game purchase in my entire life. I would rather rebuy No Mans Sky than rebuy the entire game I had with DLC for another 40$ (which was cheaper than just buying all of the DLC). You would think they would at least give all of the DLC to me (you know... since it’s “complete”). Seriously this game makes EA look generous. I appreciate buying DLC if it adds flavorful content and improves on the game, I’m all for it! But when your game pushes out tons of DLC and about 50% of it is complete garbage, usually priced at 15$, it makes me question my sanity. Ps. Despite all my rage *rock music intensifies* I still recognize that I can raid Rome to the ground, kidnap the pope and sacrifice his corpse to Thor. If it wasent for all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t DLC scamming and crappy update direction that somewhat makes you feel as though you need to buy certain DLC, this game would be perfect. Really tired of being treaed as a wallet by developers I put my faith in. TLDR: Don’t get shafted by this game by buying it with a bundle. I recommend buying it for like 10$ when it goes on sale again for the vanilla game. There are some good DLC like Viking Conquest etc. but make sure you read all the additional DLC reviews before purchasing. Yes I am mad.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 17
												It all began in one small kingdom. I was a wise king, who married Hungarian princess. We had 2 children, one daughter and one son, my heir. My wise uncle taught my son everything he knew. I had one very trusting vassal, who had stronger military than me. Luckily, he was my close friend, and he wasn't greedy, so I didn't have to assassinate him. I appointed my cousin to be a regent in case of my death, just until my son grew up old enough to rule. Everything was perfect, peace and prosperity ruled over my kingdom. But suddenly, I fewer hit me. I fell into bed and never recovered.My regent took over. His wife was an arabian princess, who was a bit greedy. She plotted to assassinate my son who was soon to become the king. Regent knew this, but decided not to imprison his wife, instead he waited. Her plot was a success, the heir was dead and her son became new heir. Feeling pressured by his council, new king, my cousin, imprisoned his wife for murdering my son. She was prisoner for 2 years, then he decided to execute her so he could get married again. He married a Hungarian princess (I guess it was in our blood to love Hungarian girls :P) and he also married his son to the princess of Aragon.My vassal didn't mind the change, he respected the new king, but hated his son. Finally, our army had become stronger than our rival's and we attacked. We crushed them and made their old ruler our vassal. Alas, not all was fine. The king was injured in a battle and became incapable of leading the country. Soon after he died. His son took over the title. But now, he had a problem, his father's most faithfull vassal hated him and became his rival. He tried to bribe him and award him honorary titles, but that hardly worked. He had even sent official diplomatic envoys few times to try to sweet talk the vassal, but that didn't work either. That had a great impact on army size of the entire kingdom since almost half of that army came from that vassal.The old vassal, whose kingdom we conquered saw an opportunity. He plotted to kill the new king. Other vassal supported him. The new king found out about it and decided to act. He had tried to imprison the old bugger, but he failed and there was full scale war again. Except now, their army crushed ours. The king was captured and assassinated, his wife was banished and his child was made a puppet king. The old bugger was a regent and controlled everything. One day, petty little king was playing on the balcony and suddeny, the edge of it collapsed, the child fell over and died on the spot. The old bugger became the new king, he betrayed and assassinated the other vassal so he couldn't betray him. He hunted down and killed or banished every member of my dinasty. And that was the end of my royal family.If you have read all of this, I can go on with the actual review. As you can see, this is just one of the many stories you can create in this game. It gives you a lot of possibility for replayability. Also there is a Game of Thrones mod, which is awesome.BUT, I will not recommend this game because of it's awfull DLC policy, which shows no respect for the new players. Sure, the game is regularly on the sale, but that doesn't justify that price. So, just like in my EU4 review, I will join the protesters against this kind of DLC policy and will NOT recommend this game. Paradox should learn about DLC policy from CD Projekt Red.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Crusader Kings II is a Grand Strategy game based around familiy dynasties, political power mongering and in short - trying to make sure you have the biggest wealthest family in the world. The game spans ~400 years of historical time between 1066 to 1453 and offers historical events and references that you can either choose to follow or create a new alternantive timeline from. Do you start a 'War of the Roses' battle? Does YOUR family takeover the Papal? Building relationships, marriages, alliances and faking claims is the key. If this sounds all very Game of Thrones then you're right - it is. Crusader Kings II is the best GoT game on the market at the moment, and that's all thanks to engine being used.Crusader Kings II is the end result of many years of creating and improving on Paradox's Clausewitz Engine (the engine responsible for Cruaders Kings, Europa Universalis, Hearts of Iron franchises). If you're familiar with those games, you might feel familiar with CK2, but the truth is this game goes beyond what the engine has produced before hand. The Clausewitz Engine is in sense the major selling point behind CK2, so while the graphics aren't anything special (and are little more than 3D Marker Pieces) the true beauty unfolds as you play.I can't think of many greater feelings than the moment you're 50 year plotting to get your Grandson into place of power from his lowly Duke title to Lord pays off. Sending your Master of Whispers into a neighbouring region to spread lies and cause dissent amongst the vassals, while you forge a plot to fabricate claims to the title and ursurp the Lordship. So good.Paradox have managed to support the game well since release in the form of DLC Expansions, which have opened the game world up and expanded the 'fringe' empires to be just as complex as the 'key' European ones. However they've also supported the game with post-release patching and balancing, so they're not ones to sitback and take your money.I'm honestly finding it hard to explain this game, the only advice I can give is; if you've ever wanted to play the Game of Thrones this is the closest you'll ever get. In fact, do yourself the pleasure of visiting: http://citadel.prophpbb.com/forum3.html and checking out the amazing Game of Thrones mod these guys have been making over the last year or so (WARNING: May contain spoilers for TV viewers).

												(I'm french, so sorry for my mistakes)This game is one of my favorite game ever so far. I got it a year ago and I'm never bored of this game. With each DLC that came out, the game became sometime harder, sometime easier, but I am not complaining about it. Each extensions gave something new to this already awesome game. However, some of those DLC shouldn't exist because they are quite basic, like the Old Gods or Sword of Islam. This game is always a suprise because there will always be something strange that happens, like a jihad for Denmark, or a crusade on France. If you like ahistorical game, this one is for you. Oh, and did I mention that you can lay in multiplayer? The multiplayer part of the game is awesome, even if the servers are unstable. You can so so much stuff stupid with your friends! For example, nearly half of my play time on this gamer is on multiplayer with only one friend!And for those who seek a challenge, try to do the achievements of the game, some are quite hard and will ask you a lot of time of practice! (Kingdom of David for example)As a conclusion, I do recommend this awesome game and if you ever buy it and like it, try the multiplayer with 5 or 6 friends, you'll never the world the same way, especially if you have the conclave DLC.PS. Again, I'm  sorry for my mistakes.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												  (sorry for the length)  A constantly politically shifting and difficult Europe centric world where you can form your medieval kingdom the way you want it, if your many enemies alow it. The game itself is pretty amazing in scale and with the newest update pretty difficult. Your goal shouldn't be to build a sprawling empire, but to get your family to stand the test of time (that's not to say that controlling a centralized depositic empire is a bad thing) and Paradox is still updating the game and adding more expansions onto it, that's not even mentioning the amazing mod's for the game, if you are in to game of thrones or warhammer, post apocolyptic America, more historical accuracy, less historical accuracy, ect.  If you survive through the ages you can also convert the map file to Europe Univerails 4 and play in a new age, which is nice if you like EU4. (It hasn't grown on me)  The game can get pretty ridiculous too, hilarious at times like when your 8 month old daughter is friends with a 41 year old mercenary captain who is never around. Or when the king of Sweden and Finland inexplicably becomes sunni muslim, and is then promptly assasinated by all of his coutiers and vassals for their religous differences. Good times...  You'll need a powerfull rig though if you want to play all the way though, like with all paradox games it slows down over time, and that's a bummer, though there are probobly mods that remove detail from the map and such. The Price is also pretty steep when you look at it, but if you get it on a sale and don't buy the artsy dlc, it's... do-able. It makes sense considering the game needs a good computer to run it on.  If you are buying the game to play with friends, all players will play with the dlc of the host of the game lobby, so only one of you will need the dlc. When I've played multiplayer games I have played with mod's, and experianced a lot of desync's, which essentially end the game, which is upsetting, but that might just be me or the mods (Dragons in game of thrones mod)  Also if you click or press buttons duing the loading screen the game might just crash. It's because of the game engine from what i've been told. 10/10I bought the artsy stuff too, skins and such (but not the E-books) all the crazy, amazing, or just plain ridiculousness of the game is what earns it the description of "Grand strategy"

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Crusader Kings 2 is real time/paused strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive. Same developer who made other great games like Europa Universalis 4, Victoria 2, Hearts of Iron 3 and Stellaris. This game is based on Middle Ages to start of renaissance, where EU4 starts. Without DLC starts around 1066, but if you have dlc\'s like Old Gods and Charlemagne you can start it on 700\'s.However before saying this game is all about invading other lands like Civ and Total War, no. Because this game is unique. You rule your dynasty and lead it through the age. You have to control your family by marrying other people for example Holy Roman Empire\'s princesses. Then you extend your family and realm. Same time there is world map, where you can invade land, like in every strategy game. But only land available is Europe, North Africa and part of Asia. There are many events in this game. I\'ll explain hordes, rebellions and crusades in this review. There are many hordes. For example Mongols and Abbasids. If you have Sunset Invasion DLC, Aztecs are gonna invade Europe too. Hordes born quickly and rise by invading all neighbor realms. They are hard to defeat but they collapse easily with rebellions. Rebellions are events where claimer of duchy of puppet state declare war on country and try to switch government or get independece. That\'s why you see all rebellions threats on your intrique menu, so you can prepare at threats or plot to kill threats. And last, crusades. If you part of catholic or orthodox religion, pope or archbishop might declare crusade to invade Jerusalem, Anatolia or any lands where real life crusaders were. You don\'t have to join crusade but if you join and get most points you\'ll gain all lands that were invaded in crusade.Family relations are pretty important as your sons that have bad relation with you might try to kill you or start rebellion. And affairs are just gonna anger your wife and your children. However having family member in countries like Holy Roman Empire might help you make alliance with them, so that is useful. On my game, I just spammed my every daughter on big countries, HRE, England, France and Byzantium.Combat works really well, but units are pretty hard to make and army levies might rise too big.Overall this game is great and I had alot more fun with it than with Civ or EU4. I recommend it!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Easily one of the most entertaining games Ive ever owned. I picked this game up for 10 dollars on sale, and for the first time ever I feel like I owe the company more money for what they provided me!Disclaimer: This game has the absolute steepest learning curve Ive ever overcome. The tutorials are pretty useless, some are broken, and dont explain features too well. Most everyone learns how to paly by watching youtube videos, of which there are many excellent series.Disclaimer Disclaimer: This is not for those who enjoy fastpaced gameplay. It is not like the Total War franchise where you take command of your armies. The entire game is played out on the map. That all being said with a little patience and little imagination this game offers literally endless fun. So many different ways to play, every single game will be different. And if any of you people out there are familiar with the phrase "Its fun to loose!", then this is for you.Youll get so many cool stories to tell, and the community is nothing short of wonderful. Everyone is helpful and polite (for the most part, much better than most other communities). Highly, highly recommend this game. 9/10.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Crusader Kings 2 is probably the most reactionary game ever made. Imagine Game of Thrones without the fantasy stuff. This is a game about killing your kin to steal their lands, diplomatically marrying daughters off to sadistic freaks, crushing peasant revolts, and crusading against the Mohammadeans. Whether you chose to play as the Holy Roman Emperor or the count of a single back country province you’ll have plenty of court intrigue to keep you occupied. It is ½ grand strategy game, ½ dynastic RPG, and 100% awesome.With the various DLCs you can play as non Christian religions too. I highly recommend picking up at least the Sword of Islam and Old Gods DLCs so you can play Muslims and Pagans respectively.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												You know, ive been playing paradox games ever since europa universalis rome and in that time iv e played at one point or another most major paradox titles espically their strategy titles.Now out of all those titles, crusader kings 2 overall  probably isnt any better than its counterparts europa 4, hearts of iron 4 and victoria 2..but it does have something that none of the others do..in fact while the aforementioned games are  similar to each other crusader kings 2 stands out..europa 4 attempts to combine various aspects from  all of these titles into one large jack of all trades that everyone can enjoy, victoria 2 embraced the economic side of paradox strategy with some hearts of iron style warfare..hearts of iron 4 while a massive improvment on the third entry in that series is still a war sim far far more than anything else.Crusader kings was intended to be grand strategy meets rpg, and it pulled that off wonderfully in the process however something uniqe and special in the gaming world was born..something that i have never been able to find a sutiable comparison for when looking at all aspects of a game..there just isnt another game that pulls of making you feel like you are that indivudal king or queen even though you arent because they are often actual historical charaters .so that every year of thier rule feels personalized to you despite the fact that the game isnt tryin gto say YOU are that ruler.At the same time your ruling for hundreds of years over dozens of rulers so how could each ruler feel individual, and to an extent that applies however..imagine the old idea of re incartaion, throughout the eons you are reborn essentialy the same sould but into different bodies and lives ((or as a tree)) adapt that slightly and you have what playing a ruler in crusader kings 2 feels like.Now i could elaborate further as i intended to cover the other points i wished to make but this review is getting a bit long so ill wrap it up...there would have been at least four blocks that size.The point is this game does something you will not find anywhere else, you may find individual aspects in other games or even a combination of a few but overall there simply isnt another comparison, at least not yet. So very simply put if you like the idea of roleplaying as a king or queen while running a country paradox style than this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2012
												Crusader Kings II is the sequel to the by now fairly old Crusader Kings and in true Paradox tradition it improves heavily upon every single aspect of the game. In particular the move to the Clausewitz engine needs a mention because it allows a game like Crusader Kings II to fully achieve it's potential in a way the previous game never could.The game is a dynastic Grand Strategy game. This means that while you still take control of a single country like in other Paradox games are you not just some faceless entity behind the screens, you actually take control of that country's ruler and upon his or her death, take control of the legitimate heir to continue your reign. This makes controlling a country and leading it to greatness a much more personal experience as it's your family that's leading the charge, with the various offshoots that didn't manage to become King constantly plotting how to remove the current favorite.In general much of the game will be spent dealing with your family and their thirst for power. Through a number of laws you can select who is the heir and how he or she is chosen and you can fully expect that anyone who doesn't not currently top that list will be working diligently to remove the one that does. And it's not always the best outcome when your able and strong son suffers an untimely accident and your gluttonous greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who is surprisingly proficient at intrigue becomes the last heir standing.Like in most of Paradox's games warfare takes the front seat and it is the prime method for which to expand your lands, wealth and prestige. However Crusader Kings, through this dynastic system makes great strides towards making peacetime more interesting. The bigger your family, the more vassals you have, the more options will be available to you during peacetime and you will often have to work hard to keep your Kingdom stable. The option for marrying off unwanted sons to powerful widows is also a very effective way to increase your lands as you may one day some generations from now find yourself the heir to whole new territories. Quicker with a little creative assassination.The graphics of the Clausewitz engine are beautiful although that is never really a necessity or a priority of a Grand Strategy game, particularly not a Paradox one, but it is nice to see that there's improvement on this front as well. The music is heavily mood setting and wonderful as always and the many small music DLC's available helps improve the selection tremendously.All in all, Crusader Kings II does not disappoint as it proves itself a great sequel to a great game. Everything is simple better. A true must buy for any fans of Grand Strategy or Dynastic games. And for anyone that simply thinks incest is hilarious.Also, completely irrelevant to the game, I'd strongly recommend that you go watch the "Seven Deadly Sins" trailers on youtube that were released as promotional material before the game came out. They are definitely worth a watch whether you want to play the game or not.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												The best (it's clear that Paradox own the genre, but this is their best one) Grand Strategy game. Whilst fans of strategy games may miss the interactive combat, this game makes up for it by being more interactive in other aspects such as diplomacy. Take your house and make it last throughout the ages! Who doesnt want to conquer the world? It is one of the most complex games I have ever played and the learning curve is extremely steep, yet through playing the game it is easy to overcome (tutorials are provided, but they arent the most in depth). The game has multiple DLC packs (which arent required, but they do make it more fun) and is being updated regularly. Be prepared to become frustrated; I built my custom house (DLC) and it lasted throughout many centuries and when it came to  the 6 Generation, I was emperor of The Byzantine Empire, Britannia, Francia, The Holy Roman empire. The person I played, was infertile, and all other relatives had been killed off or were women (the game is against women, the populace hate you if youre a female ruler), my character died and with it my House. 100 hours I put in, to lose.But remember, losing is fun!9.8/10 losing the .2 for castration being available to only greeks.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2012
												Crusader Kings 2 is the campaign of Total War, set to focus not on a nation, but on a family.  Your house must become as powerful as possible, this involves a lot of political manipulation and throwing money around.  As I say, the game is the campaign - there is no real control over your battles like in Total War, what you enter the fight with is all that contributes to your victory.  That is a shame, hopefully by the time Paradox decides to do Crusader Kings 3, they'll have worked up the nerve to go for it.While I cannot recommend the game to every type of strategy game fan, this one has been a lot of fun for me, and has presented me with a lot of challenges.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												After a dozen games that ended misrably for my character and his dynasty within only a few years after starting the game, I have finally started a game that lasted for more then twenty minutes.I started out as Leon, and all was well. Nothing happened, all my vassals were cool with me. Then I realized my kin in Aragon started to invade the moslems below us. Not wanting to be overpowered by Aragon a century later, I proceeded to take a small coastal province. I then promptly forgot what I was doing and spammed summer fairs and feasts for a decade or two.When my first character died(Alfonso), he had quite the sum of prestige(around 500 or so). And, with the game engine doin' its thing, Alfonso's succesor(his son Alfonso) got around 200 prestige. Following his dear father's footsteps, Alfonso Jr. spammed the ever-loving crap out of feasts and festivals. But, not more then five years into his reign the pope rang him and asked him to join in a crusade against the moslems. Coincedentially, the targets for Christiandom's righteous wrath happened to be the nation directly below me.So, of course, Deus Vult and all that. I invaded two small provinces in the first part of the crusade. After conquering these two places, I sat on my bum and waited the crusade out, jealously guarding my newly acquired lands.Then, suddenly, as though the Heavenly Father himself thanked me for my participation in the crusade, I acquired half of Spain.Not really sure how.But, Now my prestige started to sky rocket. First, it was 300. Then it was 400. Then, 500. 600. 700. And on, and on and on it went until I had nearly 900 prestige by the time I was thirteen. Que another decade or so of me stealing tiny chunks of realms from the muslims that remained in Spain. Not only was I the terror of the muslims, I had backed the nation of Aragon into a corner, with only two land-locked provinces and a handful of coastal lands.I then married the Queen of France.And, by the time I reached my mid twenties, I was the stuff of legend. Having already held my Grand Tournament and accumulated nearly 2000 prestige, I was on top of the world. Loving wife how owns the entirety of France, promising sons, total alegience of all my vassals.Then I became a homosexual.Nothing wrong with that, not even my vassals batted an eye at it.But they started to get worried when I went insane. Barking at people, wearing shoes as hats, the usual crazyness.I also happened to be fighting a war with Britain in defense of France at the time, all while manipulating the law to make my son's kingship more secure.Then I ♥♥♥♥ed up. I failed to see that choosing Senoirity as my inheritance guideline, I completely removed all of my children from the line of inheritence. Instead, It was my cousin.But, you know what they say, practice makes perfect.TL;DRBecame one of the most legendary kings by the age of thirteen, married the queen of France, went insane screwed over my family. This game is a must buy.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												TL;DR: 9.9/10 (nearly perfect). Pros: too many to quickly list, see paragraph below.Cons: steep learning curve, and potential expense of the full (& extremely important) game in the form of tons of DLC.CK2 has quickly become one of my favourite games of all time. This game is such a fun mix of history/alternate history, intrigue, state/empire building, and ruler simulator. The possibilities available (with all the DLC) are so numerous that during the 400+ hours I’ve played I’ve barely scratched the surface. Wonder what would happen if the Vikings had conquered, held, and integrated Italy into the Swedish or Norwegian kingdoms? DO IT. Getting tired of the Catholics attacking you when you play as the Umayyads (muslim rulers of the Iberian peninsula)? Holy war all the Catholic countries, take their territory and convert their populations to Islam; Rome the center of Catholicism? Not any more! take it from the Infidels and make it Sunni (or Shi'a), or if you're not muslim then convert it to Norse or any of the multitude of diverse and historically accurate religions .  The possibilities for epic, "world" conquering and non-historically accurate shenanigans are nearly infinite.  Let your inner history nerd free, and mess with the world in a fun, engaging, and often very personal way. Another important aspect of this game besides the world conquering/state building is the character aspect.  Instead of just playing a country you are actually an individual (a count, duke, king, or emperor).  Individuals have traits which affect (positively or negatively) their stats which in turn affect the functionality of your state.  There are thousands of unique events for your character to “interact” with, adding an aspect of role playing that is not merely a side thing but a full fledged and fleshed out mechanic.  All the possibilities and outcomes an individual character can experience keeps the game from being just another conquer the enemies territory and “take over the world” (brain) game and elevates it into a unique class of it’s own. There are only two negatives to this game, both of which ultimately don’t affect it's enjoyability. First problem is the price of the game and all it’s DLC. To get the best (and “real”) CK2 experience you really do need all the DLC and when it’s not on sale this game can cost $150+. Lucky the game goes on sale frequently and I’ve been able to (over some time) acquire all the DLC for much, MUCH less than $150. I don’t know exactly how much but it’s probably only like $40/50. Buying the "complete package" at the start when on sale costs $40 and is definitly a perfect deal.  Le'ts just say that despite not paying $150+ for the game I've definitly gotten WAY more than $150 worth of fun from it. I'm glad I didn't pay that much but now that I know how good the game is and if I had to go back & pay the full price I wouldn't hesitate.  The second problem is the learning curve. Being a grand strategy game there is a MASSIVE amount of stuff to learn.  I’m not the sharpest tool in the shed so it took me a good 50+ hours before I was confident enough to say I fully knew how to play.  The 50ish hours I spent learning were fun but I didn’t realize how amazing this game is until I actually got fluent in the game (around 100+ hours in).  Now though that i’ve “mastered” how the game is played I struggle to name a game I’ve enjoyed playing more (ok I know: The Binding of Isaac/Rebirth).  One way to help speed up learning the ins & outs is to watch tutorial/let’s play videos. There is a youtuber named Arumba who is not only extremely entertaining but is also a CK2 master.  Watching his CK2 content really helped accelerate my enjoyment and understanding of the game. I fully recommend watching some tutorial/let’s play videos while/before playing the game, it’ll help alleviate some of the frustration/insurmountability and intimidation the first time you boot CK2 up.  I can’t recommend this game strongly enough, it is gigatons of fun. I also recommend Arumba if you like LP’s and funny/entertaining yet not idiotic/spas-tic presenters then Arumba should be topping your list of ppl to watch. (FYI: I have no affiliation w/ Arumba nor do I know him, I’m just a fan making a recommendation)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Just... if you have a life, stay away from this game.Imagine taking the Sims. Now, make every character in the Sims religious and despising every one else that's not their religion. Then make them ten times more evil. Now, give them an inordinate amount of power and make them kings of lands stretching from Iceland to Bengal. Add a sprinkle of chaos and human interference, and you have Crusader Kings II.You control a king or doge and guide his actions and rulership. Be a tyrant, be a ruler of a docile disposition. Just keep a hold of your vassals, win the elections, and make sure to kill that kid that has a claim on your title.Often events pop up that give you options. However, the effects of your decision are neatly laid out for you, meaning there is little sense of randomness of what happens. You pick the thing with the best effect. The events are sometimes repetitive, and you always usually end up choosing one option throughout all your playthroughs.Although there are characters with traits and personalities, you as a player will, unless you diliberately keep your character's traits in mind, play to your own wants and needs of the game, not what the character you are controlling will want. The game's overall very fun, but lacking in documentation, and for a Strategy/RPG, does little to encourage the RPG side of things. The game's tone is usually serious and historical, but occasionally tongue-in-cheek. (especially if you get the lunatic trait) Sometimes, especially with DLC, the game can become fantasy or simply ridiculous (e.g., in Sunset Invasion the New World, more specifically the Aztecs, can colonize the old world, instead of the other way around. In The Sons of Abraham you can father or mother the spawn of Satan unknowingly. Unknowingly, that is, until he kills your entire family, leaving him as the only heir, then killing you and taking your throne.)In some ways this game is "How to be an evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 101". It has a freaking "evil plan" mechanic for crying out loud! In others it's also "How to be a Radical 101". Christians can go on Crusades, Muslims on Jihads and everyone else on Genericly named "Great Holy Wars".This game is also great if you like Game of Thrones. Murder? Check! Incest? Check! Anyone can die, no matter how important? Double-check.I'd recommend this game to the following people:Evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥sReligious RadicalsStrategy FansParadox Interactive FansGame-of-Thrones FansPoliticians

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												You know you’ve been playing too much Crusader Kings II when you start arranging betrothals between your and your friend’s children and spend the rest of your time musing on heraldry. Crusader Kings II is an ambitious strategy masterpiece full of intrigue, diplomacy, and war. The player controls a single noble dynasty through the European middle ages in a world as changeable as it is engaging.One word I would definitely not use to describe Crusader Kings II is ‘accessible’. When I first started the game, I had to sort through dozens of menu screens and tabs trying to figure out to do. I can’t be sure, but at one point I think I accidentally attempted to abdicate the Duchy of Kent in favor of my Norwegian half-brother. There certainly were helpful messages and tips in great abundance, but if I really wanted to spend an hour reading, I would be downloading O. Henry short stories, not starting up a new game.Once you do get the hang of the controls, though, Crusader Kings II opens up to almost endless possibilities. You can expand your dynasty by clever power play, strategic marriages, or through military force alone. If you work hard as an impoverished count, your grandchildren could be kings and queens. In a game revolving around diplomacy, however, the AI can be a little off-putting in its lack of complexity. While computer players are reasonably clever, they always make the most rational choice, which makes you feel a bit out of place as you attempt to coerce an Arabian sheikh to help you to invade Sweden.The graphics are nothing to write home about, unless you wanted to let your folks know that games can be released in 2012 and still run on any computer more advanced than an abacus. The Crusader Kings II interface is basically a detailed map surrounded by different menus. If you weren’t wearing your glasses, it would look a lot like Total War, only you can’t zoom in for battles- all physical conflict is resolved off-screen as you watch the number of troops still alive decrease. The constant music definitely helps to distract from the less-than-interesting graphics. The same tracks are played over and over, but they’re epic enough to make it worth it.The beautiful thing about Crusader Kings II is the way it generates stories through emergent gameplay. Take King Tudwal the Great, who loved gardening but would occasionally fly off the handle and kill his own family members, or Count Oberto, who despairingly turned to a scholarly life after failing to find a bride for his homosexual nephew. These aren’t characters you find in most Triple-A games.If you only want to relax for a few minutes, you would probably be best served playing Plants vs Zombies, but if you want to spend a challenging 400 years taking over medieval Europe through vilest treachery, Crusader Kings II is without rival. Now if you’ll excuse me, my uncle just raised the banners of Scotland in rebellion against his Welsh overlords.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												I always review the games I buy, and I usually do it after having owned and played them for around a week. CK2 is different, and in order to review such a game I had to play it more. And more, and more, and more, until finally, I believe that I have played this game enough to say that this is the best game that has ever been made! A game with both such depth and width has never been made before in my opinion.Here you can murder your son simply because you want to marry his wife, or you can seduce your sister if you want to go a little bit game of thrones. Speaking of game of thrones, if you get your hands on someone you don't like, you can torture, mutilate or murder anyone! In times of need you can even become a cannibal. Want to discreetly get rid of an annoying uncle? Put him in the vanguard of your armies, or fabricate false stories allowing you to imprison him without opinion-penalties from your subjects. But who cares about their subjects? Just imprison him and execute him publicly without reason, beacause you are the lord!I approve this message.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												The armored Cataphract regiments from the Komnenian household guard led my Anatolian armies in the east while a smaller force of Varangians led a simultaneous invasion of muslim-held Sicily in the west. Infidel armies were crushed underfoot, provinces fell one by one, and the petty emir's begged for peace as the Byzantine Restoration swept to all shores of the Mediterranean. "Good!," I said, "this was getting too easy!" when the Sunni's finally declared a jihad. My forces took the initiative and several large mercenary companies and 20,000 Byzantines landed near the Nile before the first infidel armies even reached my borders. Small muslim armies were swatted away as they attempted to repel my invasion, but they were no match for my men as we ravaged the Egyptian delta. The Shiites declared their own jihad against the recently "liberated" sicilian holdings a few months after we landed in Egypt. "Whatever," I chuckled, "the mighty sons of Rome do not fear a these desert men!" I recruited more mercenaries and landed in Sicily just as the first Shiite armies began to trickle in by boat. Each month brought a fresh wave of infidels and we crushed each attack and pressed on with the sieges.But months turned in to years, and the trickle of muslim armies became a steady stream of larger and larger enemy armies. My fleets began to frantically criss-cross the Mediterranean, ferrying whatever regiments I could spare from theatre to theatre to counter each wave. My men were winning every battle, but we were losing soldiers faster than they could be replaced. I watched in disbelief as my army and Varangian core in Sicily was overrun, trapped, and annihilated, and the Shiites crossed the strait to capture my holdings in Italy. Then my armies holding eastern Anatolia were forced to pull back to a defensive line near the Bosphorus as large muslim hosts pressed towards my capital. My Egyptian invasion force had been significantly weakened by endless waves of Sunni's, and the desert sun was killing even more. I evacuated Egypt and pulled back the remaining armies to regroup in Greece.My war chest was also running out, which forced me to disband the remaining mercenary companies to keep them from rebelling, and scrapped large portions of my fleet. My disbelief turned to horror as the Shiites landed in Greece and the Sunni's crossed the Bosporus and laid siege to Constantinople. I gathered what remained of my fragmented forces, nearly 20k men, around Athens and won a close battle over a large Shiite force that had crossed into western Greece, and finally convinced the desert men to agree to peace in exchange for the Sicilian duchy I had won years earlier. My men then charged north, defeating a small muslim host that surrounded Constantinople and relieving the city for a few months. But another Sunni host of some 50k crossed the strait soon after, forcing my army to retreat and threatening to destroy my last hopes for the Restoration. The situation had gone from dire to impossible.And that is when they appeared- A force of 50k imperials arrived on a fleet outside my capital, led by the Kaiser himself. A few years into the war, I had arranged for my son to marry the daughter of the Holy Roman Emperor in the west, and although he had officially joined the war in my defense, up to this point, I had only seen a few small inneffective armies in Italy. I marched the last sons of Rome north-east, and joined battle just as the Kaiser landed at the head of his great army. Together we overpowered and crushed the muslim forces, and the Kaiser's fleet prevented a muslim escape into Anatolia. The infidels were completely destroyed. Soon after, the Sunni's finally agreed to a white peace that left my Eastern empire intact. I never forgot that the true sons of Rome had been saved by the pretenders in the west, and our alliance lasted for generations until the new Roman Empire and the title of Augustus was finally restored.For those of you wondering, this did actually happen during my play through way back in 2013 and it was the reason I became hooked on CKII until I eventually graduated to Europa Universalis 4. This game is unique in the strategy genre and I would recommend it to people that enjoy the Total War series, but always wanted more depth in the character aspect of the game (e.g. Kings, Princes, and Generals). If you are on the fence about this game, then check out a few of the Game of Thrones mod videos on youtube- I never played the mod, but watching the LP's sold me. Enjoy!

content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												This is a great medieval simulator. The combat aspects are extremely downplayed leaving you to focus on your court polotics and intrugue. You play as a medieval lord ranging from count to duke to king. You journey through time making plays for power within your kingdom you will advance through lines of succesion to the next generation. Go on crusades to claim the holy land from infedels, and wage holy war against the pagan heathens, all the while staving off rebellion and rogue lords attempting to usurp your domain. This game features rts sandbox and rpg aspects and it well worth the  sale price of $10 for the vanilla client. IMO the republic dlc, the old gods dlc, and legacy of rome are the most worthwhile and neccesary dlc. The rest mostly just come down to personal preferance and what you think you will play.You can find plenty of mods on the paradox forum including a game of thrones westeros mod (the whole time i was playing vanilla i was wishing there was a game like that and when i found it on the forums i was ecstatic). The middle earth mod and tamriel mods are in development as of yet.If you are unsure about buying this game give the demo a try or maybe check out some lets play videos on u tube. Overall this game is wonderful and deserves your attention if not only briefly to experience the greatness that is ck2.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
Crusader Kings II is a medieval politics grand strategy game. Maneuver nobility relations as you seek to expand the power and prestige of your dynasty, generations after generations.Pros: Where to begin? There are countless characters (thousands): barons, counts, dukes, kings, courtiers, family members and everything in between for every city, barony, county, tribe, sheikdom or other political region denominator. Relationship behaviors are based off a multitude of character and personality traits. You manage a character, and upon death his heir, then his heir, through centuries of history as kingdoms and empires rise and fall, acquiring lordship over titles through conquering armies, political weddings, intrigue and backstabbing. The base game is set specifically for Europeans during the crusades, while expansions add Northern Africa, Middle East, Scandinavia, Western Asia and India, with each distinct culture and religion having its own tribal, feudal and monarchic mechanics. Many random events allow you to determine what type of person your current character becomes, engrossing you in the story of each of them, influencing and determining the fate of any trivial or world changing event. The game is regularly and constantly being updated: I'm not only referring to the multitude of DLCs that add historically accurate ethical portraits and cultural armory, but actual core mechanics are regularly revised, enhanced and added to by the developers. The game is fully open-ended, and leaves you to determine your political goal. Do you wish to rebuild the Roman Empire? Unite Great Britain? Overcome enemies in a world-wide crusade? Overthrow the Pope? Found Ukraine? Survive the Mongol onslaught? Endless possibilities!Cons: The game has a high learning curve, and new comers must be willing to put in hours of learning, trial and error, and tutorial reading to understand how every mechanic works. Graphics are passable, barely enough to serve the game's purpose. Even at easier levels, difficulty remains high and players must be willing to go through constant frustrations as you are limited to decisions your character makes as a single person, which means there is no direct control over the outcome of battles, plots and events. The game can be slow at times, sometimes requiring months, years, decades and even generations of in-game time to bring any plan to fruition.Verdict: ★★★★★ - Play this. Now.This game isn't meant for everyone. It requires a lot of patience and dedication. But the game can also be immensely rewarding when you successfully achieve your goals. This game left me retelling the tales of how, as a count, I married my firstborn son to a duchess so that my grandson would inherit the king's throne (and expected to play that character two generations later), just to have my second son get branded as a kinslayer for killing his eldest brother, becoming my new heir and throw my entire plan to smithereens! The game is addictive, so if you have the patience to play through Cruisader Kings II's demo tutorial, you just have to get the entire game!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												After 1800+ hours playing Crusader Kings II, the most recent DLC and free content expansion, Conclave, has forced me to withdraw my formerly enthusiastic approval.  CKII used to be one of the premiere Grand Strategy titles available.  Sadly, over the course of several expansion/DLC releases the game has lost its way, becoming increasingly tedious and straying far from the original wonderful gameplay.  The Conclave DLC and the accompanying free content patch was released completely unbalanced and apparently largely untested.  It caused a widespread negative reaction which forced Paradox to immediately begin work on a fix patch.  That patch, now in open beta testing, goes a long way toward fixing the worst of the problems.  Unfortunately, it doesn't go far enough.  The root of the problem is that the entire concept of Conclave makes councils far too powerful.  The intent of Paradox seems to be to make the game more difficult and thus hinder the ability of players to "paint" the map all in the color of their empire.  The intended result was achieved.  And now the game is a mess of micromanaging council votes and council favor which detracts from the initial design concept of a fun game focused on dynasties and war in the medieval period.  Paradox might as well change the name of the game to Crusader Kings II: The Council -Hindered, Blocked and Trolled.  The game is no longer focused on dynasty and conquest and religious fervor in the medieval milieu.  Now it is just a grumpy, greedy pseudo-democracy council simulator set in a medieval era with the player forced into spending inordinate amounts of time dealing with fractious, constant council problems almost to the exclusion of everything that once made this a great game.   Congratulations, Paradox.  The greed pushing a need to continually release more DLC to line corporate pockets has finally sent the core game into oblivion. You succeeded in satisfying a vocal minority who wanted the game to be more difficult (with no proof that many of those who complained had even played the game beyond the Easy setting).  In return, you've so drastically altered the basic gameplay that Crusader Kings II is no longer really about Crusader Kings.  You've turned a fine Grand Strategy game set in the medieval period into something entirely different. Short of removing the Conclave DLC and the free content expansion entirely, there is no fix for this.  The game has moved too far from its original design concept, which attracted many of us to the game in the first place.  There are other better democracy simulators available.  They aren't Grand Strategy games; but neither is Crusader Kings II since the changes of the last expansion.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												500 hours. Five. Hundred. Hours.Since I purcahased Crusadser Kings II for $23.99 on July 17, 2012, roughly %3.5 of my life has been devoted solely to this game.And I'm still playing.Why? Because it's a masterpiece. I can comfortably say this is the overall best game I have ever played. Maybe I'm a history nerd, maybe I like maps, maybe I enjoy imprisioning and killing all my relatives so that little genius baby boy can have a shot at becoming the first Breton to rule all of Western Europe. Could be there's something cathartic about converting to Cathar just so you can launch a holy war against the Pope who gave you all your power with that invasion CB against the HRE in the first place. Maybe it's the strategy, so deep that I still find myself looking to the wiki to find the most efficient way to conquer. I might get a little too into the roleplaying, would my kind, charitable, humble, Catholic duke really execute his own son just because he's a drunken imbecile? I know I'm not entirely sure what keeps bringing me back, but I do know that the sheer replayability of this game is staggering. If you're thinking about buying this game, seriously consider whether you have any real work you'd like to get done in the next two years, because more than likely you're going to be plotting against your liege rather than plotting out your next project at the office, or whatever...

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Crusader Kings II is a game from those masters of "grand strategy", Paradox Interactive. I never played the original Crusader Kings, but Crusader Kings II has been one of the most consistantly enjoyable experiences I've ever had with a strategy game. Even with 150 hours under my belt, I'm still gaining skill, and with every DLC, I'm encountering new events and new ways to play. Even the base game is a delight to play, but unlike many other games, the DLC is actually worth having, and every major DLC expansion adds a new dimension to the gameplay. When I first started playing, even with just a couple of hours of experience, I knew enough to be competitive. If you're new to Paradox Titles, I'd suggest checking out a "Let's Play" on YouTube, or reading T.J. Hafer's wonderful "Crusader Kings Chronicles" on the PC Gamer web site. The game is a sandbox, so your goals are your own. You can try to create an Empire, or you can just try to hold on to what you have at the start of the game. You can use military conquest to expand your holdings, or you can strategically marry and assassinate your way into greater power. Your options are limited only by your cunning and imagination.But it's so much more than just a strategy game. It's also got roleplaying elements. Every character has a set of five stats that range from 0 (totally incompetent) to 20 or higher (genius) that determine how he or she runs their County, Duchy, Kingdom, or Empire. Diplomacy makes your vassals and your neighbors like you more. Marshal determines how well you command your armies. Administrative determines how well you manage your finances, and how large a territory you can hold personally. Intrigue determines both your ability at plotting against your enemies and discovering plots your enemies are making against you. Learning has an effect on the rate of technological advancement, and several other factors.In addition to these five stats, each character has traits, both positive, like "Brave", "Diligent", or "Just", or negative like "Craven", "Slothful", or "Arbitrary". There are also numerous "neutral" modifiers, like "Honest" that increases your Diplomacy, but decreases your Intrigue. There are also genetic traits that can come into play, both good and bad. The first time you have a "genius" child, you'll be jumping for joy, and the first time you have an "inbecille", you'll be wondering how hard it would be to "dispose" of him. But be wary. That imbecille might be the only hope of continuing your line.Because that is what the game is about. It's not about your country. It's about your dynasty, your family line. Even if you start as the Emperor of the Holy Roman Emperor, and wind up as the Count of some random backwater in Eastern Europe, so long as your family line continues, your game continues. But even if you are the Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, if you have no remaining members of your Dynasty, then it's game over.It's a complex, but not complicated, game. Make no mistake. There is a learning curve to this game, but once you've learned the basics, you will find yourself coming back to it again and again.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
SummaryAn amazingly complex and engrossing game that can make the hours fly by.ReviewCrusader Kings II is difficult to classify. It’s a grand strategy game, a sandbox game, and in some ways a political simulator. It also happens to be one of the best role-playing games I've ever played.  I’m not even sure where to begin describing it, but what I can say without reservation is that it’s extremely immersive and fun, which is quite a trick that developer Paradox Interactive pulled off when you consider that the vast majority of the gameplay takes place in menus.The premise is deceptively simple: you play as a king (hardly a surprise given the game's title), and your number one goal above all else is to have an heir in place who will claim your throne upon your death.  When your character dies, you assume the role of his heir, and so on down the line of succession.  Die without an heir and it's game over.But of course it’s not quite as simple as that.  As a king, you’re naturally going to want to expand your realm and accumulate wealth and prestige, and this is where you find the meat of the game.  When you start, you can choose to play as anything from a lowly vassal like a duke or a petty king ruling a single province to a monarch of an entire country.  This also serves as a secondary way to adjust the game’s difficulty since a duke or petty king is going to have a harder time of it than the ruler of an entire nation.And this is where things get interesting.  I call Crusader Kings II a role-playing game because it’s all about navigating the treacherous path of court intrigue and maintaining relationships with the other characters in the game.  Sometimes you might want to have a good relationship with someone, or sometimes you may want them to think very poorly of you, and there are numerous means for doing both, from performing favors, or handing out honorary titles (including Court Jester, which never makes the recipient happy), or even straight-up bribery.  If you have a troublesome vassal, you can try and woo him back into your good graces, throw him in jail, or plot to have him killed.  Any action you choose will always have long-term consequences, for good or ill.  For instance, if you arbitrarily throw someone in jail, or attempt to have them murdered and it’s discovered, you’ll take a relationship hit with other characters almost across the board, and this could be a problem if allies refuse to come to your aid during war, or you end up with a revolt on your hands, or other characters hatch their own plans to kill you or your heir!  It all becomes a delicate balancing act as you try to keep your friends (and enemies) happy while scheming to steal land and titles out from under their noses.In addition to good old fashioned political intrigue, you will also encounter a number of random story vignettes that present your character with various choices that create a short, branching narrative, the ultimate consequences of which could be positive or negative, depending on your decisions.When things come to blows, and they inevitably will, it’s time to raise an army and clash steel.  Unfortunately, this is not the most engrossing part of the game.  Your armies march around in multi-unit “blobs” represented by a single soldier sprite with a number indicating the size of the army and a small line representing its morale.  Essentially, if your numbers are higher than an enemy army’s numbers then you’ll (most likely) win the battle.  And that’s pretty much all there is to it: march your “blob” around, defeat other blobs, and lay siege to enemy provinces until your war score reaches 100% and you can force your foe to concede to your demands.  I’m not saying this is necessarily easy, and wars are extremely costly, and sometimes you’ll be thrown an unexpected wrinkle that will turn what you thought was an easy victory into a crushing defeat, but you’re not going to find detailed tactical gameplay here (although full disclosure compels me to mention that I’m not an expert in this game by any stretch, so there may be some nuance here that I’m missing).  At any rate, the simple combat mechanics are adequate because war really isn’t the focus of Crusader Kings II even if it is an important aspect given the setting.Crusader Kings II plays in real-time, but you can pause at any point if you need breathing room to untangle a particularly difficult political conflict.  You can still interact with the game when it’s paused, but your orders won’t take affect until you start the clock again.  This prevents the game from becoming overwhelming even when things get complicated, which can happen very quickly and often without warning.  Thankfully the interface is very well laid out and places the copious amounts of information you need to manage your empire within easy reach, usually no more than one or two mouse-clicks away.  However, it is a very complex game, and even with over 80-hours under my belt to date, I feel like I’ve still barely scratched the surface.  In order to understand Crusader Kings II, you need to have a basic understanding of Medieval politics and laws, and this isn’t something that most people possess.  For instance, a pop-up will inform you that you have a “Wrong type of holding in demesne”.  What does that even mean, and more importantly, how do you fix it?  Or you might discover that your kingdom is at risk of fragmenting into the hands of multiple petty rulers when your character dies because of a potential succession crisis.  Why is this happening, and what can you do about it?  The game’s manual and tutorial missions do a rather poor job preparing you for your career as a crusader king, so you’ll probably want to find some “Let’s play” videos or a strategy guide or two.  I also suggest keeping a web browser handy while you play because you’ll inevitably have questions throughout the course of the game.Graphically, Crusader Kings II is probably about as attractive as a game like this can be with the majority of the display occupied by a vast interactive 3D map.  Details are added and subtracted depending on your zoom level, so it’s easy to pull out for a quick overview and then zoom in close enough to see individual cities and holdings dotted across the landscape.  It also runs beautifully in Linux, which always scores extra points in my book.  Sound effects are pretty basic for the most part, but you’ll mostly be listening to the music anyway which is period appropriate orchestral selections.  It can get a little bit repetitive, but there are several music packs available as DLC to expand the score.Speaking of DLC, if you’re contemplating a purchase of Crusader Kings II, you might be staggered by the fact that there is, at the time of this writing, nearly $250 worth of full-priced DLC currently available, and you may find this off-putting, but consider this: the vanilla game offers a complete experience in and of itself and can give you hours of entertainment.  In fact, I would recommend you play it sans DLC at first to get a feel for the game and to decide which DLC actually appeals to you, because not all of it will (and you should probably wait until it’s on sale anyway to get the most bang for your bucks).  I personally only have around half of the available DLC including several expansions and some of the unit and music packs, but I don’t feel like I’m missing out simply because the other content doesn’t interest me.  I should also note that when Paradox does release a major expansion, it's always accompanied by a patch that adds new features and content to the base game for free.This review could easily be three times as long, and I still wouldn’t feel like I had given a comprehensive description of Crusader Kings II.  So let’s make this simple: It’s a great game.  Buy it.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												An excellent game, thourghly immersive in its environment. With the couple of DLC i have, it is immensly enjoyable, with many playble factions, and Factions-within-Factions(playing as a count or Duke under a King/Emperor). Combat simulation is relativly simple, just move your army to the same region as the enemy, and it will auto-engage, not much micro-managing as far as i've found.  Political and governmental simulation is also a fairly easy thing to learn, but there is an ever deepening filed to play, with all the ins and outs constantly being learned about and balanced. Further adding to this is the constantly changing world, making alliances and ties to other nations very diverse. To what i can tell, the Development team went all out to bring a great game forth, highly recommend this, definetly worth the buy, as are many of the DLCs.10/10 for me, easily will take hours of my day away.[6/25/15 Edit]: In my Croatia campaign, successfully got my son killed in a war, then died from a wound in that same war, then beat it as my grandson.10/10, best war yet.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												If you are a fan of strategy games, and more specifically, grand strategy ganes (ig. Civ) crusader kings 2 is a must have game. The game begins in the year 867, or 1066 depending on if you own the "The Old Gods" expansion or not, and you must guide a noble family through the medievel era. This may seem bland to someone without experience with paradox interactive grand strategies, but it is certainly not. This game is very similar  to Game of Thrones(there is a Game of Thrones mod also) imagine playing as the lannisters, starks or any family in westeros of signifigance. As in Game of Thrones, intrigue is paramount. I have countless times murdered my children and siblings in the name of preserving my realm and i have been assassinated by my siblings and brothers countless times also. Intrigue however is not the only component of CKII, military, religious, and economic gameplay is as rewarding as Intrigue. When all of these elements work together, the Game is damn good. Imagine you are the king of Sweden. Your younger brother is the King of Norway and your uncle is your vassel, duke of Lappland with a measly 4 holdings(counties, castles, cities, and temples/churches/mosques). Your spymaster is unskilled and your uncles plot to claim your kingdom for himself has gone unnoticed. Even if the kingdom of Sweden is the most powerful of nations, you can still lose a war to revolting vassles. Especially if a foreign king like your afformentioned brother helps the rebels. It is gameplay like this that you experience in crusader kings but so much more dynamic than i could ever hope to explain on paper. In my opinion Crusader Kings II is the best grand strategy game ever, fans of the genre and newcomers alike can appreciate it: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												You know, I feel like ,compared to some of the great players (e.g. those mad tings' with 2000+ hours invested into the game) I really haven't experienced that much. In fact, I haven't even managed to run through a full game yet, that is both from the DLC-given 769 Charlemagne starting date and the vanilla 1066 date, and I like to consider myself a competent player - atleast I would hope so by this point... BUT, by my sweet black baby jesus' grace, it was when all of this hit me that I decided to write this review.That is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.400+ hours of gameplay, nearing 500, and I still haven't managed to finish a game? CK2 is the ultimate strategy out there. It doesn't recquire particularly acute battle-planning however, that is all done by a simple combat simulator and AI Martial Ability, no. This sort of strategy is that of court intrigue, seducing the Queen of Lombardy and marrying her so your heir becomes King of Italy whilst also coming from a family of barbaric Norse pagans?What? The predominantly Catholic Italians don't like the idea of having a Pagan King and try revolt against you? Beat them down then, that's what your well groomed retinues are for.But still your Council might find themselves growning a tad bit agitated with your ritual sacrifice of their fellow Christians and might attempt to, instead of overthrowing you competely, limit your power with diplomacy and the use of a strange concept. Democracy. Well, ♥♥♥♥ them, send your spymaster with his seditious intent to capture or kill them.All this in the meagre period of twenty years.Who knows what other trials, tribulations and resounding triumphs, await you upon your purchase of this game? Well to answer that. No-one. Because the possibilities are, literally, absolutely infinite.Oh and I also suggest shelling out, legit, everything in your wallet on the main DLCs, which are everything exluding Aztec Invasion.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												A solid example of a once great game ruined through pointless revisions and unnecessary changes to the core mechanics. After patch 2.5 the gameplay is more tedium and frustration than it is fun or interesting, and CKII has become so buggy that it's borderline unplayable as certain government types.This game has been progressively worsening for a quite a while now, but conclave has absolutely broken the experience.Why?-The council exists only as a gameplay obstruction as opposed to an interesting feature on it's own.-Managing anything larger than a small kingdom will now result in endless revolts to increase council power, with very little the player can do to avoid it.-Defensive pacts are an interesting idea, but ultimately don't play nice with the game mechanics and aren't very historically accurate. (For an excellent example I played as Carloman Karling and I had the invasion of Saxony event fire, due to my previous war to press my claim on West Francia almost every independent slavic pagan declared war on me to defend the Saxons. Which by the way, makes absolutely no sense and results in an almost unwinnable conflict.)-Shattered retreat suffers from a similar problem mechanically while being a good idea in theory, it simply doesn't work well in game and makes some conflicts ridiculously difficult or just pointless.(holy wars and prepared invasions are the best examples of this)-The new education system makes creating a decent heir mostly reliant on rng as opposed to a chosen guardian's existing traits.Despite all this I would still say this is a decent game, but I can't honestly recommend it anymore. If you're going to buy CKII, get it on sale and avoid some of the dlc. Also roll back to a patch prior to conclave for a better experience.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Hello Gamers! PET here with my Crusader Kings II review!First of all this is a hard game to pick up but once you do it will create one of the best and unique experiences you ever encounter (in video games lol).If you follow my video at the end of the review I guarantee you will be able to pick up the game. If not...CK2 is a Grand Strategy Game. You will start around year 1100 and play until around 1300 (don't remember the exact dates. You can change the start year but the end year will be the same).CK2 is a game about your dynasty, about politics, about your vassals and about surviving your dynasty. One of the reasons why this game is hard is that it does not give you a purpose. You can do whatever you want and this might be confusing to some people. You will get that "now what?" experience. Not only that but you will be able to play with any king/duke/count in Europe. As you see I wrote a person title and not a country. Why? Because in CK2 you play with a person from a dynasty. Your purpose is to expand your dynasty, marry your sons so they can create children, marry your daughters to other powerful rulers so you will have a claim on that territory... oh yes yes...CK2 follows the feudal system and that's one of the reasons why people find this game hard. For example you can not declare war on another person without having a De Jure claim. What does that mean? Well it means that you are entitle to that territory because you might have a title that contains that territory. Oh yes, you have titles.Really, I think it's much easier to just watch my review & tutorial here:


YouTube™ Video: Crusader Kings 2 Review & Tutorial (part 1/2) 

			Views: 8,584		

			This is my Crusader Kings 2 Review & Tutorial. This type of grand strategy game is not for everyone. The game is a bit hard to learn so I decided to combine my review into a tutorial, that way people...		

But trust me guys, this game is simply amazing. Once you learn the basics you will be able to have an amazing time.Thanks!<3

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												By far, one of the best games I've played in my lifeIn Paradox's game progression this one is the first, and it occupies middle ages from 1066 to 1452 (or from 867 if you get the DLC for it). In game you basically have to choose dynasty and play till you die or till the game itself ends. And it's really ♥♥♥♥ing difficult. You might get kicked out of your throne and die poor with no heirs or you can survive and be emperor of whole Europe.This game is great fun because:1) It is really hardcore2) The map is quite big, so variety of dynasties to play is really decent3) Things go quite different every time you play, so it doesn't become repetitive4) There are some quite competitive achievements in game, for example restoring Roman Empire or sample5) It is quite historically interesting, you can watch how things changed around 1000 years ago6) Nice graphically made landscape7) It's not just about having wars. It's about being a ruler. You will have to do a lot of things there, from starting and ending wars to marrying your offspringsWhy this game isn't flawless:1) Some really stupid and unrealistic things might happen. For example, Russian kingdom turning to catholic religion or black-skinned king of Britain (This is what I had only, most noticeable things)2) There are really many DLCs and getting them can sometimes be worthy, the most significant ones are like 8$3) Some DLCs are really stupid, for example the one with Aztec invasion. It's just plain idiotic.4) This game might be sometimes TOO hardcore. You won't be able to play it normally before you complete tutorial, so bother yourself with that. And it's gonna take you a lot of time to start playing good. I actually started becoming good at this game after 100h only and still would sometimes get ♥♥♥♥ed.Overall, this game is a great fun if you want some good time-spender, if you want some historical interesting events, if you're tired of real-time strategy games or if you just crave some difficult gameplay and not-so-stupid games. This is what you have to get then.9.8/10, would play again and again

												Have you ever thought to yourself "Hmm... I need something fun to do but my taxes don't need to be done for another few months" then look no further, my dull friend! The ultimate border and treaty simulator is here to satisfy your every need. Ever wished you could have a wife and just divorce her and kill her for bearing no sons? Done! Ever wished you could just ruin everyone elses day because of their religion, like a kid kicking over someone's sand castle because "Mine is better"? Look no further. Crusader Kings II is here to satisfy all your medieval fantisies (So long as though fantasies involve looking at political issues instead of any of the knighthood or battle aspects). If you like like strategy games so in depth that you can practically drown in them, this is for you!

content:
Posted: April 8
												So I started off as a lowly Welsh Count, a vassal of the King of Wales.  After a generations-long struggle to successfully build up enough strength to rise up against my king, the only son of my previous character was born.  A just, gregarious and well-loved leader saw a sudden surge of support from other Welsh Counts and even an Irish Duke across the Irish Sea.  After forming alliances and taking enough in taxes to bolster my growing army with another 3,000 men in the form of some European mercenaries, I challenged the Petty King of Wales and laid claim to each of his counties one by one.  The Kingdom of Brethonniad was born!150 years into the game, a complex web of marriage and strategic sowing of dynastic seeds in Irish wombs led to my eldest nephew, the Prince of Brethonniad and the heir to everything that I had fought for, not just lining up to inherit my crown but also preparing his own eldest son and heir to inherit not just the crown of Brethonniad but two Irish counties from his noble mother and, on top of that, a strong claim to the Isle of Man.This is the heir that the dynasty had been preparing the kingdom for all of this time.  Another kind and just character with military expertise and noble blood was coming, expected to unite Wales and Ireland against the English and begin to assert control over the whole of the British Isles.However, the elderly King of Brethonniad was not finished.In his dying years, he found a new lease of life following the death of his respected Norwegian wife and queen.  In his late fifties and of ill-health, the King sought a new wife with whom he could enjoy his dying days.  To the surprise of all involved, a child was conceived.  There was a new heir.      The previous heir was no longer next in line and his prodigal son, set to challenge the English, took a giant slip on his climb.Out of the frustration of those around him, the new king grew up to be a tyrant.  Imprisoning family members and mercilessly excecuting them at will left him with a rebellion on his hands.  Who was in charge of the rebellion? The previous heir, father of the prodigal son.  With little or no support from his vassals, the king was unable to recruit a strong enough army to quash the rebellion and lost his title to the usurper.  With only a female heir, not yet in her teens, he worried that she would not be strong enough to undo his destructive ways and recover the prestige of their lineage.  Little did that matter as he later remembered that he had changed the succession laws to absolute agnatic primogeniture in his proud idiocy and the titles passed on to a distant, obscure male relative married to the count of Fife.Wonderful game.  Would play again.
