content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game was awesome. Key word 'was.' Poured a lot of time and effort into my Empire only to have an update absolutely ruin the ability to play any further. Apparently updates to this game have been doing this for awhile (making previous saves unplayable) the community would have you believe that plenty of warning is given on the forums. Whilst this may be true, purchase/playing of the game is in no way a binding agreement that a player must stay active on the forums and actively be a part of the community. Something you'll need to be (apparently) unless you don't want to be pre-warned about getting your save-games dicked. Of course there is plenty of warning about the available DLC in-game, but that takes precedence over anything else I guess... Great game, terrible update model. Extremely upset. Removed from my heart and /common file. :(EDIT: I gave the game a second chance and progressed well until receiving a sudden and inexplicable error message forced that game to a close too. I could not find any information online about what was happening so I signed up to the Paradox forums themselves and left a post in the relevant location asking for tech support. It has been viewed but gone unreplied to for the past two days. I guess you're scrwed whether you join the forums or not. In conclusion: don't purchase the game and don't support the developers. All in all a very frustrating experience playing (?) and dealing with their half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥performance in the gaming industry. Not good enough.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												I don't write many reviews but, I think I've sunk enough time into this game to give my thoughts. And my thoughts are- Pretty darn good. Sure, when I first got the game I had the same problems most have, I looked at itm the tutorial and repeated a hundred times. "What the %$# do I do?" But when things start to fall into place and you know what's going on and how to control things. It's wonderful.I love history, and this game is reliving, and rewriting history all in one go. Ever curious to what would have happened in 800ad if Ireland united and took over all of Britannia and became a medieval superpower? Try it out! It won't be easy, starting as a lone Irish count working your way up to unite ireland while staving off the vikings, scots, welsh and english (sometimes others!) But it's rewarding to look at your family tree, see your starting count "Count Bob of Connacht" and look down to his current living great gandson "Emperor Bob III of Britannia." And relive all the intrigue, war and crazy things in your head that happened from A to B for your dynasty.It doesn't end there. The "Irish Empire" is born- You really think the Frensh, or the Holy Roman Empire is going to let you have all the power untested? You think  aJealous half brother count is not going to start a revolution. Should you make them fear you, love you, respect you? Combinations of all? Go completely crazy? The choices are endless, victories and defeats.Ireland aint yer thing? Well with all the DLC you can really be anyone, Original game gives you access to most of the European nations of Catholic and Orthodox beliefs. Old gods lets you start form a earlier time period and play any Pagan religion. Sword of Islam allows any Islamic nation and so on!Mods are also great, giving more and more gameplay. Ever wanted to play "Game of Thrones" on CK2? There's a mod for that. Want to start in "The old gods" time period and make every nation no larger than one territory and see what empires arise where? There's a mod for that.Endless game, endless fun.9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												For the first two weeks of playing Crusader Kings 2 I sucked so bad at managing my dynasty that game sessions usually lasted for about an hour or so before they descended into chaos, civil wars and invasions, which inevitably lead to the complete annihilation of the great house of Insertnamehere and its disappearance from the pages of history.  And I didn't even mind.  Even when you fail at CS2, you fail so spectacularly and so interestingly that you can't help but enjoy yourself. Mayhap a long lost cousin emerged with an army and an ultimatum, seizing the throne and throwing you from high king to lowly duke? Mayhap that lovingly concocted poisonous wine you gave your spouse for you anniversary finally kicked in, but you were discovered and now his or her lover plots revenge? Or mayhap you managed to unite the Holy Roman Empire and Byzantium, ushering in an era of peace and prosperity under the watchful eye of a united Rome, only to have the Golden Horde drop by for tea and biscuits?Whatever happens you'll greet it with a grin 'cause, damn it, you won't be able to help yourself.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												If you like games with emergent story (That is, the story is created through your gameplay rather than pre-written), than this is an excellent game for you.  I'm on about my 4th or so dynasty, and I love the drama that comes out of pulling off some clever tricks of politics or military strategy.  For example: In my most recent game, I started as the to-be-King of Sweden.  I united Sweden before the end of my first character (when you die, you switch to playing your heir), and spent my second generation adding Norway and pieces of Ireland and Holland to the mix.  I was having some problems in the heir department though, even with 3 young concubines all I was producing was daughters (about 6 of them).   Worried about how the Norse would react to a female ruler, I sighed with relief when I finally got a son... only to have him murdered in his crib by his eldest sister.  I banished her from my kingdom and then fortunately had another son... and then a third.   This was a problem, because as the King of Norway and of Sweden, my sons would each inherit a different country, dividing my empire in half right as I prepared to go to war with Denmark to unite Scandanavia.  Unfortunately, I died of old age before I could come up with a solution (like murdering one of the sons, or finding some other way to disinherit them).   So now I was the 5 year old king of Sweden, and my 4 year old brother was king of Norway.  Within a week, both kingdoms were in open rebellion.   I was able to help my little brother keep his throne initially, but when a section of the Sumonesko to the north declared their independence, I wasn't able to hold off the wars and I had to surrender the Throne.  Deciding the best solution would be to get myself killed and pass my titles to my little brother, I placed myself under the mentor ship of a 21 Intrigue vassal who hated me.  This surprisingly did not result in my death, but instead I hit 16 with a 21 in Intrigue myself.  I murdered the king who had overthrown me, and then his oldest daughter, mostly out of spite (but also to keep the realm in chaos while I finished the war with the Sumonesko).  Finally, I was ready, and declared war on the child-Queen-usurper and found about 3/4ths of the nation willing to join me (the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who threw me off the throne 15 years ago, mostly).  I retook the throne and I'm recovering Norway and the north from the barbarians who moved in, and preparing once more to move on Denmark.  Long live Sweden!

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Game Play 10/10  (With all DLCs)   Standalone 9/10 (Without DLCs)     Interface 8/10This is a game of empire building/running.  Paradox chooses to focus on the Dynasty, which gives a very interesting twist to the whole genre.  You now not only have to focus on building up your "states", expanding your empire, and diplomacy, but also ensuring your line has the right traits to succeed for decades to come.   There are so many different ways to play and things to focus on, the replay value is huge.  I have replayed this game 4 or 5 times so far, and everytime found something new to focus on....   There are also different mods you can get that add either more realism or go so far as to change the game into a Game of Thrones sim!  Be warned though, this is NOT for the light of heart, if you just want a game you can waste 30 minutes on, this won't be for you.  This is a hardcore sim, one that you will spend hours and hours on.  Yes, you can spened a 30 minute session on, but plan on spending 100s of 30 minute sessions before completing a game!   The only negative I can really say about this game is the interface at times makes it challanging to give you what you need.   If you are searching for a wife for your heir, for instance, and you want to filter for certain traits, there is not an easy way to do this.  There is also not an easy way to go back and forth between screens so you'll find yourself having to do multiple clicks when you do your yearly "who isn't married right now" type checks.   Maybe there are easier ways of doing these types of things, but I haven't found them yet.  Other than this, this game is great and they keep adding great features through the DLC content (Usually 15.99 instead of the cost of the game, and if you wait for specials, even cheaper!).

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Probably the best game Paradox has ever made. The game is a complex sandbox where you play as nobility in the real world, trying to forge your dynasty into every corner of Europe, Arabia or India. You can play anyone from a lowly count, up to the emperor of the medieval roman empires.It has happened that I've devilishly laughed with great geniune delight as I expanded my kingdom of Burgundy deep into the HRE, wondering for just a moment why I don't have any friends. However that was instantly replaced by rage and confusion as soon as I realized that my character had died "under suspiscious circumstances", and that I now had to deal with an astronomically awkward inheiritance.There are also many ways to challenge yourself though the game as you can choose to play either as a christian, muslim, viking or slavic nomad ruler - most often carving out a place in the world for yourself and your dynasty through conquest, murder and marriages. Every gameplay feels meaningful depending on who you choose to play as because every place and every situation your happen to find yourself in present new obstacles to overcome. It's only in the later part of the game when you tend to snowball that the game slows down.I recommend this game.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												CKII is one of the most complicated and enjoyable Grand Strategy Games out there (although Paradox's games really occupy their own genre).  Control a medieval lord as you expand your lands through warfare, inheritance, and assassinations, while ensuring the continuance of your dyansty.  This game can be rather difficult to figure out at first so i'd highly recommend skipping the game's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial missions and instead going to youtube and looking up some "Let's Play" demonstrations of the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Game Play 10/10  (With all DLCs)   Standalone 9/10 (Without DLCs)     Interface 8/10This is a game of empire building/running.  Paradox chooses to focus on the Dynasty, which gives a very interesting twist to the whole genre.  You now not only have to focus on building up your "states", expanding your empire, and diplomacy, but also ensuring your line has the right traits to succeed for decades to come.   There are so many different ways to play and things to focus on, the replay value is huge.  I have replayed this game 4 or 5 times so far, and everytime found something new to focus on....   There are also different mods you can get that add either more realism or go so far as to change the game into a Game of Thrones sim!  Be warned though, this is NOT for the light of heart, if you just want a game you can waste 30 minutes on, this won't be for you.  This is a hardcore sim, one that you will spend hours and hours on.  Yes, you can spened a 30 minute session on, but plan on spending 100s of 30 minute sessions before completing a game!   The only negative I can really say about this game is the interface at times makes it challanging to give you what you need.   If you are searching for a wife for your heir, for instance, and you want to filter for certain traits, there is not an easy way to do this.  There is also not an easy way to go back and forth between screens so you'll find yourself having to do multiple clicks when you do your yearly "who isn't married right now" type checks.   Maybe there are easier ways of doing these types of things, but I haven't found them yet.  Other than this, this game is great and they keep adding great features through the DLC content (Usually 15.99 instead of the cost of the game, and if you wait for specials, even cheaper!).

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												If you like games with emergent story (That is, the story is created through your gameplay rather than pre-written), than this is an excellent game for you.  I'm on about my 4th or so dynasty, and I love the drama that comes out of pulling off some clever tricks of politics or military strategy.  For example: In my most recent game, I started as the to-be-King of Sweden.  I united Sweden before the end of my first character (when you die, you switch to playing your heir), and spent my second generation adding Norway and pieces of Ireland and Holland to the mix.  I was having some problems in the heir department though, even with 3 young concubines all I was producing was daughters (about 6 of them).   Worried about how the Norse would react to a female ruler, I sighed with relief when I finally got a son... only to have him murdered in his crib by his eldest sister.  I banished her from my kingdom and then fortunately had another son... and then a third.   This was a problem, because as the King of Norway and of Sweden, my sons would each inherit a different country, dividing my empire in half right as I prepared to go to war with Denmark to unite Scandanavia.  Unfortunately, I died of old age before I could come up with a solution (like murdering one of the sons, or finding some other way to disinherit them).   So now I was the 5 year old king of Sweden, and my 4 year old brother was king of Norway.  Within a week, both kingdoms were in open rebellion.   I was able to help my little brother keep his throne initially, but when a section of the Sumonesko to the north declared their independence, I wasn't able to hold off the wars and I had to surrender the Throne.  Deciding the best solution would be to get myself killed and pass my titles to my little brother, I placed myself under the mentor ship of a 21 Intrigue vassal who hated me.  This surprisingly did not result in my death, but instead I hit 16 with a 21 in Intrigue myself.  I murdered the king who had overthrown me, and then his oldest daughter, mostly out of spite (but also to keep the realm in chaos while I finished the war with the Sumonesko).  Finally, I was ready, and declared war on the child-Queen-usurper and found about 3/4ths of the nation willing to join me (the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who threw me off the throne 15 years ago, mostly).  I retook the throne and I'm recovering Norway and the north from the barbarians who moved in, and preparing once more to move on Denmark.  Long live Sweden!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2013
												After a whole lot of hours on this game, I feel I owe it a more detailed review.Crusader Kings 2, ultimately, is an experience. This is a good thing and it's most active selling point - It's not a game you win or lose, it's a game you craft stories from - as all the other reviews will likely show!It is a game that appeals to multiple playstyles. If you want to be the grand overseer, some sort of mini-god surveying all that you have and making incredibly far-sighted decisions about where to conquer, who to ally with and what wars to start, looking at it as a gamer rather than a character? You can.If you want to look at it as the character you are, say King Eucedis "The Fat" Salian of England, roleplaying as a man obsessed by excess, greed and pride, while simultaneously ruining future generations of your family tree by seducing all the courtier's wives and having a large pool of illegitemate children? You canIf you want to play it as a complete and total joviality, name your family the "Megatrons" and rename every single English city after each Sonic the Hedgehog level, because why not? You can.All of these and many more are games I've had. Sometimes the game hates you and wants you to suffer, such as letting your 25 year old genius, attractive king who has all the claims in the world die from a cough, leaving you to inherit as your 1 year old, dumb, hairlipped son, who immediately gets rebelled on by his better brother, leaving you a peniless and landless wreck. At other times, the game loves you and even though you played as a merciless, heartless father who had a child with his eldest son's wife (who also never had any more children) and then he immediately dies and because of your inheritance said child inherits, but the brother ends up staying loyal and true, which gives you more than enough forces to make the others kow-tow.All of the above scenarios have happened. More have too. More still will. If you enjoy having fun stories to tell people, or even fun stories to look back on, this game is for you.The only two downsides - The game has a lot of DLC, which all add a lot to the game. This is somewhat mitigated by them regularly being on sale, but the cost still adds up. I must admit though that even having that, I mostly still play as the Christian rulers that start off accessible, alongside the Norse - The key is to experiment after purchase of the base product with it online, as if the host has the DLC you can use it in an online match. That way you can get a feel for what you want. The second downside is the game layout. The game is not massive on visuals, aside from the pretty map and such, so most of it is small character portraits and menus. This has the side of making the game complicated because it's not initially easy to understand where you go wrong.But I promise you - if you put the time into the game, it pays off.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Crusader Kings II is a very good game. I think it's fun to play as a ruler and that you meet resistance along the way. You can pick ambitions, fulfill others ambitions so that they like you more. You can throw someone in prison, assassinate or excommunicate him/her but it might backfire on you. That CKII support mods is awesome, although I've only downloaded one so far.One of the best DLC:s I've bought is the Ruler Designer. With it you can change appearance, make the shield design as you want it and add traits. When I started playing this game I didn't have that many DLC:s and I felt that the base-game as it is was kind of boring. Luckily they sell the DLC:s cheaper from time to time. Now that I have played it for some time with the extra content I must say that it is much more fun. It's a shame that you have to pay extra money for DLC:s to be able to truly enjoy the gameplay. That's how it was for me anyway. The reward-system in this game could be better. Maybe some more in-game rewards in form of likes, money, prestige. To be able to get achievements on Steam, I have to play in Iron Mode. I have not dared to do that yet. It would be very nice if I could get some by just playing the game in any mode. CKII already has a lot of traits but I wouldn't mind to be able too choose among even more.I would absolutely recommend this game. If you like strategy then I think you would like CKII. It is not the easiest game. The longest rule I've achieved is until my Kings son took over after his fathers death. It was chaos from the start of the sons rule because he had some bad traits. The shortest rule I've experienced is one I've played recently. The man got sick and died shortly after. So many things can happen along the way and it's interesting to follow the rulers development. To try again with a new ruler after the last one failed. Something makes me keep playing it. Maybe it's the pace, the challenge or that you can customize so much. Or perhaps it's the freedom and choices. Doesn't really matter. I enjoy playing this and will keep doing just that. Maybe my new ruler will succeed where others failed. Maybe...

content:
Posted: March 8
												So, having played this game for 1000 + hours, i can honestly say, it is arguably the funest game i have ever played. With the deep modding support, And no one time being the same, this game is the ultimate Grand Strategy game.It does have a rather steep learning curve, but, if you stick with it you will be surprised how much fun you can have.Yes, there is a massive amount of DLC, but several are really optional that you don't NEED to have, some are fantasy (Sunset Invasion) And of course there are others that (in my opinion) are must haves:-Sword of Islam-The Old Gods-The Republic-Charlemagne (sorta)-Way of Life (again, sorta)-Horse Lords-Conclave (Slightly Annoying but still fun)-Monk's and Mystics-Raja's of India-Sunset Invasion (arguably the worst DLC relased, but, eh)-Legacy of Rome-The Reaper's Due-Son's of AbrahamThe list isn't in any order, just to show the primary content mods apart from everything else.So, in short, in my opinion this game is a must have for those whom love strategy games, and those looking for a new kind of experience.9.5/10

												Crusader Kings II is my favorite game of all time. Its depth, complexity, and staying power are unmatched by any other game I've played.That said... ♥♥♥♥ you, Paradox. The amount of DLC they've♥♥♥♥♥♥out for this game is absolutely shameful. Discounting all the cosmetic stuff, most of the big content expansions are things that should have been in the game from the beginning, and frankly the game is nearly unplayable without at least a couple of them.Play it, it's great. But the gnawing feeling of guilt you get when you realize you bought into the DLC scam they're running here lessens the experience a bit.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												To start off this game has been an amazing journey, I bought this because it was in my queue long ago. I am just a person who is interested in one strategy games and two historical games. This one fit the bill perfectly and when I purchased it I was extremely impressed. Before playing this I had never heard of Paradox nor played any of their games, after this game however, I love to play all of their games. This game is exciting and allows you to rule as your own medieval ruler after that you can do just about anything you want. The community for mods is also great and makes excellent improvements to the game the devs also have made excellent expansion packs. Many reviews will talk about the devs failures and how DLC is over priced. I do not agree with that in any way, I have slowly purchased most of the dlc and have loved every bit of it. The DLC add great content to the game and bring in new and interesting features. Yes the game is a lot of money if you purchase the game and then all the DLC however, how I like to see it as this you are getting multiple games out of one game. You want to play as a Viking you can do that, you want to play as a Muslim Caliph you can do that, you want to be a Catholic King you can do that, you want to be a Byzantine count you can do that. My point out of that is you can be anything in this game you get the chance to make your own story over and over and over again. Sure the game is not perfect however, no game is the game is special however, and this game will allow you to have a great time on it. The learning curve is steep and at some points extremely hard, thats okay though thats the fun of the game the harder you have to work the more spectacular the experience will be. I hope you enjoyed this review and I would recommend you begin playing this game.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 27
												It was a tepid summer night and a fresh but soothing breeze flew over the landscape of the county. It wasn't just some county, it was the one county where Lady Justicia ruled fair and just. A county where no rules would be broken, no secessions could happen, where no farmer or subject would stand up against their beloved duke.This is the story of your county. After investing gold into the possibility of renaming the ancient old and unfitting county name, your county "Anal for free" felt renewed. Reforms flushed through your political system and your subjects were simply happy with what they had and felt treated fair in your feudal government.The pope tried to gain influence of your county once again, so you decided to do what the gods actually wanted from you and you moved back in time to relive the old roman religions, pray to Jupiter and from there you can achieve something even greater:  Restore the Imperium Romanum in its greatest fashion. Bring back peace, power and prosperity to every subject in the known world with you as their Caesar and with the hellenistic gods at your side.Your dream of restoring the Imperium was brought down to reality when someone knocked on the door behind the balcony you stood one."My lord, you have to come out and do something! Quickly!!"You sighed. Once again, some vasall who doesn't like your new traditions tries to make himself and his fiefdom independant or join another county - obviously illegally, since you are their de jure feudal lord for hunderds of years already.You turn around and look into the blue eyes of your servant. She was a young girl, merely 20 and already mother of 16 children of which 12 were mongrels. However, when she was walking through your capital, trying to climb over the piles of garbage and excrements that once again piled up in the middle of the main market, you couldn't resist to stop your palanquin and have her join you.It was the best sex you had in your long 50 year old life. Your other twentyfour wives didn't really like the new girl, but you had all right to rule both over your god given county as well as over your women, so none of them actually had a choice and those who disagreed with that simply died in a tragic carriage accident.You slowly walked over to her and touched her face. She cringed for a moment and looked at you with her begging, big eyes. You ignored your empathy and pushed her back inside, onto your bed. Quickly you tore down her dirty dress and without even really noticing, you slapped her eleven times because she started to scream and begged you to not do what you decided to do seconds ago."P-p-p-please my lord, not again, I'm already pregnant again!", she begged. Without even thinking about stopping for a second, you simply whispered: "No worries, I'll clear that pipe and make room for a new one."You felt the feeling of pure power when you sensed the warm, moist sensation on what you called the Small Lord. What an excellent feeling that was. This was the reason you beheaded twelve of your former wives and it was the reason you got the county in the first place, because who could have thought that the former duke died only two days after you married her daughter in an orderly way (because you bribed him before of course), so that you became the next one to herit the county.It was the sensation that made the world true and it should be the one that would keep humanity alive for another 1000 years at least.Your servant screamed again and you simply pressed your sweating hands on her mouth, pressing so hard that you wondered if you would break her petite chaw if you pushed just a little more.Slowly you moved the Small Duke back and forth, increasing the great sensation that made you feel comfortable and it wouldn't be long until you felt the power of a thousand suns pressing inside your duke. The power that empowered mills to crush wheat, the power that made it possible for a ox to plow your land for the farmer that was working on it. You moaned as your speed increased even further and your pressure became unsustainably high. All of the sudden, your inner steam was released through the valve that the gods gifted to you inside of the greatest of all limbs. You kept laying for a moment longer, then got up and went back to the balcony. Your glance moved slowly over the peaceful fields that your workers had worked on over the day to capture as much of the sun's power as possible to keep your war machines running and fill your treasury.The moon watched over what the gods gifted to you and you were happy. After turning around, you realized that, once again, another servant could not keep up with your power and had to concede at your might. "Oh well", you thought, "I'm sure she got enough money to pay Charon for her last trip."Quickly you grabbed her leg and threw it out of your now blood filled bed, so that she landed on the other two corpses that you forgot to throw out last morning. You called for your only male servant that you employed only for the reason of reliability and had him move them all out of your chamber.You went back on the balcony and took a last glance at the farms - your farms - that were burning. You ignored the sounds of dying farmers and screaming children, while the troops of the neighbor county moved their trebuchet in position to hit your castle below you. Thousands of armed soldiers who tried to take away what you alone owned to enslave your people and make them part of another empire.The smell of burning wood and blood filled your nose. It was a good night.And it was good to be the king.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Crusader Kings II is one of those glorious sandbox/emergent game play titles where success and failure are two sides of the same coin.  Start with just a county and build a legacy to staggering heights - then watch it come crashing down!  Conquer medieval Europe!  Unite Ireland!  Take back Spain!  Defend Rus from the Golden Horde!Be warned: like Dwarf Fortress, event details take place in your mind's eye.  There are no fancy graphics - just a lovingly detailed map, and units marching across it.  There are no cut scenes - just pop-ups containing a nice bit of art, event details, and your potential responses.It's like The Sims meets Civilization, and it's glorious.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												A game like no other. Yes, it is mostly watching the map and sometimes giving orders (which means clicking 2 or 3 buttons). But if you want a medival simulation as realistic as possible, then this is the game for you. Just do not expect a lot of action going on. Also do not expect a real-time or turn-based strategy game. This game is not about conquering the world (Europa Universalis IV might be more your game then...), it is about simulating the feudal system. Therefore, there are mechanisms in the game, such as inefficient taxation when you own too many provinces or the gavelkind succession laws that splits your realm between your children when you die. While these might look like huge fun-blockers for an average gamer, they perfectly make sense in this game. Again, this is a feudal simulation and it excels at this.Recommended DLCs: The Old Gods, Sons of Abraham, Sword of Islam, Legacy of Rome.For long-term playability: there is a huge amount of mods, including some total conversion mods that put you in the world of Middle-Earth (Lord of the Rings) or Westeros ("Song of Ice and Fire" aka "Game of Thrones").

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a sandbox game where you given direct control of a single individual with the goal of preserving your family legacy. Gameplay is strategic and chaotic. It's one of the most fun things I've done in quite some time and I did start to really get into my character and their families.For example,  One of the Nordic Kings sieged my castle in Dorset while my army was away helping an allied king, imprisoned my pregnant wife and then after she gave birth to my first son (while I had Agnatic Primogeniture Succession laws), held HIM hostage, took my wife as his concubine - and then continued to siege my lands.When my army finally returned to the de jure Kingdom of England to take revenge, I was faced with 10 to 1 odds and no allies strong enough to make a difference.  So I decided I would have the Nordic wife-stealer killed in his sleep. My (now technically) ex-wife was MORE than happy to contribute to the plot and he was killed in a carriage while travelling. My involvement was discovered and the Nordic King's son was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I could not diplomatically persuade him to free her.So I tried a DIFFERENT plot against the son, except now I couldn't get anyone to back the plot. Even my ex-wife had moral qualms - she was free of her concubinage and had nothing personal against the 12 kid who we had thrust onto the throne. But I wanted my son and wife back.I couldn't use brute force, I lacked the numbers.I couldn't use diplomacy, I had♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the Nords too much.I couldn't use Intrigue, no one shared my vision.I couldn't use Religion, I wasn't pious enough.Sure enough, the 12-year old Nordic kid grew up to be a more terrifing fighter than his dad and decided to take his revenge by once again sieging Dorset.I was eventually thrust right back into the familiar postion of Elodie - except instead of a dead lumen mother, I had a dead duke dad. A young girl with no allies or experience needed to fight her enemies.Except where Elodie had magic powers and a kingdom's resouces, I was a poor muggle countess. It didn't end well.So I started a NEW game where I took particular note of the original Nordic King I was fighting and what he did and I have managed not to draw any attention to myself thus far.I am LOVING this game, but it was incredibly expensive even during the Summer Sale where everything was 75% off or more. That is perhaps the main problem with this game, although it has not deterred me.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												One of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. The amount of depth is amazing, and the text based build allows for very easy modding. Although some parts of the game may be ahistorical, owing the limitations of the game engine (Namely, the portrayal of Byzantium and the Islamic caliphates as decentralised, essentially feudal realms), there's still much fun to be had. With two years of DLC and patches under it's belt, and a further year (At least) to go, I can only see it getting better.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												If you're into medeval-themed games and enjoy strategy, boy is this the game for you.TL;DR Steep learning curve, have a friend / youtuber teach you, wait for the game to be on sale to get all the DLCThis game is incredibly fun, but the steep learning curve turns many people off though. Once you get a used to how the game works though, the possibilites are endless. I strongly recommend having a friend/family member teach you the basics of this game. What's that? You don't have any friends? Well lucky for you, there's a plethera of youtube videos that you can learn from, but it will take more time than being taught by someone in person. One of my favorites is ArumbaAnother thing that may seem ridiculous is the amount of DLC this game has, and that is not entirely incorrect. A lot of DLC is not essential, like the portiat DLC, but it does help with immersion. The essential DLC is just if you want to stay in Europe, but this game does offer playable characters from Iceland to India to the Asian Steppe. If the game is on sale, and you have $50 to spare, buy the complete edition of the game with all the DLCBEFORE BUYING DLC, MAKE SURE YOU READ THEIR DESCRIPTIONEssential DLC:CharlemagneOld GodsWay of LifeRecommended DLC:Merchant RepublicLegacy of RomeRuler DesignerSons of Abraham

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Rating 8.5/10Make sure you buy the CK2 Complete Pack on sale(GREAT VALUE FOR MONEY)This is a must have for any grand strategy fan.  (BEWARE STEEP LEARNING CURVE)<by this i mean a good 6 hours or so to get the basics. Even after this you are always learning something. would recommend Arumba's CK2 Tutorial Series on youtube. Also great to watch to get an idea of the features in the game and the level of depth involved.Features.Manage your dynasty.Plot to kill other characters in the game. Amusing events and decision based on your characters traits and ambitions(Of which you can manage once you learn the game).Conquer lands for your county/duchy/kingdom/empire.Manage your council and court.And many many moreIf you are still reading now for my reviewI enjoyed 90% of this game, although there are thing's that paradox could have done better such as the warfare,Building management, religion and the whole pope minigame, But this is still a great title and i was very happy with my purchase. I spent hours on hours managing my dynasty,Court and my council. While this was happening i was also plotting against my enemies and even my own subjects in my kingdom/empire who were a troublesome sight to my reign. Also had to help my allies and keep an eye on my dynasty members(sisters/daughters) in particular, who i married off to people in larger empires outside my lands who i had high plans for. Overall this game is outstanding if you enjoy a nice in depth/complex empire and dynsaty management system.

												I've never found a strategy game better than Crusader Kings II. I've owned it for nearly two years (ignore my playing hours, I actually have two copies of CK II; one from gamersgate, and one on Steam I picked up off the humble bundle), and I LOVE it. It's stunning in depth and complex like few other games, yet I found it easy to pick up and learn. Anyone who likes royalty, strategy, or family politics will love this game. Graphics are great; beautiful even. Very few strategy games I've played have such beautiful graphics in every area - character portraits, interface art, maps - normally something out of those lets you down. To mention it comes with its own, original music - beautiful, fitting classical pieces.I've found it to have infinite replay-ability. Not only because there are so many different characters you can try out (nearly anyone in mainland europe, and with DLCs all of India and the middle east), but because it has a great AI that always makes the world different each time. In the footsteps of real medieval europe, inheritance can change the map fundamentally. Play historically and rebuild the empires of a dynasty, or just conquer a whim - both are fun.This game is also constantly updated. Paradox has a great DLC policy where you get nearly every bit of content without the DLC just in the updates - all the DLCs do are to make characters playable, introduce new starts and new interface themes. So if you don't want to pay, you don't have to; you still get most of the experience, and you won't be left behind if you want to play multiplayer with others. There is no DLC wall. Not to mention DLCs can be easily turned on and off via the launcher.So much content has been added since I began playing, and the game is always getting better - just recently they doubled the map size, an enormous amount of work for Paradox, nearly 2 year after the game came out. My ratings?Music - 9/10Graphics - 8/10. Only thing that could be improved is player portraits might be higher-res.Gameplay - 10/10Replayability - 10/10Updates - 10/10Support - 9/10Overall - 9/10.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												If you know of this game you've probably heard it refered to as a "sibling murder, incest, warmonger, and religious intolerance map simulator" or something of the like. While this is a humurous synopsis of the experience - and mostly true - it's not very helpful if you're trying to decide whether or not to dump copious amounts of cash into this thing. I mean, just look at all the DLC. It's at least 160 something odd dollars for all of it. So, is it worth it?The short answer: maybe. I know that's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ short answer, but hear me out. This game is niche. Very, very niche. It's unique certainly, but that does not change the fact that you could very well absolutely hate it. For starters, if you're thinking of making this purchase and have not played other games like this one (Europa Universalis etc.) then go watch Arumba's guide on how to play it. Also, pay attention to the fact that it's 22 videos long of about 18 minutes each. Granted, they are very in-depth, but this does not change the fact that understanding how this game works is not easy. It's an experience, and you will have to put time and effort into this game to get any sort of rewarding feeling for playing it. However, once you reach that point it becomes something very fun. Suddenly your son dieing of small pox leaving your daughter the only one to inherit becomes a challenge, rather than a guaranteed game over. Your neighbor converting to a different religion becomes an opperunity, not a reason to cower hoping that they won't declare war. The Pope becomes your "friend" rather than the guy that excommunicates you so your neighbor can steal your♥♥♥♥♥♥ It goes on and on.Now, I like this game. I want that to be clear. However, this is not a game for everyone. It's not a game made for everyone either, hence the price point. This game in itself is a bit of a hobby, and while the price is stupidly high, it's about 6 or 7 expansions of decent content and a butt load of not so decent penny grabs. However, playing without all the dlc is very different from playing with all the dlc, and the game with dlc is objectively better most of the time. It's got more content, a bigger map, more events, religions, etc. As such, if your on the fence about this game, I'd suggest waiting until it goes on sale - as it does usually every so often - and pick up the whole thing for about 25~30ish dollars. At that price I'd hands down suggest this game to anyone with even a remote interest, but whether or not it's worth the full 160 is your decision, and you might regret it.Onto what this game actually is. In essence, you play as a family, not a single character. You do play as one person at a time, but you are survived by your children or relatives. You build power through war - which is not as exciting as it sounds - and intrique - which is. This game is not about the combat. It matters, yes, but playing a warmonger is only fun for about the first 80 hours put into a dynisty before you own all of Europe and are expanding into uncivilized lands. It is - above all - a game about the sibling murder, the incest, the bribing, the corruption, the intrigue, the homosexuals, the lovers, the concubines, the children, the murdering of the children, the arranged marriages, the raiding, the power struggles, the underlings -  the dirty, dirty unloyal underlings - the castle building, the character improvement, the ruling, and - above all - the characters. This game has no story, and yet the best story of any game I've ever played. Everything that happens is your legacy. You murdered the duke and stole his titles, well that's now part of your family legacy. Married into Royalty. That's there too. The whole game is about building your own alternative histories where the Scottish get invaded by the Moors and become Muslims, where Russia is formed early and fends off the mongols, where the Viking Pagan Empire stretches from Iceland to India. It's about doing whatever the hell you want, and it's glorious.This game is fun, and half of the fun is figuring out why it's fun. But for the love of all that is watched over by Zun, don't spend 160 bucks on the thing if you're unsure it's your cup of tea. It might be the best tea you've ever had, but wait until it's on sale.

Posted: November 29, 2015
												If you're into medeval-themed games and enjoy strategy, boy is this the game for you.TL;DR Steep learning curve, have a friend / youtuber teach you, wait for the game to be on sale to get all the DLCThis game is incredibly fun, but the steep learning curve turns many people off though. Once you get a used to how the game works though, the possibilites are endless. I strongly recommend having a friend/family member teach you the basics of this game. What's that? You don't have any friends? Well lucky for you, there's a plethera of youtube videos that you can learn from, but it will take more time than being taught by someone in person. One of my favorites is ArumbaAnother thing that may seem ridiculous is the amount of DLC this game has, and that is not entirely incorrect. A lot of DLC is not essential, like the portiat DLC, but it does help with immersion. The essential DLC is just if you want to stay in Europe, but this game does offer playable characters from Iceland to India to the Asian Steppe. If the game is on sale, and you have $50 to spare, buy the complete edition of the game with all the DLCBEFORE BUYING DLC, MAKE SURE YOU READ THEIR DESCRIPTIONEssential DLC:CharlemagneOld GodsWay of LifeRecommended DLC:Merchant RepublicLegacy of RomeRuler DesignerSons of Abraham

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Do you remember the primitive empire building mechanics in Mount and Blade? Ever feel like they weren't able to cover the real breadth of possible political intrigue? Did you ever think you could have solved a standoff by quietly assassinating a regent, marrying off your sister to a mongolian despot, keeping a rival monarchs heir under lock and key by offering to "educate" them before declaring a surprise war or carefully replacing all your precursors council members with men fiercely loyal to yourself? Then step right this way my friend, as Crusader Kings 2 is essentially ALL that and a metric tonne more.On the positive side Crusader Kings 2 is one of those games that benefits from a level of detail that should impress even the most brick-chewing and hardened history buff as the majority of its campaigns are based around the monarchs and clergy of the real middle ages. Paradox has done a laudible job in recreating the insane game of political backsies that these historical figures found themselves living through or dieing in. The fact that it also gives you a quick and easy way to look up more information on particularly interesting characters is a great example of tangential learning used in gaming. Further to this there's a truly dizzying amount of depth to the games mechanics that gives you an idea of just why every ruler had to have a retinue of advisors and counsels to help them manage information and make decisions. The lack of a strong structured narrative also gives the player a lot of freedom in how they tackle problems or exploit oppurtunities. It leads to some rather interesting emergent gameplay scenarios that I suspect people who enjoy the game while love swapping with other players just to compare how they each dealt with unexpected problems.It all adds together to give CS2 a real sense of atmosphere, refreshingly not in the usual "dark, rainy and miserable" sense that highly atmospheric games often default to. You end up feeling like a man (or woman) with a bit of power under their belt but an order of magnitude more responsibility than you could possibly have been prepared for.On the other hand...the user interface and tutorial could use a hell of a lot of work. Yes this is fairly par for the course in a Paradox game but it becomes more of a bugbear than usual in CS2 due to the sheer magnitude of information the game is required to communicate to the player.  You open a single figure's profile and you're given their nationality, general skills, specific strengths and weaknesses, religion, marriage/betrothal status, claims to land and title, demense makeup, alliances, honourary titles, family tree, dynastic tree, vassals, retainers, your opinion of them, their opinions of you, their hopes and dreams...AGH! STOP! Look I just want to know who his heirs are so I can kidnap one of them!Compounding this problem is that the number of possible avenues of play is quite large and, while the tutorial does it's level best to introduce us to all of them, it felt like trying to teach the specifics of circuit design to a confused panda: More difficult than nessecary and ultimately kind of pointless. When I sat down to go through the tutorial myself I had already initiated and succesfully resolved two murder plots by the time the game actually introduced me to the plotting and conspiracy system. Yet by the time my neighbours were marching over my home territory and I was running about in a flap trying to route them the game decided that now, after the invasion of my home had already begun, would be a good time to teach me about building static defences...on my island colony several thousand kilometeres away. Thanks CS2, you couldn't have mentioned this whole "developing technology" thing a little earlier? Perhaps back before my paper thin walls had been breached by a ballistae?Ultimately though once a player works out the ins and outs of the system, and yes that might take several decades of PHD level research and a small team of interns working around the clock, they'll find themselves immersed in a mechanically deep and highly immersive world that will reward them with... well probbably a poisoned cup of wine carried by your heir apparent but a historically accurate one nonetheless.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is a sandbox game where you given direct control of a single individual with the goal of preserving your family legacy. Gameplay is strategic and chaotic. It's one of the most fun things I've done in quite some time and I did start to really get into my character and their families.For example,  One of the Nordic Kings sieged my castle in Dorset while my army was away helping an allied king, imprisoned my pregnant wife and then after she gave birth to my first son (while I had Agnatic Primogeniture Succession laws), held HIM hostage, took my wife as his concubine - and then continued to siege my lands.When my army finally returned to the de jure Kingdom of England to take revenge, I was faced with 10 to 1 odds and no allies strong enough to make a difference.  So I decided I would have the Nordic wife-stealer killed in his sleep. My (now technically) ex-wife was MORE than happy to contribute to the plot and he was killed in a carriage while travelling. My involvement was discovered and the Nordic King's son was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I could not diplomatically persuade him to free her.So I tried a DIFFERENT plot against the son, except now I couldn't get anyone to back the plot. Even my ex-wife had moral qualms - she was free of her concubinage and had nothing personal against the 12 kid who we had thrust onto the throne. But I wanted my son and wife back.I couldn't use brute force, I lacked the numbers.I couldn't use diplomacy, I had♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the Nords too much.I couldn't use Intrigue, no one shared my vision.I couldn't use Religion, I wasn't pious enough.Sure enough, the 12-year old Nordic kid grew up to be a more terrifing fighter than his dad and decided to take his revenge by once again sieging Dorset.I was eventually thrust right back into the familiar postion of Elodie - except instead of a dead lumen mother, I had a dead duke dad. A young girl with no allies or experience needed to fight her enemies.Except where Elodie had magic powers and a kingdom's resouces, I was a poor muggle countess. It didn't end well.So I started a NEW game where I took particular note of the original Nordic King I was fighting and what he did and I have managed not to draw any attention to myself thus far.I am LOVING this game, but it was incredibly expensive even during the Summer Sale where everything was 75% off or more. That is perhaps the main problem with this game, although it has not deterred me.

												Rating 8.5/10Make sure you buy the CK2 Complete Pack on sale(GREAT VALUE FOR MONEY)This is a must have for any grand strategy fan.  (BEWARE STEEP LEARNING CURVE)<by this i mean a good 6 hours or so to get the basics. Even after this you are always learning something. would recommend Arumba's CK2 Tutorial Series on youtube. Also great to watch to get an idea of the features in the game and the level of depth involved.Features.Manage your dynasty.Plot to kill other characters in the game. Amusing events and decision based on your characters traits and ambitions(Of which you can manage once you learn the game).Conquer lands for your county/duchy/kingdom/empire.Manage your council and court.And many many moreIf you are still reading now for my reviewI enjoyed 90% of this game, although there are thing's that paradox could have done better such as the warfare,Building management, religion and the whole pope minigame, But this is still a great title and i was very happy with my purchase. I spent hours on hours managing my dynasty,Court and my council. While this was happening i was also plotting against my enemies and even my own subjects in my kingdom/empire who were a troublesome sight to my reign. Also had to help my allies and keep an eye on my dynasty members(sisters/daughters) in particular, who i married off to people in larger empires outside my lands who i had high plans for. Overall this game is outstanding if you enjoy a nice in depth/complex empire and dynsaty management system.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												I have enjoyed this game much more than I anticipated. My favorite aspect is the length of time in which to create a lasting "family dynasty." Paradox (the game studio) has offered, for better or worse depending, several downloadable content ("DLC"s), not all of which are crucial, but offer different enhancements. "The Old Gods", my reason for purchasing this particular DLC, allows the player to begin the game in AD867, instead of AD1066. Crusader Kings II, affectionately knowns as "CK2" which ends with the fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Turks in AD1435 (I think), has a DLC with allows a "saved game" to be exported to another Paradox game, Europa Univeralis IV, or "EU4." EU4, which is quite different, allows the CK2 game to continue on past 1435. CK2, has more detail when it comes to creating a family dynasty that lasts through hundreds of years and allows a player to play in a dynastic succession. If you have more questions, please ask!

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												A Grand piece of work in the Grand Strategy Genre of Grand Strategy games...Humor aside, the game has a strong focus on managing relationships (especially amongst your vassals) and guiding your dynasty from the Dark Ages to the High Middle Ages. The "Sandbox" effect and replayability of Crusader Kings II is by far it's most prominent feature, no two play-throughs will ever be similar. The Scope and scale of the game, and it's gameplay depth have been greatly increased since it's launch by many well-priced "core expansions" (Sword of Islam, Old Gods, The Republic, Way of Life, and Horse Lords). Offering countless hours of replayability, a good level of gameplay depth, and a vibrant modding community, Crusader Kings II is probably (in my opinion) one of the best Strategy Games of all time.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Crusader Kings II (CKII) is the most tactical strategy game of all time. From the producers at Paradox, it incorporates a number of features missing from most strategy games, and provides a robust modding experience allowing players to rewrite history on their own terms. As a person who detested Paradox games, I went into CKII expecting to be turned away, but instead, I was sucked in to an intricately unique character development system.Unlike most strategy games focusing on war and city-management, CKII's character development system sets the bar for future grand strategy games. Literally every character in the game has traits. These traits culminate into a character's statistics, and their behavioural A.I. For example, characters with the ambitious trait are aggressive in pursuing actions to further their own personal agenda; however, characters with the content trait tend to be passive. Characters who are lustful pursue multiple relationships, deceitful characters are more driven to betray others.As your nation's leader, you must juggle between these behaviour types, and more, to create a peaceful and large country amongst threats from various warring fronts. You have rebels, political strife, assassinations, the Mongols, the Pope, and simply ill-fated events, such as the plague. Age is also a factor, and as you and your council grow older, your favorite characters are more suspectible to illness, and negative traits, such as being infirm. One day, my talented leader died because his heart wasn't healthy enough for sex. The game is profoundly deep, and you'll feel like it accounts for everything.Speaking of sex, the game dives into very controversial taboos that would make some developers squeamish. There is imprisonment, torture, concubines, bi-sexual relationships, pagan religions, cruelty to children, making someone eunich, and that's just the original CKII content! Intrepid modders have already added slavery, assassinating your own children, and fantasy content, such as Succubi, werewolves, and vampires. The game is what you make of it! CKII also has an ambitious Game of Thrones mod. It includes a customized map, and all the characters from the show with their corresponding behavioural traits, events, and more.CKII is a ground-breaking ambitious title setting the bar for future strategy games. It's character-driven concept is fresh and innovative, and I hope Sega's Total War series embraces some of its ideas.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I've spent waaaaay too much time in this game whether modding or playing it.This game certaintly has a hard learning curve but once you understand it the game is incredible.  I recommend choosing the Canary islands and speeding up the game for around 30 years and then saving and reentering as a random person in the world.  It is incredibly satisfying seeing the insanity that is possible and slowly working your way up the ranks.Even aside from the world the game brings, if you don't like medieval Europe then get a mod that is a post-apocalyptic North America or Skyrim or Game of Thrones.  You can add magic, werewolves, and many other assortment of Fantasy beings.  There's a mod that completely transforms the game into the space age.  Counties are now worlds and it adds a ton more content with all new cultures and religions.Even better than all that, if you don't like a small part of the game, even part of a mod, you can just take it out.  The coding language is incredibly easy to grasp and you can remove or change pretty much everything in the game.  The only real downside of the coding side of things is the fact that there aren't really many guides out there and the ones that are out there are kind of lame and lack support.  That is all forgiven by me though as you can easily reference other mods and the game code itself to see how they do things.To add even onto that the console in the game is well done with numerous commands.  If you want to cheat you can cheat and if you want to play legit you can play legit.I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who has some time and the small commitment to learn the game.

content:
Posted: February 17
												Easily one of the best games I have ever played. I'm going to be honest, if you want your game to be action packed, this is probably not a game for you, as it is a 100% strategic game, especially in Ironman (not cheating, only autosave) mode.I've tried explaining this game to a couple of people and it's just not possible, 'cause there is just so much to it.Not only can you roleplay perfectly in this game, you can raise your Dynasty from the Count of Paris to the King of France, it's all in your hands.It might not be action packed, but trust me, if you are playing as a Count with a 45 year old wife, 0 intrigue (trait for killing people etc.) no children, and thus no heir, you are going to be Game Over.I can't say enough how much enjoyment and pleasure this game will give you if you love medieval, strategic games.There is, however one downside to it, if you buy the game without DLC's you are going to have to pay A LOT of money to really enjoy the game (have the ability to play as Muslims, Jews etc.) There are ofcourse Game + DLC packs available on the internet which will give you enough DLC's to play the game properly. Game is NOT recommend without the mayor DLC's.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Probably my favourite strategy game of all time. It is a very in-depth game which looks at the complex relations a ruler or lowly count must maintain to stay in control of your vast or small empire. You can play as anyone you want in Europe and beyond.The A Game of Thrones Mod is also amazing as it has totally converted the entire world, added events, traits and people to the vast world inspired by GRRM's A Song of Ice and Fire.This game is regularly on sale so it is a good buy for those who like other games such as CIV 5, Total War or other Paradox Games such as Hearts of Iron 3 or Europa Universalis 4.EDIT: A few years on and this is still my favourite strategy game of all time, with each free patch and DLC release the game just gets better and better. Whilst the game may be daunting to learn in the beginning it is certainly worthwhile. The huge DLC list may be off putting but only a handful are what are considered the core DLC (ones that add major features to the game past visual packs like portraits or songs packs etc) and there are plenty of lists you can quickly find with a Google search of which are the most recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												It has a VERY steep learning curve, but for strategy fans, I can't recommend it enough, its a very unique game. Basically, the goal is to last as long as you can, its over when ether you lose your last piece of land, or if your ruler dies without a heir. Its very complex, but so worth it once you get the hang of it. I mean really, how many games come along where you can say you had the Pope assassinated? Unlike a lot of strategy games, its not so much about build this and conqure everyone, its more about surviving and the political intrigue of the times. People will try to fabricate claims on your land, your second wife may try to have a son you had with your first wife assassinated so that her child will become the rightfull heir. You can start in Ireland and work your way up from count, to king, then conqure Scotland and England to form the Empire of Britannia. You can stratigically marry off your daughters to prestigous people of other countrys, then their sons will have claim to those lands. Theres different rules too, which you can change so that daughters can inherit, or that women can even inheret on the same grounds men do. There is a LOT to the game. The DLCs add even more, such as being able to play as pagens and sacrificeing your prisioners, if thats more your thing.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												This game is only worth it if you've played other strategy games and gotten bored because there isn't enough detail.You can plot to kill a member of your court, join a war, start a war, arrange marriages, imprison people, execute those people and quell some rebellious villagers while you're at it.In my game I helped my uncle take over Norway and once he had won using his wealth and considerable armies I had him assassinated and inherited it all at almost no cost to myself. Felt very game of thrones-esque.The one thing to be warned of is that since I bought this game a couple years ago the developer has removed things from the game and resold them as DLC, they've also added a bunch with DLC and continue to do so but my advice is to be careful with your money because you can easily overspend on this game to have a more "complete" experience.*EDIT* I should add that this game is very poorly optimized so even though it's a very fancy 2D game you can easily encounter very significant FPS problems given that the game seems to only utilize one CPU core. It starts off strong but the longer the game the more Ai characters your computer has to manage and that slows it down considerably.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												The sheer brutality of ruling Medieval Europe made available to you on your computer. I doubt I will ever have the "Paragon of Virtue" trait in any of my games. In order to be a strong leader you have to be smart, keep your vassals happy, forge alliances, make sure your heir is strong and that he inherits all of your holdings. I bought the Charlemagne expansion pack, and I am currently playing Charlemagne.Crusader Kings 2 is an awesome alternate history generator- I was able to marry Gisela into the Byzantine Imperial family (historically the attempt to marry her to Leo, Constantine V's son, did not happen since the contract was broken. In real life she became a nun, and ultimately was the abess of Chelles Abbey), which provided the foundation for a formal alliance with the Byzantium in the game I am playing now. I can't wait to see how history unfolds based on this, and all of the other choices I have made up to now. The only drawback to the game is that it's really hard to play the game "out of the box". The tutorial modes are not that great. I had to watch a few videos of gameplay on Youtube, enough to get a basic grasp of the game. I watched these two and went on with my own designs for ruling. This is the better of the two gameplay vids that I watched: 


YouTube™ Video: Let's Try Crusader Kings 2: Charlemagne 

			Views: 39,573		

			https://www.paradoxplaza.com/crusader-kings-ii-charlemagne?___store=world Want to see more? Make sure to Subscribe and Like!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I do think I could write rivers of ink about this game but, mostly, that would be missing the point of a good review, in particular a review that should be good for new player.So let's start with basics and the game's feeling: you control a dinasty, you get to decide things about your realm, your subjects and your family members... and then your ruler dies horribly and then you get a new character and everything can change (usually for the worse, true GOT style).There is little logic in Crusader Kings II mechanics, and most of time this happens because it actually reflects historical Feudalism. If you like logical strategy games you are mostly in the wrong place.That does not mean that you cannot find your logic trail here and there bust most of the time you just need to KNOW what triggers what. It is mostly about knowledge and less about strategy.That said the best part is the narrative side. The mix of events, character personalities and objectives can create funny stories.It is, and it has been for a while, my "just 5 more minutes" game, replacing Civilization, and I am quite confident it will stay like that for a while.If you like this mix but also more coherent and hardcore strategy experience move toward Europa Universalis IV. That is the agme for you

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This game... ahh this game. I was introduced to the world of Paradox games via EU3, and it was during the wait for EU4, it's acclaimed successor, that I fell into the world of Crusader Kings 2. Before anything else I will tell you this, Crusader Kings 2 is one of my favorite games of all time. I have spent countless hours having absurd amounts of fun staring at little marching sprites and glorified statistics pages on my computer screen. I have put more planning into securing lands, titles, marriages, etc in this game than I have on probably most anything in real life. I wouldn't have it any other way. The sheer amount of DLC is abusive and must be bought at massive steam discount. Much of it is purely aesthetic and need not actually be bought at all. But this is made up for with the sheer number of quality mods, including huge overhauls like my personal favorite Game of Thrones one. CK2 is basically the gaming embodiment of Game of Thrones whether the blades my little commanders are wielding are Valyrian or Damascus Steel.The point is you should buy this game. If you like strategy, if you like grand strategy, hell if you like court intrigue on TV, you will like this game. The learning curve can be a little steep. But a little effort to learn the game is paid back tenfold with endless story forging opportunity. Because that's what this game is, the most incredible merger of sandbox strategy and deep plot there ever was. Hopefully the people in your life will be at peace with seeing you less often.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I do think I could write rivers of ink about this game but, mostly, that would be missing the point of a good review, in particular a review that should be good for new player.So let's start with basics and the game's feeling: you control a dinasty, you get to decide things about your realm, your subjects and your family members... and then your ruler dies horribly and then you get a new character and everything can change (usually for the worse, true GOT style).There is little logic in Crusader Kings II mechanics, and most of time this happens because it actually reflects historical Feudalism. If you like logical strategy games you are mostly in the wrong place.That does not mean that you cannot find your logic trail here and there bust most of the time you just need to KNOW what triggers what. It is mostly about knowledge and less about strategy.That said the best part is the narrative side. The mix of events, character personalities and objectives can create funny stories.It is, and it has been for a while, my "just 5 more minutes" game, replacing Civilization, and I am quite confident it will stay like that for a while.If you like this mix but also more coherent and hardcore strategy experience move toward Europa Universalis IV. That is the agme for you

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This game... ahh this game. I was introduced to the world of Paradox games via EU3, and it was during the wait for EU4, it's acclaimed successor, that I fell into the world of Crusader Kings 2. Before anything else I will tell you this, Crusader Kings 2 is one of my favorite games of all time. I have spent countless hours having absurd amounts of fun staring at little marching sprites and glorified statistics pages on my computer screen. I have put more planning into securing lands, titles, marriages, etc in this game than I have on probably most anything in real life. I wouldn't have it any other way. The sheer amount of DLC is abusive and must be bought at massive steam discount. Much of it is purely aesthetic and need not actually be bought at all. But this is made up for with the sheer number of quality mods, including huge overhauls like my personal favorite Game of Thrones one. CK2 is basically the gaming embodiment of Game of Thrones whether the blades my little commanders are wielding are Valyrian or Damascus Steel.The point is you should buy this game. If you like strategy, if you like grand strategy, hell if you like court intrigue on TV, you will like this game. The learning curve can be a little steep. But a little effort to learn the game is paid back tenfold with endless story forging opportunity. Because that's what this game is, the most incredible merger of sandbox strategy and deep plot there ever was. Hopefully the people in your life will be at peace with seeing you less often.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												If you are looking for a grand strategy game, this is it. I came to this game as a fan of the Total War series, and initially looked upon Crusader Kings II with trepidation. However, I can honestly say that this game more fully scratches the grand strategy itch than any other. A word of warning, however. The learning curve is extremely steep. If you try to jump right in, you will surely drown! That being said, if you can devote the time to learn this game's expansive intracacies (every time I play, I learn more), you will not be disappointed. Who I would recommend this game to: Any strategy gamer that is not satisfied with calling "Clash of Clans" or "DoTa" a strategy game. If you wish the Civilization series had more depth, or the Total War series more historicity, this game is hands down for you.Who I would NOT recomment this game to: people with low attention spans.For me, hands down the best strategy game I've played in years.

												This is probably the best strategy game paradox has ever made. It has excellent modability and replayability, deep and complex mechanic, constant support (at least until they release new game), good visuals and music, and It gets even better with mods like AGOT (game of thrones) or CKII+ and VIET.There are however few issues with game engine - the longer you play one character/dynasty the slower the game gets, bugs start to appear, family trees keep getting messed up, crashes occur, AI gets worse. This hasn't been fixed with patches.I also disapprove of the excessive amount of addons and dlc's, and would've preferred if they bundled them together or kept some of them on sale constantly.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Crusader kings II is the holy grail of grand strategy games. On the grand scale you control a king and his realm (Or a duke or count if you'd like) and make various decisions to benefit it. On the smaller scale of things, you become entwined in a web of international politics and plots, domestic politics and plots, feudal succession laws and many other things. It's a game where everything in the world actively affects everything else in the world. DLC is not required at all, but it does double up the game size with each DLC, each adding even more replay value to a great game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												If you have the patience or a friend to teach you how this game works, it´s a game you can easily spend hundreds of hours in. If you are into strategy games I can definately recommend this one. It´s not the easiest to learn, in fact, after fifty games you will still learn more about this game, and with the continuous supply of DLC you will not get bored of this game quickly.Now, why is this game so great?+ A big map that gets expanded occasionally. You can start of as a viking king in Norway and eventually rule India, or start as a Russian Slavic pagan and become emperor of Europe. And who knows what Paradox is preparing to add next?+ A hundred of options with a thousand of choices. Whether you start off as a viking or a muslim, you will encounter similar problems. However, every religion, culture and country has it's own way of solving those. And as your character develops he will unlock (or block) other options. You'll never stop exploring these options.+ Easier and harder gameplay is possible, so whether you are new or experienced you will always find your challenge+ Great multiplayer, especially with friends. Whether you like PvPing or play versus the computer, a good multiplayer match will always keep you interested. Connecting to other players has been made easier (compared to how it was in the past), and is easily done via steam.+ Events and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold.This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.+ You can create your starting king with the ruler creater DLC+ Loads of DLC that add new and interesting things to the game. When playing multiplayer, only the DLCs owned (and activated) by the host are available. If you play with friends, have the person who hosts most often get some DLCs, so the others won't need them.+ Starting date can vary from 769 to 1337 (there currently are six bookmarks, respectively the Early Middle Ages (769), the Viking Age (867), the High Middle Ages (1066) , the Alexiad (1081) the Age of the Mongols (1241) and the Late Middle Ages (1337).+ No game will every be the same. After a hundred years into the game, you will notice considerable differences in each game. A game would not be realistic if not without flaws, so here are some of the downsides- Event and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold. This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.- Multiplayer can sometimes be unstable, especially if you play with more than 5 people. Desyncs will happen every now and then (usually you can play for an hour or two), and you have to restart your game to properly solve it. This is less common if you play with less player and if the internet connections are good. (If you have good internet, and so do your friends, this is MUCH less likely to happen.)- At first, this game might be very complicated and confusing. I recommend playing with someone with experience, if possible. - Once you get to a certain size, you will become quite unstoppable (although there are a few big armies coming to Europe, like the mongols, that might make you lose lands again). Overall I would easily recommend this game. Once you grasp how this game works, you will be able to spend hours and hours of your time into this, exploring the near unlimited amount of options, and seeing how every game is available. If you play with friends, get a co-op game going. 9/10
