content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Crusader Kings in an incredibly indepth sandbox medieval grand strategy game. Simply put you are given a map and a dynasty and your task is to do what ever you want with them! Take a lowly Count and raise him (or his heirs) to Emperor. Eliminate your rivals at court through intrigue. Conquer Europe and Asia in the name of a restored Empire! You choose an objective to achieve and use the games carefully designed features to achieve it.Things to note: There is no real time battles; numbers, terrain and generals dictate win/losses.It's not a graphically interesting game; don't expect the spectacle of the Total War series here.It can be tough to get into; initially the game can be overwhelming but if you stick with it you won't be disappointed.In my opinion this game is a must have for any strategy fan; push through the learning phases and you will loose hundreds of hours to this game.More info in the video bellow for those interested.[url=https://youtu.be/QHbOkqzLrCc/url}

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												This is a pretty nice game to be honest, although, really, I enjoy it a lot more since I got a fair amount of the DLC.Been on and off this for some time, but the more I play it, the more I love it. It's not like the Total War series (which I originally thought it would be like) at all, it's so much more gritty and, in some ways, devilish. It gets to the point where you manage to get past the learning curve which, thankfully, isn't too steep, and you're able to build a nice kingdom that has secure borders and is the ire of many. Pretty soon you'll have people bowing to you and wishing your might didn't come crashing down on you!The intrigue system is, for all intents and purposes, your home at some point or another. You'll be using this to stage either Grand Feasts or Mass Conversion to a religion or culture, but it's more fun after a point to be the WRONG religion in relation to your neighbours. Makes things  very  interesting. There is a little bit of micro-managing, especially when it comes to trying to get claims and manipulating other powers, but once you get this down, you'll be living in a spinster's paradise.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Let me start of by stating that Paradox Studios is by far my favorite company. They make their games mod friendly, they create games with great depth and amazing mechanics that essentially develop into hours and hours spent constantly replaying as different characters in different eras of time. Not only do they release the game with this much customer care, but they also continuously update it and include features without DLC that dramatically improve the game. Crusader Kings II is a ridiculously fun strategy game that you'll be able to spend hours and hours playing, while never boring in the process. It's character development and focus on historical realism makes Crusader Kings II quite possibly the best video game ever made. New comers to strategy will find it really hard to understand the mechanics at play, as it took several people that I know (as well as myself) HOURS of gameplay to finally get a clue as to what we were doing, But, once you understand the game, you begin your reign over the medieval world.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Hours played is conservative because I generally play offline. I like to try out a lot of different games and genres, but I always come back to CK2 (and I lose entire weekends to it when I'm supposed to be working). My favourite strategy game by far.It wasn't easy for me to learn (to be honest, I'm still absolutely terrible at it) - I had to look up things online frequently at the beginning - but even screwing everything up can be fun. I love the dynastic aspect of it (think Rome TW's dynasties but better). I get a kick out of marrying people off and stealing heirs. I don't often play an aggressive game - you can war and pillage if you feel like it, but you don't have to, which makes the game ridiculously replayable for me because eventually I get bored of raising armies and chasing idiots across the sea.My favourite part is earning kingdoms through a couple of generations of sneaky, well-placed betrothals. Which always inevitably backfires. You start doting on your little bloodline, get cocky because the wives start popping out geniuses all day erry day, and then bam, your only son gets landed by inheriting some obscure dead relative's puny county, marries an inbred forty year old, and screws up all of the beautiful perfection. I fangirl this game so hard...The game is frequently updated, and for me, stability is rarely an issue. I love the DLCs (yes, even Conclave). I want more events, and traitors, and faces... as I said, fangirl. But I've played this so much, and I still find new stuff in every playthrough. Well worth the steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2013
												It's a series of family trees (a familial forest, if you will) with a seemingly random event generator, whilst you essentially play as the godfather of your own pre-industrial mafia state. The game is about managing relations (based around an opinion modifier) with your vassals, personal court, liege lords, alliances and your family in general in order to succeed and thrive in the world. Made all the more complicated by the fact these people aren't always mutually exclusive, and if your younger brother is a powerful duke set to inherit your lands he does become a serious threat to be mitigated by alliances elsewhere formed solely by marriage, which will offer sufficient protection - but may scupper your attempts to breed with that commoner with the genetic Genius and Attractive traits and spawn some sort of Uber-Lord heir.Still: after all this you are part of a noble family spreading across Europe, West and North Africa, the Near East, and now India in the hope of... well, surviving mostly. That is the aim: the game is not about conquering, it's about stability, lasting longer than humanly possible as you serve as multiple patriarchs of your family. Even after the Mongols appear in the East and take half of your territory and annex you the next year: you won't have lost. You may lose your Kingdom to rebellions, your warfare, but as long as you remain in control of at least a County (the second smallest land division of the game) or a merchant House (one of the smallest units but only available in the Republic expansion): you will survive. Warfare is simple in some respects, it's based on territory, the leader, and unit types with a random dice roll. If you have significantly more men, you will win. If not, positioning them at choke points and distraction tactics do work - having an enemy army chase a small mobile stack, whilst your main force seizes their capital is a viable route to take. But, that takes a while, and in less you're defending it will cause your vassals to become and their men to become irritated and want to return home. You call up your vassals to fight for you much like an alliance, and if they don't like you: they simply will not come. Now, you can rely on your own men to some extent (maybe even hire some mercenaries for cash or a Holy Order - if you're fighting infidels) in a small kingdom or independent duchy your personal forces and permanent retinues can provide a decent army. But really, you need them as the core for which your vassals surround, otherwise they're going to be killed and the next rebellion that pops up will leave you defenceless.The base game has you play as a Christian noble (though with some variation as you can be: Catholic, Orthodox, or Miaphysite) though this is what most of the game is still based around there are some fantastic DLCs. The DLC has been as clunky as it has been brilliant however due to implementing non-feudal cultures into game mechanics designed around Christianity and vassalage.  For example, my personal favourite: the Legacy of Rome, is based around unique events for the Byzantine Empire and potentially refounding the Roman Empire. All DLC did however come accompanied with a free patch allowing for the game to update considerably anyway, so the base has long since changed significantly. The DLC allows for you to play a new play style, which frankly you may not enjoy: Rajahs of India is dull for me, however the Legacy of Rome and playing as a Zoroastrian in the Old Gods is fantastic. The only ones I will outright say to buy or avoid are:- Buy: Ruler Designer - you lose access to ironman, but designing your own house and choosing your religion does make being Jewish (Sons of Abraham) or Zoroastrian much simpler.- Avoid: CK2-EU4 Save Converter - ostensibly built to allow you to play your CK2 realm through EU4 but it simply doesn't work, there have been points where it has actually worked, but every update to either game breaks it and by the time it has caught up and been fixed, a new update is being announced.Other than that if you like the sound of a DLC, buy it. If you like Rome? The Legacy is for you. Venetian fan? The Republic. You like ahistorical late game invasions by an angry Aztec horde that you forgot about? The Sunset Invasion. 300 years of extra game play? Oh-ho-ho Charlemagne and the Old Gods.There's other minor cosmetic DLC too (unit sprites, music etc) that are pretty dull, but the majority of the DLC is complicated and really does add a lot to the game. Not just the unique play types I've mentioned, but the random events alone can be worth it. Such as when your child turns out to be the spawn of Satan, summons a cabal of witches, assassinates you, and attempts to conquer the Earth in the name of Evil.On the performance side of things: the Clausewitz engine is funny if you have an unusual monitor set up, though. I primarily use an 1176x664 which it will work on, but leave me unable to push the "accept" button, rendering warfare and diplomacy immediately unusable. So, prewarning there. Other than that the game is generally stable, however since the India expansion it does take up a considerable amount of memory to run: it is the most intensive of the Paradox Interactive games.So that's it, that's the review. If you kind of like history (but you're not going to be a pedant about getting things slightly off for the sake of playability), maps, managing relationships, and betrayal: this is the game for you. In essence, if you look at the Mafia and think "yes, that is something I could get involved with" then you'll lose just as much as your life as I have in a downards spiral whilst you tell yourself "just 5 more minutes."

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												What is Crusader Kings 2? You ask as you boot up the game for the very first time. 6 hours later you are involved in a plot to kill your brother, crusading for the holy land, and your uncle is leading a revolt to lower your crown authority.Crusader Kings 2 is a grand strategy game developed by Paradox that lets you play as a count, duke, king, or emperor during the timeframe of 1066 to 1453. Instead of most grand strategy games where your ruler lives forever, in Crusader Kings 2 your character will die and then you will continue to play has their heir until your dynasty is killed off or the game ends. In fact the entire game is based around you running your dynasty rather than your country. Good traits, prestige, and wealth are all passed down so it is important that you maintain good bloodlines, even if you need to kill a few family members off. The second part of the game is religion. When a Crusade or Jihad is called, you are expected to join and fight or suffer the consequences. Rulers of the same faith will tend not to go to war with each other while the opposites will. There is a lot more stuff I didn't mention but you are going to just have to play to find out.The game, unfortunately, has the "Paradox Plague" meaning that if you want to do anything (custom character/country) you are going to need to pay for the dlc. Even major things like playing as Islamic characters requires a dlc. Granted they are cheap and go on sale quite often, but it is still content that should already be in the game, or at least a free update. Thankfully the game has great mod support so you can play user created content.Crusader kings 2 is worth your time and you will sink a ton of hours into it. There is a learning curve, but once you get over that you will be ruling with the best of them.9/10UPDATE: Get the EUIV converter.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Takes a really good game to make me play for 16 hours almost non-stop on my first session.Crusader Kings 2 is an RTS like many of Paradox's previous titles; highly complex (where your typical RTS is concerned) and providing a highly realistic simulation of empire-expansion. Every facet, save tactical involvement in battles, is explored with detail, and with much at the player's control.One of the key features in CK2 is it's dynastic political system. Not only must you secure your line of succession through heirs to continue in your quest for glory, but there are no formal alliances. Everyone you can count on is either directly in your sphere of influence and thus obligated to serve, or aligned through familial ties.Even though I bought it during the sale, as previously I was unsure, now that I've played Crusader Kings 2, I can definitely say I'd not have issue with paying full price for it. This is even one of the few games I wouldn't be opposed to paying full price for DLC.5/5

												As of now, I have ~200 hours in this game and I have to say I love it. However, there are some things you should know before buying this game.1. The learning curve is semi-steep2. There is no 'objective' per se. You have to find what YOU want to do in the game.3. You should have the major DLCs like The Old Gods, Charlemagne, The Republic, Sons of Abraham, and Legacy of Rome.I'll admit that initially this game appears to be an overwhelming database of content, but the truth is that it only looks that way and is in no way confusing once you get about five hours into it. There are too many features for me to mention, but I HIGHLY recommend buying this game as it has tons of replay value.Update: ~800 hours in and the game still is just as fun. I can't recommend it more!

content:

												Oh gosh, the visceral experience of looking at maps, menus, and occasionaly seeing two giant men duke it on over a county is one of the most thrilling experiences I have ever had.Forget Call of Duty and Battlefied when it comes to intensity. When your only heir contracts Smallpox and you are sure he will die, you are on the edge of your seat hoping for a miracle, even though one won't come, even with all that piety sitting there being nice and pretty.You won't regret buying this game, even if you aren't a maps and menus sort of man, this has helped me learn about the different nations throughout Medieval Europe, and how you can ruin history, so can everyone else! Simply by playing as Vikings and taking Scotland and making it Skotland.10/10, would play again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
 Crusader Kings II Review This is going to be a long in-depth review into Crusader Kings 2 so you better get some snacks to fill yourself up for the read.  Gameplay (8/10):  Crusader Kings 2 is a very unique game in the category of gameplay. It gets this uniqueness by bringing 2 genres together in a way different then usual. These two genres are RPG and real-time strategy. Unlike a game like Age of Wonders III where your RPG elements come from designing a undying hero, Crusader Kings II lets you create and play as characters that range from weak to powerful yet no matter what are extremely mortal. In Crusader Kings II your character has a set of traits that they start with however this can change in a blink of an eye. These traits can be obtained and loss through events and the traits can alter certain events meaning if you truly want you can play as if you have those traits. Crusader King II also brings in RPG to a slightly bigger level with not only managing relations with the outside world but with realistic an historic vassals who can leave powerless if left unattended. Also Crusader Kings II makes you manage your vast and growing dynasty in the game who can press their own inherited claims. In the category of strategy Paradox brings their classical style of strategy to this game with you playing and altering the past from historic time marks from between 769-1453 which then you may convert the save file so you may continue the saga on another Paradox strategy game. In the end where this game lacks is due to the massive locked content behind DLC (more covered later). Certain religions and start dates are completely inaccessible because of this.  Mechanics (9/10):  One area where Crusader Kings II excels in is mechanics. Unlike its counter-part in Europa Universalis IV, Crusader Kings II has a great variety of things to do even during peace time. Crusader King II has an in depth relationship system where certain decisions you make and traits you have can have an effect on a relationship with someone. These effects are shown as numbers where +100 is the highest opinion you can get while -100 is the lowest opinion you can get. Crusader Kings II is a game where relationships can turn from sweet to sour with the help of another system, the intrigue system. The intrigue system can be used to plot and kill people of your choice however if caught can drastically change the situation.  The systems work well and fit in together like a perfectly planned puzzle, even the marriage system. Using the marriage and intrigue systems in unison you can make your wife claim all of her brother's land and then she can pass it on to your heirs. There is three major systems that I haven't talked about that form the basis of this game. The first one includes a hierarchical feudal system. Firstly there are counts (the weakest playable characters) who own pieces of land who have barons living in them. If you have a few counties you may become a duke and etc. all the way from kings to emperors. The base mechanic is that you may only have vassals (people with land under you who pay taxes to you) that have a lower rank. You have a max amount of vassals you can have before you begin suffering from penalties, this is to stop rapid expansion and is to balance the game. Another base system is the holding system. Every character has a set amount of counties or baronies they can hold (a.k.a holdings). Duchy, kingdom and empire tier titles do not count as a holding. In a matter of fact having multiple of one of these titles can boost your holding limit. The final major system is the casus belli system. Unlike a game like Civilization V you need a casus belli to go to war (i.e. it is a reason to go to war). You may get these by fabricating claims or by naturally inheriting claims and more. There are so many more mechanics but then this review would become miles long but overall mechanics are detailed and in-depth, the only problem can be the huge number and complexity of them.  AI (7/10):   Like most strategy games Crusader Kings II has a difficulty option that changes the way the AI works. However it is unconventionally placed in the options menu. Yes this allows you to change the difficulty of a save mid-way through however it changes the difficulty of all the saves. Looking at the actual difficulties the differences between easy and hard can be seen. In easy the AI plays more passively and only declare war for casus belli they already have and rarely ever fabricate their own claims. In hard this is different as the AI will take a few more risks and is more likely to jump on someone's weakness even if it is a small one. Also they more pro-actively fabricate claims on other people's territory and in harder modes the AI is much better at vassal and family management. However there are smaller aspects of AI that is useful yet terribly flawed. If you have excess holdings you are able to let a AI give out your excess holdings. This piece of the AI is broken as it can give out the duchy your capital is in and make one of your vassal massively over-powered. In my opinion the gap between easy and hard is too great and a finer scale of difficulty must be used. In addition to that the easy AI should be given some more intellect so very basic decisions do not come out with the most outrageous decisions that even a new player would not make.  Price (6/10):   This is often the deciding factor when buying a game and that is the price. The base version of the game is £25.99. In my opinion this is a fair price but this is where the drawbacks come in. This game has huge amounts of DLC that when bought and added have great changes to the game and bring in a lot of new features and a lot of these features were developed after the game came out. However this is not the thing with all the DLC. When choosing a character you choose a person out of the map but some of these characters (e.g. Muslims) you cannot play in the base game. The game goes furthermore to rub it in your face by discolouring the play button, deactivating it and by saying "You need to buy the Sword of Islam DLC". That is not the only problem. Some of this DLC seems pointless. Although a lot of these pointless DLCs are 99p, these are things you would expect to be part of updates. For example new music, new textures for cultural units and even more useless crap. Yes people may say "it is a business they need to earn money" but do they really need to go this far? I think not. To get all the content of this game it costs a staggering £122.99 (This number is not outdated). This is by far the biggest dragging point of the game.  Overall (8/10):   Overall this game is very unique in its content. Despite its slight complicity once you’re into the game it just becomes second nature. It’s one more turn equivalent of just that one more kill or just that one more plot to finish effect does leave a massive effect on you. Oh and not to forget it huge replay-ability where no two runs are the same. I believe that the overall good quality of the game can somewhat make up for the high price.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												What is Crusader Kings 2? You ask as you boot up the game for the very first time. 6 hours later you are involved in a plot to kill your brother, crusading for the holy land, and your uncle is leading a revolt to lower your crown authority.Crusader Kings 2 is a grand strategy game developed by Paradox that lets you play as a count, duke, king, or emperor during the timeframe of 1066 to 1453. Instead of most grand strategy games where your ruler lives forever, in Crusader Kings 2 your character will die and then you will continue to play has their heir until your dynasty is killed off or the game ends. In fact the entire game is based around you running your dynasty rather than your country. Good traits, prestige, and wealth are all passed down so it is important that you maintain good bloodlines, even if you need to kill a few family members off. The second part of the game is religion. When a Crusade or Jihad is called, you are expected to join and fight or suffer the consequences. Rulers of the same faith will tend not to go to war with each other while the opposites will. There is a lot more stuff I didn't mention but you are going to just have to play to find out.The game, unfortunately, has the "Paradox Plague" meaning that if you want to do anything (custom character/country) you are going to need to pay for the dlc. Even major things like playing as Islamic characters requires a dlc. Granted they are cheap and go on sale quite often, but it is still content that should already be in the game, or at least a free update. Thankfully the game has great mod support so you can play user created content.Crusader kings 2 is worth your time and you will sink a ton of hours into it. There is a learning curve, but once you get over that you will be ruling with the best of them.9/10UPDATE: Get the EUIV converter.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2013
												It's a series of family trees (a familial forest, if you will) with a seemingly random event generator, whilst you essentially play as the godfather of your own pre-industrial mafia state. The game is about managing relations (based around an opinion modifier) with your vassals, personal court, liege lords, alliances and your family in general in order to succeed and thrive in the world. Made all the more complicated by the fact these people aren't always mutually exclusive, and if your younger brother is a powerful duke set to inherit your lands he does become a serious threat to be mitigated by alliances elsewhere formed solely by marriage, which will offer sufficient protection - but may scupper your attempts to breed with that commoner with the genetic Genius and Attractive traits and spawn some sort of Uber-Lord heir.Still: after all this you are part of a noble family spreading across Europe, West and North Africa, the Near East, and now India in the hope of... well, surviving mostly. That is the aim: the game is not about conquering, it's about stability, lasting longer than humanly possible as you serve as multiple patriarchs of your family. Even after the Mongols appear in the East and take half of your territory and annex you the next year: you won't have lost. You may lose your Kingdom to rebellions, your warfare, but as long as you remain in control of at least a County (the second smallest land division of the game) or a merchant House (one of the smallest units but only available in the Republic expansion): you will survive. Warfare is simple in some respects, it's based on territory, the leader, and unit types with a random dice roll. If you have significantly more men, you will win. If not, positioning them at choke points and distraction tactics do work - having an enemy army chase a small mobile stack, whilst your main force seizes their capital is a viable route to take. But, that takes a while, and in less you're defending it will cause your vassals to become and their men to become irritated and want to return home. You call up your vassals to fight for you much like an alliance, and if they don't like you: they simply will not come. Now, you can rely on your own men to some extent (maybe even hire some mercenaries for cash or a Holy Order - if you're fighting infidels) in a small kingdom or independent duchy your personal forces and permanent retinues can provide a decent army. But really, you need them as the core for which your vassals surround, otherwise they're going to be killed and the next rebellion that pops up will leave you defenceless.The base game has you play as a Christian noble (though with some variation as you can be: Catholic, Orthodox, or Miaphysite) though this is what most of the game is still based around there are some fantastic DLCs. The DLC has been as clunky as it has been brilliant however due to implementing non-feudal cultures into game mechanics designed around Christianity and vassalage.  For example, my personal favourite: the Legacy of Rome, is based around unique events for the Byzantine Empire and potentially refounding the Roman Empire. All DLC did however come accompanied with a free patch allowing for the game to update considerably anyway, so the base has long since changed significantly. The DLC allows for you to play a new play style, which frankly you may not enjoy: Rajahs of India is dull for me, however the Legacy of Rome and playing as a Zoroastrian in the Old Gods is fantastic. The only ones I will outright say to buy or avoid are:- Buy: Ruler Designer - you lose access to ironman, but designing your own house and choosing your religion does make being Jewish (Sons of Abraham) or Zoroastrian much simpler.- Avoid: CK2-EU4 Save Converter - ostensibly built to allow you to play your CK2 realm through EU4 but it simply doesn't work, there have been points where it has actually worked, but every update to either game breaks it and by the time it has caught up and been fixed, a new update is being announced.Other than that if you like the sound of a DLC, buy it. If you like Rome? The Legacy is for you. Venetian fan? The Republic. You like ahistorical late game invasions by an angry Aztec horde that you forgot about? The Sunset Invasion. 300 years of extra game play? Oh-ho-ho Charlemagne and the Old Gods.There's other minor cosmetic DLC too (unit sprites, music etc) that are pretty dull, but the majority of the DLC is complicated and really does add a lot to the game. Not just the unique play types I've mentioned, but the random events alone can be worth it. Such as when your child turns out to be the spawn of Satan, summons a cabal of witches, assassinates you, and attempts to conquer the Earth in the name of Evil.On the performance side of things: the Clausewitz engine is funny if you have an unusual monitor set up, though. I primarily use an 1176x664 which it will work on, but leave me unable to push the "accept" button, rendering warfare and diplomacy immediately unusable. So, prewarning there. Other than that the game is generally stable, however since the India expansion it does take up a considerable amount of memory to run: it is the most intensive of the Paradox Interactive games.So that's it, that's the review. If you kind of like history (but you're not going to be a pedant about getting things slightly off for the sake of playability), maps, managing relationships, and betrayal: this is the game for you. In essence, if you look at the Mafia and think "yes, that is something I could get involved with" then you'll lose just as much as your life as I have in a downards spiral whilst you tell yourself "just 5 more minutes."

TL;DRThis game makes Jaime and Cersei's p0rn shoot at Joffrey's funeral seem like rainbows and unicorns. ___________________________________ 26 year old king: Involved my sweet uncle by granting him a title and some hot, sinister honey to a plot to assassinate the nurturing breasts that fed me from my youth--my own mother. Imprisoned my sweet sister unsuccessfully. Now she is determined to tear her flesh and blood apart. Betrothed to an eight year old who had the specialty of being humble, a plus in my book! Everybody did it back then when this was considered to be the norm, at least for the British monarch, but now I finally got a taste of virtually grasping its essence in its most truest form. Alas, once I quit the game because I was getting very sleepy did the sudden realization of what morbid behavior I had done begin to gnaw deep within my grief, drenched soul. Taylor Swift's Shake It Off! always soothes me at day's end. Swift's angelic voice and mesmerizing twerking won't even relieve this guilt trip of mine. What have I become? WHAT. HAVE. EYYEEE. BECOME! ...the only logical solution is to start a new game to redeem myself. I feel better now.

												Probably the best game I've played in a long, long, time.In my opinion, it's more choice & consequence focused RPG than strategy game. At least, that's how I've been playing for twenty hours, thus far. I've had so much fun as my randy Transylvanian duke, with a penchant for seducing every woman at court, and the wives of others - sadly, he later died in his bed due to a mysterious snake being in there with him; haters gonna hate, I suppose.I had hoped you could play as a religious order, or an unlanded noble - that would make for even more awesome roleplaying - unfortunately you can't. I highly recommend this, with some of the major DLC - especially ones which add even more character interaction, choices, mechanics, etc. I'm currently playing as a merchant prince of Venice, and it really is a very different experience - I feel like some sort of mob boss.My only complaint is the battle system. It's often just a frustration - which is why I was glad I didn't have to focus on it as a merchant prince of Venice.(P.S. I only fell in love with this game when I stopped playing it as a pure strategy game, and played it for the immersive character interactions. Haven't been able to stop playing it since.)

content:
Posted: February 25, 2013
												An absolutely excellent strategy game. It is fun, deep, and engaging, but beware of the high learning curve. Once you get past the learning curve, it shows itself to be one of the best strategy games ever. It might even be my favourite game of all time.It is essentially a medieval dynasty simulator. Unlike most strategy games, you do not play directly as the country, but rather as a land owning ruler with many vassals, who in turn own land. It sort of has an RPG aspect with character stats and relationships that form between characters. when you die you are succeeded by your heir, but if that heir is not of your dynasty, the game ends. There is really no real set goal to the game, other than reach the end date of 1453. You make your own goals, such as conquering  a rival power's land, Reforming Pagan religions to resist Christianity, restoring Jewish Israel, Zoroastrian Persia, or even the Roman Empire, and try to survive in a hostile time filled with war and intrigue.

At least, that's how I've been playing for twenty hours, thus far. I've had so much fun as my randy Transylvanian duke, with a penchant for seducing every woman at court, and the wives of others - sadly, he later died in his bed due to a mysterious snake being in there with him; haters gonna hate, I suppose.I had hoped you could play as a religious order, or an unlanded noble - that would make for even more awesome roleplaying - unfortunately you can't. I highly recommend this, with some of the major DLC - especially ones which add even more character interaction, choices, mechanics, etc. I'm currently playing as a merchant prince of Venice, and it really is a very different experience - I feel like some sort of mob boss.My only complaint is the battle system. It's often just a frustration - which is why I was glad I didn't have to focus on it as a merchant prince of Venice.(P.S. I only fell in love with this game when I stopped playing it as a pure strategy game, and played it for the immersive character interactions. Haven't been able to stop playing it since.)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Fantastic. My most played individual game by far. With every patch, every expansion the game has gradually gone from good to just downright fantastic. Take the role of an individual person and lead your dynasty to greatness, control duchies, become king and form a-historical empires as you please. With the added ability to convert a CK2 game into a Europa Universalis IV game the experience is further lengthened and strenghtened. The dev team behind the game is fully in-tuned with the wishes of the fans and their forums show this, as fan's wishes for new expansions are slowly but surely making their way into the game. We've had catholisim fleshed out, Vikings, Islam and the Byzantian empire with more sure to follow. Sure, there are some negatives. Fear isn't modelled at all, you can't rule based on fear and the constant match-making can get tedious. Rebellion squashing used to be a hassle but has since been made more managable save the few incidents where rebel stacks several times your own personal retinue and combined armed forces stand up to overthrow you it's fairly well balanced. That said, there's a reason for this as well - you're a terrible ruler and you don't deserve to sit on a throne. A++ would play again, continuing to play.. over a thousand hours to date. That should in all honestly speak for itself.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2012
												Let me tell you some actual things that I've done in that Crusader Kings II:I was the Queen of Wales, and I saw that the person who was third in line for the duchy of York was an unmarried woman. She had three young children, two boys and a girl. The current Duke of York was a young man, with a single son, and a chaste wife. I invited the woman who might inherit York to my court, and I arranged for her to marry into my family. Meanwhile, I betrothed all of her children to members of my family. Being a member of my court, she had little choice in the matter. Then, I murdered the Duke of York, sending assassins after him. It took a small fortune, but he was eliminated. His young son made a poor feudal lord, being four, and it was quite easy to convince his court to murder him. With that murder, my erstwhile courtier became the Duchess of York. Two generations later, thanks to my long term family planning, the Duchy of York came into the possession of my family.I was a Scottish Duke, and I served my king loyally for two decades. He was my friend, my cousin, and I served with pride as his chancellor. But he sickened and died, and his young child became king. A wee lad of six, and I was made his regent and tutor. I also discovered that I was his heir. So, I murdered him, and usurped the crown. My new vassals were unhappy with my actions, so I purged them and replaced them with cousins. I betrothed my son to a brilliant, lustful Byzantine princess, and all seemed well. Until my son swore an oath of celibacy. With needs her husband could not fulfil, my daughter in law turned to me. Not so long after, a baby boy was born. I legitimized the child, murdered my son and my wife, and started over with my new family. I was known as Malcolm the Good.I was the Empress of Cymru (once known as Britannia), and my realm had turned to the Cathar faith. The Cathar faith is a Catholic heresy that believed in reincarnation, that a person might be man or woman in any given life, and which believed in gender equality. Being Cathar, I was able to land a woman with a fine mind for tactics as a countess, and I made her my marshal. When the Caliph declared a Jihad against me, trying to retake Hispania, I gave her command of my armies. At times, all three flanks of my main force were commanded by women. That countess led my armies in every major battle, becoming pregnant twice during the course of the war despite being 39/40 at the time of the births. She was wounded more than once, she led armies into battle while being outnumbered 3:2 or worse, but she never lost a battle. She became the second most famous person in all of Europe at that time, with more prestige than the Pope or Caliph or Byzantine Emperor or the Khans. By all accounts, over three hundred thousand infidels were killed by her forces. After the war, she suffered from depression, she lost her courage, but she was still the best person to lead the fight in a Great Holy War against the Norse tribes, far from her home in Portugal. She died at home, and one of her born-on-a-battlefield sons succeeded her.I was the head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark, and a treacherous family member gathered an army and struck directly at my capital. He destroyed my retinue army, and assaulted my capital. Outnumbered, with no support from my allies, with my other family members choosing to support the usurper, I was forced to surrender. I remained a duchess, but all of the barons and mayors and religious holdings in my territory reported to the usurper. For a decade, I raided Ireland and northern France, carrying off loot and hostages for ransom. Building myself a great hoard, I waited until the right moment. Eventually, the usurper became embroiled in a war in East Francia, fighting most of the still powerful Karling family. With his armies weakened, I hired mercenaries and I struck at his capital, assaulting it and all of his holdings. He tried to bring back his armies, but my own force outnumbered his almost four to one, and he was crushed. He died in battle, and I imprisoned his brother and heir; I banished him from my realm, reclaiming my rightful titles as head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark.I have conquered Europe in Odin's name. I have forced the wives of my defeated foes to become my concubines, and I have shed oceans of blood in the name of women's rights. I have accidentally married my great-granddaughter and deliberately married my sister. I have served Popes and I have murdered Popes. I have been trained in the art of war by a Ronin. I have had misadventures involving a merry band of outlaws in my forests. I have restored the Roman Empire. I have murdered spouses for fun and profit. I have seen battlefields where the dead number in the tens of thousands, and fought wars where neither side could muster five hundred men. I have turned back the Mongol hordes, and I have watched in despair as they annihilated my armies. I have conquered Rome for Islam, and I have retaken Jerusalem for Christ. I have plotted, murdered, schemed, fabricated, built factions, sent bribes, hired mercenaries, raised armies, raised children, murdered children, arranged marriages, taken lovers, banished prisoners, executed prisoners, shown mercy to prisoners, died childless and alone, died with far too many children holding power and claims to the throne, and so much more.If you approach Crusader Kings II as Risk with an annoying thing about people that you need to deal with every so often, you might have some fun, but you're missing out on the real game: Eugenics and Murder Simulator II. The game is totally not for everyone. It is NOT a game that people pick up quickly. But once you get into it, it's the deepest and most rewarding RPG ever made. It's about guiding a family through history, through the sinners and the saints, through the great kings and the terrible ones, it's about surviving all the multitudes of things that can go tragically wrong, and it's about the joy of crushing your enemies, to see them driven before you, and to hear the lamentation of their women.As you might guess, I'm a fan. It really isn't for everyone, but if you have the patience to get to the point where you can take control of your own destiny there's really no game like it.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2012
												Let me tell you some actual things that I've done in that Crusader Kings II:I was the Queen of Wales, and I saw that the person who was third in line for the duchy of York was an unmarried woman. She had three young children, two boys and a girl. The current Duke of York was a young man, with a single son, and a chaste wife. I invited the woman who might inherit York to my court, and I arranged for her to marry into my family. Meanwhile, I betrothed all of her children to members of my family. Being a member of my court, she had little choice in the matter. Then, I murdered the Duke of York, sending assassins after him. It took a small fortune, but he was eliminated. His young son made a poor feudal lord, being four, and it was quite easy to convince his court to murder him. With that murder, my erstwhile courtier became the Duchess of York. Two generations later, thanks to my long term family planning, the Duchy of York came into the possession of my family.I was a Scottish Duke, and I served my king loyally for two decades. He was my friend, my cousin, and I served with pride as his chancellor. But he sickened and died, and his young child became king. A wee lad of six, and I was made his regent and tutor. I also discovered that I was his heir. So, I murdered him, and usurped the crown. My new vassals were unhappy with my actions, so I purged them and replaced them with cousins. I betrothed my son to a brilliant, lustful Byzantine princess, and all seemed well. Until my son swore an oath of celibacy. With needs her husband could not fulfil, my daughter in law turned to me. Not so long after, a baby boy was born. I legitimized the child, murdered my son and my wife, and started over with my new family. I was known as Malcolm the Good.I was the Empress of Cymru (once known as Britannia), and my realm had turned to the Cathar faith. The Cathar faith is a Catholic heresy that believed in reincarnation, that a person might be man or woman in any given life, and which believed in gender equality. Being Cathar, I was able to land a woman with a fine mind for tactics as a countess, and I made her my marshal. When the Caliph declared a Jihad against me, trying to retake Hispania, I gave her command of my armies. At times, all three flanks of my main force were commanded by women. That countess led my armies in every major battle, becoming pregnant twice during the course of the war despite being 39/40 at the time of the births. She was wounded more than once, she led armies into battle while being outnumbered 3:2 or worse, but she never lost a battle. She became the second most famous person in all of Europe at that time, with more prestige than the Pope or Caliph or Byzantine Emperor or the Khans. By all accounts, over three hundred thousand infidels were killed by her forces. After the war, she suffered from depression, she lost her courage, but she was still the best person to lead the fight in a Great Holy War against the Norse tribes, far from her home in Portugal. She died at home, and one of her born-on-a-battlefield sons succeeded her.I was the head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark, and a treacherous family member gathered an army and struck directly at my capital. He destroyed my retinue army, and assaulted my capital. Outnumbered, with no support from my allies, with my other family members choosing to support the usurper, I was forced to surrender. I remained a duchess, but all of the barons and mayors and religious holdings in my territory reported to the usurper. For a decade, I raided Ireland and northern France, carrying off loot and hostages for ransom. Building myself a great hoard, I waited until the right moment. Eventually, the usurper became embroiled in a war in East Francia, fighting most of the still powerful Karling family. With his armies weakened, I hired mercenaries and I struck at his capital, assaulting it and all of his holdings. He tried to bring back his armies, but my own force outnumbered his almost four to one, and he was crushed. He died in battle, and I imprisoned his brother and heir; I banished him from my realm, reclaiming my rightful titles as head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark.I have conquered Europe in Odin's name. I have forced the wives of my defeated foes to become my concubines, and I have shed oceans of blood in the name of women's rights. I have accidentally married my great-granddaughter and deliberately married my sister. I have served Popes and I have murdered Popes. I have been trained in the art of war by a Ronin. I have had misadventures involving a merry band of outlaws in my forests. I have restored the Roman Empire. I have murdered spouses for fun and profit. I have seen battlefields where the dead number in the tens of thousands, and fought wars where neither side could muster five hundred men. I have turned back the Mongol hordes, and I have watched in despair as they annihilated my armies. I have conquered Rome for Islam, and I have retaken Jerusalem for Christ. I have plotted, murdered, schemed, fabricated, built factions, sent bribes, hired mercenaries, raised armies, raised children, murdered children, arranged marriages, taken lovers, banished prisoners, executed prisoners, shown mercy to prisoners, died childless and alone, died with far too many children holding power and claims to the throne, and so much more.If you approach Crusader Kings II as Risk with an annoying thing about people that you need to deal with every so often, you might have some fun, but you're missing out on the real game: Eugenics and Murder Simulator II. The game is totally not for everyone. It is NOT a game that people pick up quickly. But once you get into it, it's the deepest and most rewarding RPG ever made. It's about guiding a family through history, through the sinners and the saints, through the great kings and the terrible ones, it's about surviving all the multitudes of things that can go tragically wrong, and it's about the joy of crushing your enemies, to see them driven before you, and to hear the lamentation of their women.As you might guess, I'm a fan. It really isn't for everyone, but if you have the patience to get to the point where you can take control of your own destiny there's really no game like it.

												I really do'nt know what to say except: this is an excellent game. The way the entire system of  Medieval World was set up; the makers did a wonderful job. I am a history teacher, I thought I was informed about this time period. How mistaken was I. Now, this game has help me understand the mind set of the Medieval times. Also, how things worked in that time. Please, I highly urge you to purchase this game, mainly if you love this time or not you will be pleased with this period of our history. Try it! You will NOT be disappointed. The most important aspect of this game, is to be patient. Remember, this is a game you must think matters through and not go in without thinking first. Think before you do and not do before you think. Finally, the A.I. is competive and the story lines are great. Remember, no game is perfect, but this is an absolute wonderful game. I wouldn't NOT tell anyone to buy a game that cost a good amount of money on something awful.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Finally, a game that does DLC right.I came into this franchise a little after the Old Gods DLC was released. Intially, I just played the original game, since there's a pretty steep learning curve and  the base game alone has tons of hours of gameplay by itself. The great thing about this game is, it a fully complete and deep game no matter if you decide to expand or not. With that said, each expansion has brought a different flavor and experience to the gameplay that I hadn't even known that I wanted until I was playing it. Having played them now, I would not be able to go back to just the original game as is. Even owning this game for as long as I have, I still play it on a consistent basis.Some people argue about how expensive the game and all of it's DLC are.  CK2 goes on sale like, every other month (if not more). Pick up a DLC here and there (theres so much in these that you really will be kept busy by the features in each) for a fraction of the regular price. Half of the DLCs you can ignore, because they are mainly eye candy things - extra skins or shields. I wouldn't worry about those until you have all the gameplay ones in your library.And if all else fails, there's a great Game of Thrones mod.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I remember when I had a family, friends, and a youthful figure. This game took all of that away, and gave me something better. Every day after school I sprint home to resume my Crusader Kings 2 journey, forging my dynasty to make it the greatest in all of Europe. My teachers tell me I will have to repeat the 8th grade, that my grades are slipping, I tell them to meet on the hills of Normandy where my dynasty reigns with an iron fist. My family has tried everything, whether it be cutting my computer cords, stealing my monitor, or turning off the power in our house; I always find a way to return to my beloved Crusader Kings 2. The first 200 hours of this game are a warmup lap, after you complete the warmup lap you realize you need at least another 600 hours to get the complete experience... After 800 hours, you cannot stop, and you realize this game has consumed your life in every aspect, but do you care? Of course not, because deep down you know that your real life doesnt matter anymore, only the lives of your characters in-game matter. Once you come to this realization, you will be at peace. I must finish this review now, my Chancellor has notified me that my liege lord is waging war, I must gather my troops and prepare for impending conflict. Farewell all, and pray for me.

content:
Posted: April 10
												I keep coming back to this game. I've introduced it to my 54 year old father who is all about Civ games. It's just a well done game that continues to come out with interesting expansions and you are never fulfilled in your conquest or intrigue. It's an intense board game come to life. I've logged many many hours in this game and it's cousins. When I discovered this game a few years ago I was overwhelmed with how difficult it first seems, even playthroughs and guides couldn't really tell me or show me exactly how to play. And each time you reinstall the game you have a new goal, a new play that you learn and then the developers add something new that you want to try. If you haven't yet installed this game after it has been sitting in your library,  even after all these years. Try it again, give it more than 30 minutes. You'll fall in love with it and it may just become your favorite game. Plus then you'll get to finally play EU4 and everything else that they develop as well.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												I thoroughly enjoyed this game.I mainly play the Game of Thrones mod and probably only have around 15 hours of the base game out of my entire 200+ hours. Even though they might have some of the worse forum policies I've seen so far, I still love the political intrigue that comes with the game. Dynasties rise and fall, nations conquered, etc. Shattered retreat has a mod that removes it from the game completely (which is good since I hate shattered retreat, mainly due to the fact that if an entire army is going to retreat they would be much less organized. Especially if 10-12,000 troops just died out of your 15,000. If anything the army would split and scatted randomly, not being much of an army anymore.)Although I do hope for an RPG with similar political intrigue in the future (hopefully Game of Thrones based with smarter AI) as that would be a game of dreams for me.Amazing stories can also be created in the game, and I love the changes in history (or the differences in the Game of Thrones storyline) that can be found throughout it all. It's all extremely satisfying and I hope for more great mods in the future.Although when Crusader Kings 3 comes out you'll probably feel like your playing the first Crusader Kings on initial release. PI has a thing for reverting to it's base stage and making you pay for all the cool and interesting upgrades from the previous games through semi-expensive DLC.At least it's not Train Simulator DLC.

												Ever dreamed of cutting off your neighbourghs balls because he screwed your wife? Ever dreamed of then executing your wife and all your children so you can marry that hot hungarian princess and produce children with CLAIMS? No? just me? Anyway, this is Crusader Kings 2.Crusader Kings 2 is a personal grand strategy game by Paradox Entertainment, taking place between 769 a.D and and 1453 a.D (assuming you got the dlc). In between, you will form a grand Dynasty, backstab enemies, fight wars, ♥♥♥♥ing go crusadin and♥♥♥♥♥♥and hopefully rule the world. Or you might just die childless to the 715th byzantine revolt in the last 30 years.Unlike most other grand strategy games, ck2 works on a "personal" base, instead of a "national" base. What that means is, you are not the country of poophill, you are duke kevin II of poophill. This mechanic leads to a very interesting gameplay, where personal rivalries and intrigues, as well as the capabilities of the different characters play a major role. As such, it is fundamentally different from other grand strategy games, which is always welcome in my mind.Due to this personal system, the game also offers great variety on who to play. Wanna play a great byzantine emperor and reinstate the roman empire? You do you, go ahead. Want to play as a pisspoor eunuch, whose only way of dynastial survival is being cucked by his wife? If you're into that kind of thing, feel free to. The game has near limitless possibilities on who and how to play, and it will keep you entertained for hundreds, if not thousands of hours.The biggest contra of this game, however, is it's insane amount of dlc. Of course, most of them are not mandatory for an enjoyable experience (I for one recommend: at least get legacy of rome and the old gods.), but they do add up to an insane amount of money for one game. As such, you should grab this game while it's on sale. Stuff on sale is cheaper. Cheaper is better. You can spend more money on food that way. Or on your weird fetishes, but hey, i don't know anything about you.To come to a conclusion, I can fully recommend CK2 to anyone who's interested in a different take on the grand-strategy genre, to medieval history nerds of all kinds and sizes and especially to psychopaths who like cutting off other peoples balls or blinding them, just because he won a tournament against you (that's what you get, Patreikos).Happy Crusading, Deus Vult!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2013
												An absolutely excellent strategy game. It is fun, deep, and engaging, but beware of the high learning curve. Once you get past the learning curve, it shows itself to be one of the best strategy games ever. It might even be my favourite game of all time.It is essentially a medieval dynasty simulator. Unlike most strategy games, you do not play directly as the country, but rather as a land owning ruler with many vassals, who in turn own land. It sort of has an RPG aspect with character stats and relationships that form between characters. when you die you are succeeded by your heir, but if that heir is not of your dynasty, the game ends. There is really no real set goal to the game, other than reach the end date of 1453. You make your own goals, such as conquering  a rival power's land, Reforming Pagan religions to resist Christianity, restoring Jewish Israel, Zoroastrian Persia, or even the Roman Empire, and try to survive in a hostile time filled with war and intrigue.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Crusader Kings II involes complicated strategy: diplomatically and economically as well as in handling domestic affairs to prevent insurrections and dynastically to continue your family's rule. It is set in one of the most captivating and exciting periods in history, has a myriad of possibilities, and even shows complex webs of feudal relationships quite well. It is a game that may seem overwhelming at first -- but that initial overwhelmingness translates into much thought and variations later. As with Europa Universalis 4, I definitely recommend the game, but it needs its DLC, which can get quite expensive at times.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												This game is seriously addictive. I can't stop playing, but it's great. Downsides are that it's a bit tricky / intimidating starting out, not much in the way of a good tutorial, and it can be complex. However it's still very accessible, just make sure to clock a few hours before writing this game off and get in the swing of things first if you're initially struggling. Great if you want to transition from more popular strategy like CiV into more complex games. The Game of Thrones mod is a must if you're a fan of the series. Absolutely recommend this if you appreciate games with depth.

												This is rather a simulation than a game. It has synchronisation issues and crashes in multiplayer sometimes.  the player need an imense amount of time. The game does not really have a steam integration neither does it help players connect with other players. it has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of DLCs at insane prices. there is almost no music and the extra tracks are DLCs that cost extra.It has hell long loding screens. it has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial which is probably the most boring thing to get into ever. But i still would recommend it. its a very good game. its complex. fun to play with friends and has many other very cool features. its one of those games you can play almost passively at one time and very actively at another.If you are looking for a world domination game this probably ain't really the thing, because it takes very long time to ammess smaller regions with war and war usually brings less new land than a few well placed marriages.31 hours of playing and i'm still not sure if i really understand all the mechanics. so yes this game is great, but its surely not everyones taste.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												There's very little to say that the dedicated, vocal and truly helpful CK2 community has not already said.  Grand Strategy is the name of the genre, but everyone knows the game is really both a broad and deep Medieval Dynasty Simulator.The learning curve is often described as steep, but it is only as steep as you want it to be.  Want proficiency in all the subsystems so you can build a dominant hegemonic empire?   Just want to fool around with history and see what happens?    The game will happily take all comers.If new to the game, don't worry about the DLC avalanche.   Try out the base game and see if it's your cup of tea.  (Hint:  if you like history or strategy or power or maps or even sweeping dynastic stories, it will be your cup of tea.  If you like all of these things, then welcome home.)

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I cannot explain what is so fascinating about this game.  Is it the alternate history?  Is it the dopamine hit I get when I reach a goal, or survive one more year?  Whatever it is, I find myself thinking about the count of Udonen, or the king of Georgia or whatever dynasty I happen to be playing.  A lot.  Even better, it loads fast, and if you only have 15 minutes?  No problem.  It is great for short bursts.Drawbacks:  you can sometimes get stuck in a situation where you can do almost nothing, except max out your game speed and wait until your situation changes.  This can occasionally lead to boredom, but it is a small portion of the game.

The depth and complexity with everything from politics and family is so, so far away from totalwars simple game it can't even be compared. I love this game from the bottom of my hearth.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												I bought the game 3 days ago and I have 45 hours in it so far.. This game is so addictive. I much prefer this game to similar games such as Europa Universalis IV, especially when you bundle it up with all of the DLC.I can't recommend this game enough, it is so complex and intricate while being exceptionally rewarding. Don't expect a military strategy in the vein of Total War, as Crusader Kings 2 goes beyond the scope of any Total War game. some people may find the combat lacking compared to games like Total War etc. However these are completely different types of games, which some people just don't get. Combat comes down to size of force, composition of units, commander abilities, terrain and other modifiers. You don't get direct control like you would in Total War etc.There are so many different mechanics at play all at once. You have the Feudal system, where you're trying to please your vassals and build relationships with them, while you're trying to protect and enhance your dynasty, all the while stopping plots on you or your family, you're trying build claims on land to justify an invasion and you're setting up an Anti-Pope because the Pope excommunicated your uncle... Seriously when it all comes together it is both mind-boggling and fantastic.If you've always wanted to Marry your mother and imprison your father while waging war on your illegitmate half-brother.. well now you can. And it's brilliant.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												One of the greatest games ever made.I always had a love-hate/hate-love to Paradox Interactive. It all started when I used to play their 2005 published game "Knights of Honor" and they never released a KoH2. But with the start of the Crusader Kings series I started to love them again, even though, it took them years to release a second part.I awaited this game with high expectations, which got fullfilled. The economical and political algorythm is deep and complex, so the game provides hours of game fun for every strategy junkie. Even if I think the DLCs are slightly expensive for the short time they release them every now and then, it is still worth buying them.Everyone who search for a great strategy game should really have a look at "CKII".Tip: Search your favourite search engine for "CKII Game of Thrones Mod" for the probably best Game of Thrones mods of all games.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2012
												This game is the most accessible and least buggy game that Paradox has ever released.You can unify your lands through marriage or mace, conquer Europe, go from Count of Dublin to King of Africa over the course of generations, or merely try to hold your kingdom together in the face of your relatives, who might not be so numerous or so quarrelsome if you didn't feel like having 10 kids a generation or two back.Ultimately, Crusader Kings 2 is a game of emergent story. I don't remember my conquests as much as I remember the time that a once-favored cousin in Ulster managed to grab a piece of Italy through marriage and immediately defected to the Holy Roman Empire, leading to a massive war as I attempted to bring my wayward vassal to heel and left me managing a motley crew of dissatisfied Italians who now owed fealty to a distant Irish liege.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2013
												Sheikh Hakim of Ascalon and Beersheba was put into a peculiar situation whereupon he needed an heir to his titles.  As fond as Hakim was of his wife, Fatima, his vassals were chortling behind his back: he only had the one wife!  Well, one wife became two, and two daughters became three.Things became more desperate as the the good Sheikh advanced in age.  Very concerned about having an heir to claim his titles and take care of his dynasty, Hakim took another wife, and yet another.  Fortunately his many daughters - six now - were betrothed to men who would be valuable (if mercurial) allies against the Emir who coveted the Sheikh's territory.At last, a son was born to Hakim and Fatima.  Abdulallah would be groomed and prepared to become the best hope for the Sheikhdom of Ascalon and Beersheba.  In time, Abdulallah would prove himself by going on Hajj to Mecca and fighting rampaging Crusaders bound for nearby Jerusalem.  When Sheikh Hakim spoke his final words - the Mohammedan Confession - his son became the lord at long last.Abdulallah's first task as Sheikh of Ascalon and Beersheba was to rise up and defeat the tyrannical Emir who dared to revoke his dynastic titles upon his father's death.  With the help of Allah - and a few coins well spent on Turkish mercenaries - he did just that.Crusader Kings II may go down as one of the most brilliant games I've ever played.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Probably the most deep and engaging historical game ever made.  Turns you into a know-it-all of early European/Eurasian history...and interstingly enough was probably was the best supplemental material for my History major throughout my college career lolBut seriously, CKII is like the real-life Game of Thrones.  You act as a sort of sociopathic line of kings/dukes/counts/etc and try to navigate the incredibly complex political realm of 800-1300 CE.  The game taught me more about the pagan faiths and general world geography than any class ever did.  Insane amount of detail and historical information, including political figures and their personal traits.  Makes you appreciate the game even more.  Even recommended it to professors as a sort of simulation of the time period.12/10

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												What makes this game so fun is also what makes it so replayable, the ability to write your own alternate history.There are so many ways you can play out your characters. Often unexpected events lead to very interesting, challenging or downright hilarious scenarios. Very often various characters that you plays as (somtimes even those you don't plays as) will end up endearing themselves to you, as you painstakingly try to guide them succesfully through the political quagmire that the feudal system can become.That being said, this is by no means a simple game, it is complex and can be daunting at first.The graphics are functional, and only serve to convey information for the most part.The majority of the storytelling will be going on in your imagination, since there are no cutscenes and events appear as a text popup with some artwork. Personally I love coming up with elaborate character stories, so this isn't even a factor for me.Battles are simplistic in nature, essentially clashes of numbers with some factors thrown in, like commander skills and traits, terrain and so forth.In conclusion, if you like grand strategy, I absolutely recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2013
												If you like both Role Play and Strategy games, this is the One True Game for you!Crusader Kings II features both well known Role Play elements (like character traits, decisions you make, interactions and opinions) and Strategy elements that fans of the genre are so used to.In this awesome game you play with a count, a duke, a nobody, a king or an emperor (featuring female characters of course) and behave however you see fit to rule or to live in this crazy backstabbing traitorous world once known as Europe. Handle rebellions or invasions from other kingdoms, handle the muslims or the catholics (you choose whatever you want after all), make sure the Pope likes you so you're not excommunicated and other kings or lords are not your worse nightmares, because they can and they will crush you.Shape Medieval Europe as you like...conquer the whole world with one single Kingdom and show how powerful your House is, but be careful...dark forces may be working against you inside your own castle...in your own court or council. That's right, you can hire people to be your councilors granting them titles if you want like Master of the Horse, Master of the Hunt and Seneschal among many others.The multiplayer aspect of the game is fantastic both in LAN and Internet servers allowing you to play with or against your friends. The game also supports modding being the most famous, perhaps, A Game of Thrones mod for Crusader Kings II, which, by the way, brings the game to a higher level.The only downside of Crusader Kings II is an indirect one: the cost of the many DLC turns out to be higher than some could handle but the DLC themselves add so many awesome new features to the game that going hungry for a month is totally worth it.My final rating for this game is an honest 9/10! Get it, learn the basics and play it alone or with friends! I assure you, medieval Europe will be glad to have you there..."Many were called, few were chosen"

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												The base game allows you to play a dynasty in medieval times. From ruler to ruler. You'll manage inheritance, engage in political backstabbing, conquests, tournaments and much more. You might wonder, all this playtime and no achievements? That's because not playing ironman or using mods disables them. But who needs them? The main strength of CK2 lies in it's big mods. Period. Like A Game Of Thrones mod, where you can play as most characters you know from the show or books. There are of course Dragons too. Or Warhammer Geheimnisnacht, with many different races and cultures. Elves, Dwarves, Lizardmen, Greenskins (Orcs), Skaven (rat people) Vampire clans, Tomb Kings (undead necromancers), Chaos Nomads, many different types of Humans and much much more. Not to mention Slaanesh. All of the flavor you might know from old Warhammer Fantasy, without the controversial AoS stuff. There are mods for other fantasy worlds too, like Elder Kings (TES) and Middle Earth.If the total price for game+DLC scares you, just wait for a sale and grab it all cheaply. Not to mention you don't need most stuff.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Disclaimer: I like somewhat complex games like Eve Online (yay spreadsheets), Civilization, Stellaris, Kerbal Space Program (best game...ever!!!!!!), Rimworld...you get my drift. So if you hate those games, I'm probably not a good benchmark for you ;)Just bought this during the winter discount period, and wow!! For anyone who likes micro-managing stuff and "deep" games, this is a total no-brainer. If the intrigue, spying and politics in Eve Online are something you like...you will like this too. Want to marry some lord's wife? No problem, just get him assassinated. Pretty much anything is possible. It's a bit like Civilization in terms of sucking you in. The hours just fly by. The main difference is that you actually CARE about characters in game. They aren't just figures on a board. Yes, upgrading structures and building armies is essential...but so are the relationships you build and influence between in-game characters. It just creates more of a "story"...YOUR story. I just downloaded the Game of Thrones mod and OH MY GOD IS IT GOOD!!! Right now I'm Littlefinger and I'm plotting to kill Edard Stark (the naive fool...stupid man!) so I can marry his wife. If that fails, Sansa will be mine...or Denyris. Geoffrey is a dead man, I just haven't decided how to get rid of him. I'm gonna wipe out the Lannisters (except for Tyrion of course). Tempted to create an alliance between the pirates, the dragon chick, Tyrion, Wildlings and maybe some of the Starks if they aren't so bloody dumb and get themselves killed. But first I need to make a child with Edard's wife or his daughter...because if Littlefinger dies of the plague or some other stupid reason, that baby will get me on the Iron Throne. If you like deep games giving you a great story, tons of complexity and micro-management, unlimited replayability and great mod support...get it. If you consider Broforce complex or watch the Kardashians for educational purposes...this game probably isn't for you ;)

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												For the past year my top game would definitely be "Crusader Kings II" for the PC. Simply put, it's a grand strategy game where you strive to conquer Europe through military and diplomatic warfare.The game has a serious learning curve, but with a few tutorials it comes together eventually. It has a great community, and if you're mildly interested in grand strategy games, the demo on Steam is definitely worth a try.Nothing is more satisfying than inheriting a large kingdom through a multi-generational plan involving series of assassinations, while simultaneously fighting off your religious enemies and enacting your masterfully designed eugenics program (to produce the perfect heir).

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Started a new game one week before finals, what could go wrong? Night before first exam, I can't stop, the Kingdom of Francia is within reach and I must succeed. Almost failed Constitutional Law exam. Night before second exam, it's been hours now that I'm frantically trying to save my dynasty. I've killed my brothers, sisters, sons and daughters in order to make the Basileus of the Byzantine Empire my heir. He dies, his slow matrilineally married son inherits. Suddenly, I die. My game is about to be over, no heirs of my dynasty, two weeks of my life about to come to an abrupt end. All his children must be imprisoned and executed, and now I have to deal with the fallout. I barely passed the Social Psychology exam. Night before third exam, I'm in the flow of a crusade on Hispania, when I realize another dynasty member has become Basileus. Time to try again. Many good dynasty men and women rulers died in that crusade. But I finally became the Basileus and Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, tonight was a good night. The following morning I aced the History exam, my professor never knew the Roman Empire was restored thanks to a Great Crusade that united the Byzantine Empire and Holy Roman Empire. TL:DR:10/10 Will become your #1 priority above all else.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												In order to understand why I like this game so much, bear with me for a second while I share a small story. Ivan the 2nd was the new ruler of Muscovy. His father had expanded the duchy greatly, but he had 3 sons. Ivan was the eldest, and his two younger brothers were not even of age yet. Still, when Dad suddenly died they each received a bit of the massive duchy. Ivan the 2nd was not happy about this state of affairs. Ivan had weak claims on each of their kingdoms, but he couldn't press them via war. The middle brother was just a few months away from turning 16 and he could get a wife! If he got a wife then that meant children and Ivan the 2nd would never get that territory back from his brothers. Then a terrible, awful, evil idea entered his mind. If he couldn't fight them directly, there was another way to inherit the provinces. After all, if something were to suddenly "happen" to his two younger brothers, then he stood to get everything. What a tragedy it was when both of the young children suddenly died in mysterious circumstances before they could have children of their own. Then Ivan the 2nd formed the Kingdom of Rus just in time for the Mongols to show up. Oops.

The game also supports modding being the most famous, perhaps, A Game of Thrones mod for Crusader Kings II, which, by the way, brings the game to a higher level.The only downside of Crusader Kings II is an indirect one: the cost of the many DLC turns out to be higher than some could handle but the DLC themselves add so many awesome new features to the game that going hungry for a month is totally worth it.My final rating for this game is an honest 9/10! Get it, learn the basics and play it alone or with friends! I assure you, medieval Europe will be glad to have you there..."Many were called, few were chosen"

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I have now logged 100 hours with this game + countless more on other Paradox titles: from a personal standpoint, this is the best game Paradox has made. This is strange to say because it doesn't really cover my favorite time period - that would be Europa Universalis. But in CK2, playing as an individual ruler and having to deal with all the varied personalities that you encounter in your role gives the game a narrative and role-play element that sets it above the rest of the Paradox series. The struggle to keep up with claims, maintain a strong council, prevent your vassals from starting revolts, arrange politically advantageous marriages, assassinate liabilities in your court - it all feels like you're playing a medieval House of Cards, or perhaps more appropriately the first two seasons of Game of Thrones. You will do horrible things to preserve and advance your family in the world, and you will enjoy it. Kinslayer means little when you're Emperor.
