number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												If you've played Europa Universalis and co, then this game is awesome. Enough said - buy it and dive in. If you've never played a Paradox game of this nature before then read on....This game has a steep learning curve, matched only by the joy from the gameplay after you get over the initial hump. My brother showed me the interface and took me through some of the concepts of the game initially which got me over that learning curve. I would recommend watching some kind of Youtube videos or reading up on the game concepts because it doesn't pull any punches when it comes to the terminology of the era.There's a moment when it just starts to click and when it does, it feels like you've opened a door to a whole new world of great gaming. I have spent more time playing this game than any other.I would recommend buying some of the expansion packs for flavour as the big ones have some excellent additions to the Crusader Kings gameplay however to start with, the normal game is great. I have always been a fan of the Total War series. This game is not that. It's not as hands on tactical (regarding battles and such), it's much more strategic in it's approach. It's much more personable. Your character, his or her family, friends, relations, vassals and enemies really MATTER.I have always been a fan of the Civ series. This game is not that. It's a much more in depth dive into the feudal system. Civilisation is a brilliant glimpse at the whole of human history. This is the PHD on the middle ages.If you're into strategy games, you deserve to play this and don't be put off by the initial learning barrier. Because when you're succeeding at this game, there's no feeling like it.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												At first glance, this game is extremely intimidating. The UI and overall gameplay are complex and hard to understand without tutorials; even with the tutorials, the game is just confusing. It doesn't help that you are never really given any goals or anything to do. Now, you may be wondering, why am I saying these negative things if this is a positive review?Because those are the things that make this game great.Crusader Kings II gives the best interpretation of Medieval government, diplomacy, warfare, and royalty in any game. Ever. While it lacks the fancy battles of Medieval II: Total War, it brings in mechanics like functioning diplomacy and levies for a much more realistic and fun grand strategy game. On the topic of complexity, a newcomer may find the maps and tabs to be excessive and stupid. Once you realize their function, however, you will find them indispensable. I mentioned earlier that this game has no clear cut goal. This is probably the best part, as you really define your own experience. Work your way up from Count to Emperor. Or don't. Maybe your personal goal as a Spanish Catholic is to finish the Reconquista. Maybe you want to convert to Islam and teach Christendom a lesson. It's completely up to you, making for a unique and personal playthrough every time.Your main incentive to get off your♥♥♥♥♥♥and achieve stuff is your dynasty. In the beginning, this may just be you and your personal family (if you are starting small), but by the end you will have a branching royal dynasty who may even be on the other thrones of Europe. Crusader Kings II has you play as a ruling member of your dynasty, and mixes in your character's personal life into the mix with your strategy gaming. Many events will pop up about your character making choices in regards to their spouse, children, friends, and enemies. This gives you a personal attachment (good or bad) to your character as well as others, making each playthrough even more unique.To conclude, I'll bring up another plus: The modding community. Mods have added minor tweaks as well as moved the game into the fictional universes of A Song of Ice and Fire and even The Elder Scrolls. They add even more replay value to a game that will keep sucking you back in no matter what. Thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Lie to your spouse, betray your liege, murder your own family - all in a day's work for any CK2 player.  This game is a wonderful tool for educating one as to why it is that sociopaths always rise to the top and the world is run by scumbags... and it does it by putting you in their shoes and making you stare into the Nietschean abyss of human ambition until Machiavelli himself would say "Yo, Darth Scumbag, dial it back a bit, ok?"You know that you've truly started to get into CK2 when you look at Geoffry Lannister and think "He's not such a bad guy.  Heck knows I've done worse."  You're halfway there when the ghost of Alfred Hitchcock appears to you and starts applauding.  Eventually you'll start calling guys like Francis Underwood and Kaiser Soze "boring amateurs."  You will begin to question your own morality, your own sanity, having to tell people that "Hey, it's just a game."  Then one day your jerk neighbor with the annoying dog gets arrested on an annonymous tip about the drug stash that you paid off the garbageman to hide in his garage and his dog discovers a two pound chocolate bar in it's food dish.  Then, and only then, will you realize that CK2 has made you a better person.  Yes, better.  Stronger, more determined, free of the constraints and burdens of lesser people.  Their silly morals and ethics have made them weak.  They deserve to be conquered by someone with more ambition, more intelligence, more drive.  Someone like you.Three job promotions, one new house and two unsolvable missing rivals later you sit back and realize that buying CK2 was the best decision that you ever made in your life.10/10 - I regret nothing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8
												"Crusader Kings II" is an unfortunate name for a game that is SO much more than the title indicates. CK2 is a history simulator that takes place during various times in the Middle Ages (700-1400 AD). It is also a Medieval role playing game, with clear elements of Dungeons and Dragons implemented throughout.I have never played a deeper, more intricate, and more sophisticated grand strategy game than CK2. Every time period represented has (an ever-growing) map of the "world" (Europe, N. Africa, India, C. Asia). The map is incredibly detailed and full of different cultures, and even better... you can pick just about ANY ruler you wish (ranging in influence from Emperor to lowly Vassal). Some favorites are Charlemagne (esp. for the detailed, historically accurate drama that plays out during his life), Rurik (viking founder of Rus/Kiev) and King Alfonso VI of Leon (the Tutorial character!). At the moment, there are ~8 "time bookmarks" that one can select when starting a custom game. It is stunning to see the world map change so much between each interval. What this means for you is an almost endless amount of variety. And you will undoubtedly learn a lot about history in the process (I know I did).As if this isn't already enough, CK2 takes things one step further by being an RPG as well. It's kind of like "Civilization meets Dungeons and Dragons." In CK2 you ROLEPLAY your chosen ruler... while still managing and expanding your realm (and techs) like you would in Civilization. Every character in the game has a set of D&D-like base stats: Diplomacy, Martial, Stewardship, Intrigue and Learning. On top of this - and also like in D&D - every character has a number of personality traits (like Genius, Cynical, Ambitious), as well as personal ambitions (have a child, see kingdom prosper) and a personal focus (War, Carousing, Seduction). The  secondary traits I mentioned (of which there are MANY) are of course linked to your core D&D stats (e.g. Martial determines how good you are at War, Learning ability comes with Genius, Diplomacy is needed to be an affective Carouser).Some character traits are set in stone from birth. Others can be earned/loss through how you RP your character. Or through luck. Or questing. Or by precious relics in your inventory/vault.And let me just say... that there many, many opportunities for RPing. You can always go looking for it yourself... say by starting your OWN crusade... or by making one of your Dukes the Court Jester so he tries to break away from your kingdom... or by secretly joining a Satanic cult that gives you superpowers (like Summon Familiar). This last part is where CK2 diverges from history/reality a bit... but who cares! Mideival history is more fun with D&D superpowers!Look, I could write a more lenghty review of this product... and feel like it deserves one... but the simple take-home message here is: if you are a fan of games like Civilization and like RPGs set in Medieval times.... THEN JUST BUY CRUSADER KINGS 2.Oh and get most of the DLC as well...Yeah that's the only downside to how this works. Vanilla CK2 is lacking some of the things I mentioned (like joining cults). Paradox is constantly expanding the depth, breadth and replayability of this game by slowly releasing DLC. Ok, whatever. Just accept this. Then go ahead and load up on DLC. It's frequently on sale for 50-75% off.

Christmas still sucked, in a big way.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												Crusader Kings II: The latest entry in the Paradox Grand Strategy game lineup.    Unlike in most of Paradox's strategy games, you take control not of an entire nation, but of the rulers within that nation. If your ruler has no heir, it's game over. Duke, King, and Emperor are all well represented here. The base game starts in a pretty historical 1066 (the Old Gods expansion pushes it back to 876). However, once you unpause it, history is thrown out the window. Everything can change from there on out.     Once you are familar with the UI and pretty much all the features of it, which can take a while as Paradox's tutorial is not extremely helpful in that regard, you are ready to start a real campaign. You set the campaign goals, forma  specific empire or Dutchy, make your dynasty last to the end of the game, 1453. It's up to YOU.   Controling the leader is a nice change of pace as well, becaus eit adds an RPG like mechanic to a strategy game. Many things can happen to your character, and ultimatly death, and then you take control of his/her heir. The mechanics are fleshed out and deep. They feel meaningful. You need to have a reason to declare war, and a good portion of the time you only have claims to one province at a time. This makes conquest difficult, but rewarding a little more realistic than other Paradox games. The graphics are pretty good for a strategy game of this nature, where you are essentailly staring at a map waiting for things to change. The Clauswitz engien does well in that regard. All the artwork ingame is beautifully done and looks marvelous. In the end, the only thing that truly bugs me is the amount of DLC. Many of it is purly cosmetic and is not needed to fully enjoy the game, but they do add to the atmostphere. If you are to get any of the DLC make sure to get Sword of Islam, The Republic. The Old Gods, and The Legacy of Rome as those are the meaty expansion type DLC's. If you want a very ahistorical scenario pick up "The Sunest Invasion" to have the Aztecs bid for control of Europe as well in an alternate history scenario.Overall I give Crusader Kings II a 9/10.

												It's quite impressing game. Compared to Europa Universalis IV it is more focused on running your very own family business instead of ruling an empire. Nevertheless map is small then in EU it feels quite more into-depth when picking best mariage partner for your sons and doughters which will (hopefully) go on with your struggle to found an empire. Probably new 'Stellaris' will be a mix out of both?Waited long to buy this title, as I doubt it is a never ending progress with all that DLC out there. Catched a quite impressive bundle, but still 2-3 DLC's missing...well the newest ones, which I hope to get in a sale ...hm... the other year probably. What lately brought me into buying this was the impressive workshop with it's huge mass of very interesting mods. It starts with some UI and color changes, upgrades with items, mechanics, fantasy mods and others and results in complete conversation mods like 'A game of thrones' or Stellaris like 'Sci-Fi' scenarios, which pretty much change every aspect, including map, of the game. With my current ~20 hours gameplay I'm just playing arround to find out all one could do, but looking forward to start my very own dynasty next. :)

												This game is like crack, it's addictive and once you start playing it and actually learn it, you realize that there is no game better than this.The learning curve might be a bit hard, but once you get over it. Man, it is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.Put countless hours in to it when it was new and bought every useful expansions pack (On sale, because I'm greedy).And all I can say after purchasing every useful expansion pack is "Just when I thought I was out, they pull me back in."It has consumed me, I was only a mere shell of a boy until I played CK2, now I have aged into a man.I guess I have seen most of the Christian/Pagan messages by now, but for some reason I just keep playing as them because it creates new stories every time with different characters. It just seems to have endless gameplayAs said, I wouldn't recommend something that's bad, but this is unhealthy good. Meaning that once you master it, you will probably sit countless hours in front of your screen, marrying away your children, building a kingdom and a dynasty, killing some heathens, plotting to kill your wife so you can marry a younger one etc etc.My most interesting character was Borkvard who was ironically called "The Blind" who was a maimed master of intrigue and a possesed lunatic. He managed to revoke many of his family members titles simply by spying on them and finding reasons to arrest them. So he could blot them all to Odin, he already had kinslayer for killing the last reasonable kinsman to go against him so no problem there. The guys he decides to blot all begs "Pleae Borkvard you can't kill me, we are family!" to which Borkvard just went full nope and said "It only proves my strong bonds to Odin" and sacrificed all 3 of his kinsman and inheriting all their titles. And weirdly enough achieving his Paragon of Virtue ambition.He went on doing several mad things like the red turnips act and such, before long after he died of old age and everyone hated him. 420/69 why would you even need a life when you have CK2?

content:
Posted: January 8
												I really want to like this game.  I do, I really do.  But I just don't.  Maybe I just don't get it?  Maybe I spent too long trying over and over with the "be a small duke in Ireland to learn the ropes" suggestion.  Maybe one of the dozens of goofy DLCs would make it more palatable for me.I think it's just that the game experience winds up being extremes in terms of things going on.  I spend years sitting and waiting for things - getting a false claim so I can start a war, getting enough money accumulated to afford a war, etc.  You want to plot to kill a young heir so that you take their place?  Hope you don't mind waiting 10 years!  Then, once a war actually starts, 100 little nonsense notifications pop up - oh hey, you've got a major pitched battle going, could you arrange a marriage for me or assign a guardian for my child?  Maybe you want to seduce a random courtier?  Oh, and of course, once I get a groove going and have a ruler who works well with a decent heir and am making some progress, he takes a bonk to the head and is "incapable" - but then won't die, so I spend years unable to do anything.I think I wanted this to be Medieval 2 Total War with deeper interpersonal dynamics and it just isn't, it's a totally different sort of game.  Was worth the $10 I paid on sale, but glad I didn't pay more.  Not saying you won't like it, but I definitely did not.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												This game is fun enough and fills a nice niche for people who want to play a grand strategy. I cannot recommend it, however, due to where the development team spends their time. Please take a look at the number and price of DLC available for this game. It's obvious that the dev team has continued to spend a lot of time working on this game. However, the core game itself could use a lot of improvement. The interface is confusing, especially when you're trying to establish relationships (education, and especially when attempting to match people for marriage). This is a very character-based game, however the search function for characters is dismal. Very frequently the search function does not provide full results for the query you provide, and doesn't offer options such as searching within a specific empire, kingdom, duchy, realm, or county. Should you attempt to look for people by looking at characters and seeing their relationships (family, vassals, etc) you are given very little useful information about those characters unless you click on them and make them your primary window, when it would be much more useful to the player to have a choice of views that would include stats and traits as a list of multiple characters. Finally, probably originally intended as a way to deter frequent loading of previous saved games, the ability to load games once you're actually playing is quite painstaking. There's no way to quit to the main menu without first resigning a game, and then loading a saved game takes 4 clicks when 2 should suffice, and the saved game information provided is minimal, even with a full screen preview prior to the 4th click.Perhaps if the devs were making efforts to improve the core game's interface somewhere amidst pushing out dozens of DLCs I would be more apt to recommend this game, but as it stands (especially with purchasable DLCs being advertised to you in-game) I cannot.

content:
Posted: March 27
												5 hours in and I finally finished the TUTORIAL!You read that right. 5 hours. For the tutorial.That is not a negative for me. That is by far one of the biggest positives in a game I've had in a while.This game is layered like the world's biggest onion. The amount of micromanagement in this game is definitely something for the record books.And the lore! The lore is rich, detailed, abundant--and most importantly--factually correct. If history class/social studies approached the material in the curriculum like Crusader Kings 2 does, I most certainly would have paid more attention in school. =PI've read the base game itself is woefully incomplete, and that the developers of CK2 have a penchant of nick-and-diming the player for content patches. That's really unfortunate, because an aggressive DLC model of a 40-60$ game is just plain rude and almost shows a sort of indignation towards the player. Every patch has minor mechanics (yet essential none-the-less) that should not be sold for 20$; we're being charged largely for an increased lore canon, which, in most games, I'd have no problem with (unless of course it cost 300$ like the canon in CK2 does). I do have a gripe with it in Ck2, however, because we're essentially being charged an arm and a leg for anecdotes on world history. I find that particular business practice to be offensive, but at the same time the developers deserve to be compensated for their hard work. Unfortunately, 20$ per dlc is like George R R martin charging you 20$ every time he wants to add a new chapter to the last Game of Thrones book, and so I refuse to pay full price. I suggest you do too. Instead, look for the DLC bundles through secondary sellers and save yourself your hard-earned money.If you're an impatient person, CK2 is not the game for you. I'd only really recommend CK2 if you're a history and strategy buff, and only if you like reading. And I mean, really like reading . This game is just one giant history text book and requires constantly poring over lengthy passages to learn complex gameplay mechanics (as well as character histories, opinions, etc), all while trying not to run your dynasty into the ground. Good luck! ;)

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Very deep game with interesting gameplay systems, marred by a lack of polish and a really bad UI.- After four years of development there's still no way to assign a title to someone from that region's details view, you have to do it the other way around and select the character first! Makes assigning vassals to conquered land sooo tedious. And that's just one example. One wonders why they don't let you export/import that stuff so you can edit it in LibreOffice Calc or Excel, it would actually feel better. <troll> Just provide a CKII skin DLC for those programs </troll>.- The much-touted roleplaying elements are nothing more than a bunch of dialog boxes. And they do love to obstruct your view by spamming dialog boxes. You know some games like Civ 5 have a better way of presenting updates to the player, right guys?- The combat isn't particularly interesting.- Doing anything in this game is typically a lot of work, often for little reward- The Youtuber/Streamers that seem to have fun with this usually exploit the system to the max, exploits that Paradox then takes out of the game, often without a proper replacement. Don't expect to have fun like them.No matter what you do, unless you love frustration don't play the William the Bast.erd start where you have a big army and go after England. The game mechanics don't support this scenario well neither from a gameplay or historical point of view, and the devs haven't made any effort to make it better since the game's release. You've been warned. (Curious? The game will usually snatch your victory from you just as you were crushing the last English province. Your King allies with your enemy and cancels your war, no option to rebel despite technically having your own kingdom now. That's the usual outcome of the suggested starting scenario... thanks Paradox, know what we'd like instead of more DLCs?)As an aside, I don't like Paradox's new policy of releasing a bunch of DLCs along with free patches. It means that feature introduced in one DLC can't interact much with others, and that they're unlikely to get revisited later. Please go back to the old "patch-expansion" model we were used to with Hearts of Iron III... people think they can pick and choose and pay less now, but they don't realize what they lost along the way. Newcomers, in particular, who get the base game for the cheap to try things out, will never know if they disliked their experience because they just don't like the game, or because it would have been better with 200$ of DLCs. A bit steep, to try a game the average gamer is statistically likely to dislike? And forget the refund policy, you need more than a hundred hours to make your mind on this one, not two.Despite my dislike for this game I might come back to it. So many people defend it as amazing that I can't help but wonder if I missed something or I just didn't experience the right scenario. But even if I discover it it will have been at the cost of close to 100 hours of my life, not sure that's worth it.Heck, if the idea is "make your own fun", I'm pretty sure I've had exponentially more hours of fun and satisfaction with a soccer ball, purchased for a small fraction of this game's cost.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												It's funny how many Paradox shills here keep reusing the same arguments."But you spent over xxxx hours on it""DLCs aren't a must, you couldn't play non-christian character X since the release of CK"CK2 has the same problem as Kerbal Space Program: The game is run by incompotent and greedy developers.There are so many flaws in how the game mechanics work and contrast to history we know IRL (see: Iqta government), yet Jewhan actually has the guts of seperating the main DLC from its music, potraits and unit models.Paying 15$ for a bunch of copy paste provinces to the south, with the information tweaked of the characters from Wikipedia? Writing a few scripts so a text with an image can come up to give you more piety? Yeah, clearly alot of effort went into these DLCs, especially if you compare them to the Warhammer mod.Also, isn't this game called 'Crusader Kings 2'? So why can't we play the other side of the crusade, unless we pay 10$ for it?Alot of people argue that this is because muslims weren't playable from the start.That's the most pathetic excuse I have ever read on Steam. So I could just release a fighting game where you can play faction x against faction y, but I charge extra so you can play faction y yourself? Even though all of the fighting moves were already in the game?You don't have to be a developer to know how easy it must've been to insert all these "new" characters and change some attributes.Summary: The developer intended to not release those unplayable religions from the start and locked them, so he could find a better date to release them as DLCs.

content:
Posted: January 19
												:TLDR:The game is unplayable, because the devs will not add UI scaling.I really love this game.  But, I can no longer play it.  Why? Because, in this game EVERYTHING is text related...  All of the vital decisions your leader must make, all of the stats of all of the characters you must manipulate, all of your armies, taxes and laws. I cannot play this game, because I cannot read it.  Without UI scaling, I cannot read this game on my monitor.  And for that reason, I cannot recommend this game.  I have over the course of years spent in excess of $100 on this game and its expansions.  FIX YOUR GAME PARADOX!

number of helpful: 20 of 38 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												I regret I sank too much time into this black hole of a game.  CK2 when everything boils down to it is essentially a university student's biology simulator but with medevil politcs survival instead of plants and animals competing.Oh it started so well, but patch after patch, dlc after dlc and the game's been shackled to a CPU load whether you bought the extras or not.  Great way to sell you the stuff because it's right there up in your face in game but after the Rajas of India expansion no one could deny the devasting effects of Paradox's business model.Today the final straw broke the camels back.  Got bored so I reinstalled to see how things went after very very long hiatus and low and behold the one and only great saving grace: Crusader Kings 2 Plus mod (CK2+) was pulled from steam workshop along with zero activity on GitHub and the others after July.  In conclusion, I may never play another Paradox game again unless it's well under.Congratulations Paradox on a job well done screwing us over!  Bravo you really went the extra mile to almost make it personal.

That'd be a 1000% improvement.I shouldn't have to rent the hubble telescope off NASA just so I have the ability to read your damn games' text.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												Every history lover must own this game . Great mechanics , historical accuracy and deep intruge system ...These are the things that makes you love the game . Of course it has some sort of bugs (such as changing your heir without a reason) but you start getting used to that after a time .Understanding the game mechanics is going to take time too but when you do you feel a great accomplishment feeling that i never felt in any other game ... My final verdict would be 8/10. Have a nice day ... (btw you might want to wait for summer sale or something like that to buy this game ... )

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												A very advanced grand strategy game. Probably my favorite slow paced strategy, the pace gives it the long tactical games of turn based strategy like Civ V but without the need to wait for other players completeing their turn since it is technically an RTS. Also the focus on having to develop your own character to get bonuses and at the same time balance it up with other people's opinion of you.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												At first i was overwhelmed by the immersion of this game. Once i took the time to figure things out though, boy i can't stop. This is a game that you can replay repeatedly and NEVER have the EXACT same game. Even if you load back to replay a part you just did there are different events that occur. I'm just in love with this game in general and would highly recommend for any Strategy fans. If you liked Civ V then you'll love this game.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												-Start a customized campaign as a Strategos in the Byzantine Empire-Make a badass looking general with a beautiful wife and two boys-Finalize an epic coat of arm-Everything is perfect and everyone is happy-Typhoid pest comes from the east and ravage the Empire-My character contracts it and dies-His wife and heir contracts it as well and both die-One child (1 years old) left as the heir of my duchy with all my subjects looking to take him down-Save the game-Ragequit-Open Steam-Start Crusader Kings II-Do it againIf you are looking for a realistic simulator about Middle Ages, this is for you. Great game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												This doesn't really compare with any other strategy game I've ever seen except for EU4. In one playthrough, starting from 867 finishing in 1452 I went from a Duke in Norway to being the Emperor of Scandinavia, having a vast portion of Europe at my control. It was a long emotional rollercoaster that lasted 70+ hours.If you're into Risk-esque game, this is for you. It's hard to get into, but once you're in you're there for good. Use YouTube tutorials as the in-game one isn't a whole lot of help.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This is a Paradox game - a probably eeriely complex strategy game, if you never heard of them before.You probably need dozens of hours to learn the game, after the tutorial, and you will lose your first games, because there is some connection between two datas you weren't aware of.To be successful, you will probably have to micromanage a lot. You should read the wiki  (www.ckiiwiki.com/Crusader_Kings_II_Wiki).If this doesnt frighten you, you can have hundreds of hours fun with this game, be it with building the biggest and baddest empire, be it with the smallest lord just to survive. It can be a challenge - if you choose the right lord -, impossible, or a walk in the park (after you learn the game, of course...).I have my fun building an empire from scratch, micromanaging everything from my family to the buildings in my demesne and conquering everything around me, as soon as I can. But this game allows a lot, so search for your own purpose in the game, and allow for the randon number generator...I love it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Good game for anyone interested in grand strategy. While the battles in the game literally consist of assigning commanders to flanks and watching the numbers of each side drop, the depth of every other aspect of the game more than makes up for that area. To be honest, with enough skill and manipulation (say, manipulating people off a balcony or over a cliff in a carriage) of other characters you could probably get away without fighting a single battle and end up with a sizeable realm.Like other Paradox grand strategy titles, this one has a particular focus: characters. CKII is much less about the lands than the people who rule them, which can make the game a challenge from beginning to end. It doesn't matter if you're the King of France if you're a new incompetent person who everyone hates! This is both a benefit and a hindrance, and make for much more interesting gaming. With one character, you might be leading Crusades and expanding your realm: a sudden death and you're fighting tooth and nail to hold onto your titles.Another good aspect is the scale. The number of characters playable, from 1066 to the 14th century, is virtually endless. This gives the game great replay value, and lower ranks like Dukes are stillvery interesting to play provided you make use of the full range of backstabbing ploys and traitorous acts available to you in various forms.The only issue I have is the prevalance of DLC, required to play groups like Muslims, Pagans and Republics. This means that in order to get the full CKII experience, you do have to stump up a lot more than the £30 original price.Overall, good game, well worth the money, excellent replay value; don't go expecting explosive action, though. The best (and worst) of CKII is hidden under the cloak, so to speak.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Where to start? My steam stats aren't helpful, because I originally owned the GamersGate version of it and only recently had it migrated to steam. Nevertheless, I would estimate that this is the single game I've played the most since its release a couple of years ago.2 important things have been the main contributors. The 'roleplaying' element is strong in this one. Taking the heritage of the original Crusader Kings, where the characters and their family relationships, rivalries and complex courts helped shaped the success of your dynasty in its rush to acquire titles, CK2 has let the concept blossom. You interact with characters - whether those in your own court and demesne or other families and title-holders, plotting against them, marrying them, sending assassins to help a title pass closer to one of your dynasty. There are lots and lots of events, random and semi-random to guide the freeform story taking place.Secondly, Paradox have a fantastic DLC/update structure in place. Supported by paid DLC of two types, they have improved the game for two years already (and going strong for more), adding new mechanics and refining old ones. Major DLC usually involved adding a category of playable characters (originally only Christian feudal rulers available), but many of the core mechanics have just gone into the patches which have been going strong all this time. Cosmetic DLC has also been good and now well-priced for a quid or so.It does take a little bit of effort to get into, and a Let's Play from youtube is highly recommend to get started, but if you're up for some personality-laden strategy, I don't know why you haven't already given this a go?!

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Arugably one of the single greatest games I've ever played.  If I had my list across genres this would be up there with Masters of Magic, Master of Orion, Civ4, Wing Commander 2, Warcraft 2, and WoW in terms of a game that just keeps bringing me back to it time and again. The replayability on this game is simply amazing.  You can play as any lord of any land in the middle ages, and if Paradox didn't put the land your looking for in there.....just Mod it to add it in!!!The modding community both from other players and even from the developers is phenomenal on this game and you absolutely MUST play the Game of Thrones and Elder Scrolls mods.You can get ahead by virtually any means possible: marriage, construction, espionage, war....you name it. This is THE game to play when you want to experience guiding a family through the ages.The learning curve is steep (I'm told, I was a CK1 vet so this was actual much easier to navigate for me), but very worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2013
												Plotting to murder your uncle, King of Bohemia, has never been more fun! CKII is a grand strategy game without any clear goals except for those you set for yourself. Take control of a mayor of minor family in medieval Europe and see how history plays out. I advise to role-play a lot and make decisions based on the traits of your character, since it will make for some "interesting" situations which will provide new challenges. It's a great improvement over CK1 in nearly every aspect, and especially concerning the interface: it might very well be the most accessible game Paradox has ever made, although the learning curve is still quite steep. Expansions are also well worth it, since they allow you to play previously unplayable factions. Also highly recommended for fans of Game of Thrones, since the politics in this game remind me a lot of those books/show (and what do you know: there is actually a GoT mod :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Crusader Kings II is one of the best strategy games ever.  I have been a fan of strategy games since the glory days of the mid 1990's, but I have not played a strategy game more than this one.  It has a fine balance of playing with politics and war that no other game has.  I love how there is no main goal for any particular playthrough, besides ensuring the survival of your dynasty.  You can choose any random area and play as that areas main character and their dynasty.  Unlike the Total War games and games like Civilization, there are no cheap moments where you can be allied with someone and then the next turn get attacked out of nowhere.  You have to have a legitimate reason for your actions in this game and more than anygame, I look forward to the fallout of mistakes I make.  I highly recommend this to anyone who is a strategy fan.  There is a bit of a learning curve, but once you understand how the game works, it is pretty awesome.

												Easily Paradox's most accessible to date. Despite this ease of access the game  is deceptively deep. A game of characters, where empires and kingdoms merely present the background; where the goals are inherently  personal, and can include merely trying to usurp a minor barony to establishing your family's hegemony over Europe.  A game where you won't blink an eye at murdering your incompetent family members, scheming rivals, and the occasional anti-pope, all in the name of "the realm." A game where marrying off  your club-footed, inbred children to lowly lords to secure their allegiance is met with much praise. Totally awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												When I first bought CKII I played it for 10 minutes after completing the tutorial, the game needless to say is most probably the most complicated game I have ever played and after watching numerous playthroughs on youtube and tutorials I felt ready to dive back into it. From my game hours you can probably see I got the hang of it finally, that's the worst thing about CKII its horrible to learn and feels like a chore at first and requires quite a bit of patience but once you get the hang of it the game is amazing. CKII is nothing like any strategy game you have played before, sure games like Total War introduce a couple of characters and familys but nothing like what CKII does having thousands of unique characters of different cultures, religions and goals makes this game what it is. I can honestly say that I have done many playthroughs of this game and each time it feels like a new fresh experience. The beauty of CKII is the fact that it doesn't force you to be huge or rich or have a brilliant military, in fact the game has nothing to do with your nation, it is about YOU. Your character, your family, your choices. Playing a minor count in ireland and marrying into the Capets, rulers of france and then killing their family until your son is the new heir to the french throne feels brilliant. Or if that's not your thing you can participate in the mass scale crusades to win back the holy land(Jerusalem) and become its new king. The huge amount of decisions the game lets you have to achieve your goals is brilliant. That's the other great thing about CKII it is YOUR goals, the game doesn't tell you what to do it leaves it all to you, do you want to conquer the world? Try. Do you want to just survive? Go ahead. In conclusion Crusader Kings II is probably the greatest strategy I have ever played to this day and I don't see that ever changing. 10/10, Plus it has a huge amount of mods to give you more replayability.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2012
												If I had to identify the major roadblock to me enjoying grand strategy titles, it is the inevitable surging creep of the game getting harder and harder to manage as the game goes on. I'm not saying this is bad for everyone, but I find it hard to enjoy a game that is actively trying to destroy everything I've built and done for the past several hours. Imagine if you had to maintain your builds in minecraft against decay.Crusader Kings II is my #1 Grand Strategy title and one of my favorite game of all time because the gameplay doesn't have the difficulty creep. From the very moment you get vassal counts to the end game where you control entire kingdoms spanning Europe, the management of your Kingdom remains more or less the same, just increasing in quantity. Instead of having to constantly deal with everything trying to collapse around you whenever you want to expand, you face the same trials you've always faced. For me, it allows both an immersive, somewhat challenging, time-consuming experience, but without the intense frustration found in similar titles.As for the positives of the game, you not only get to rule a growing realm, becoming more and more powerful and facing the changing political situation of the map year after year, but you get to play a character and his family, worrying about keeping everyone happy so they all go along with your grand vision of world conquest. The mechanics of battle are a tad simplistic, but there is more than enough to keep you occupied as you avoid river crossing and trying to find the appropriate terrain to defend on, all the while trying to occupy your enemies lands and preventing him from doing the same to you. Religion plays a major part of the game, whether you are a Christian, Muslim, Pagan, or Jew. Keeping yourself from being excommunicated or avoiding high decadence is always a challenge for the most experienced player.If you're looking for a Grand Strategy title having been frustrated with the genre for its overly challenging difficulty curve, I'd recommend CKII in a hearbeat. Perhaps not right for every gamer, it's still a fantastic title and if you are remotely interested in Grand Strategy, Management Games, or History, you should pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												Paradox are well known for their ambitious scope when it comes to making games and what experience they have at doing it too.  CK2 is certainly no exception and their best yet in my opinion.  I love the medieval world as a historical setting so for me, this makes CK2 the best game by Paradox yet.It is a true mammoth challenge that has endless possibilities.  Admittedly, the mechanics and controls are complex and take a while to getting used to but once you get your head around it, it's remarkably straightforward.  For those critics out there who say CK2 is overly complicated, may I suggest it's not the game for you for there is no way to create a game of such incredible depth without some initial complexity.  However, if you have the patience to overcome a few difficult hours of learning the ropes, then the rewards are infinite and the stories you can create are truly fantastic, funny, horrific and unforgettable.The DLC has added even greater depth and variety to an already marvellous game and the variety of Mods available are fantastic too with some notable highlights being a Game of Thrones and Elder Scrolls mod.This game certainly appeals to a certain type of gamer and won't be for everyone but if it's your kinda game, then get stuck in and say goodbye to countless hours of your life as you chart the highs and lows of your feudal characters and try to create a house to equal the Borgias!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2013
												This game is some of the most fun I've had in a long time. Speaking as someone who enjoys the total war series as well as many other strategy titles, this was a great, great buy. It's very much a strategy game (don't expect *to* much depth to the combat), with a myriad of different options available to your characters depending on how you play. Want to win via subterfuge? Then marry your sons and daughters off right assisinate off anyone in their path to the throne. Want to win via conquest? Come up with spurious claims to their territories and invade by land or sea. Gain piety and ask the pope for invasion privelege. The game is very open ended and the mods only make it even better. The latest patch (old gods) has added in looting and pillaging (and more beards) which although I haven't had much chance to play around with is great fun and an extra dimension. A great, great buy if you like strategy, with a good community behind it.*Edit* - The new expansion brough me back again after some time away and I can say that after 150+ hours invested in this game, it's one of the favourites in my library. The endless myriad of options that are presented as you play through combined with the many many different ways to play and objectives you can make for yourself make it a game you can just play again and again. 11/10, will play again :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Crusader Kings II is a very entertaining game. While actively managing and (hopefully expanding!) your nation you must  also be prepared for the future in several ways-most notably you must have an heir. Marraiges are very important and often vital to a nation's security and success. Firstly marraiges with foreign princesses or powerful nobility provide strong alliances. Additionally, your descendants may be able to pursue the claims of the spouse marrying into your dynasty, if the right conditions occur. However, you must besure to evalute the traits of a wife/husband, not just their background because marrying a character with severe defects such as slow or imbecile, can ruin a dynasty's plans for several decades.The different time periods, regions, and rulers you can play as provide a lot of variety. With paid DLC, you can play any character ruling in 769, 867, or anytime between 1066 and 1337. These characters' families can be played up until 1453. Also with the appropriate DLC, you can play as a character of any of the in-game religions. This means chacaters located from Scandanvia to India, and Mongolia to Mali. Even without any extras, you can play almost any Christian character between 1337 and 1453.While the game is complicated enough to take some getting used to, after a few hours you should be able to get the hang of it. So don't let the learning curve keep you away from the game! Besides, if you ever have questions about almost any aspect of the gameplay, information is avalibleonline-especially at the game's Wiki (<http://www.ckiiwiki.com>). If you do end up purchasing the game, different strategies and situations should be enjoyed to their fullest extent!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Crusader Kings II wasn't my first foray into Paradox's grand strategy games, but it's definitely the one that got me actually into them. The game is very intricate with many nuances, yet manages to be reasonably accessible to a new player without spending hours upon hours learning the very basics. And once you've scratched the service the game is totally addicting. It's very rare to be able to genuinely say it, but no two games of Crusader Kings II are alike.My first attempt at Paradox's games was Hearts of Iron III. It was the most appealing time era for me and one of the more recent ones at the time. But it was quite an experience for a newcomer. I played the tutorial all the way through as recommended and got a rudimentary idea of how it worked. Even after 15 hours I felt like I had no idea what was going on though. There were no graphics, there were too many units, too much going on all at once. Even if the AI could be turned on to handle details of the game you didn't care about, just one section felt like a monumentous task on its own. Everything was just a number, it was totally detached even if it was interesting. Compare that to this game, where you are just one guy. One guy. Maybe you own one county, maybe you own an empire. But in the end, the game is about your character and his family. There are plenty of decisions to be made still, but they're more top level - "What do I want to do and how do I want to do it", not three tiers down. You spend more time on the plan than the actual execution of the plan, which is what I would expect from a game that bills itelf "Grand Strategy". You're the king of the castle, the executive of the company. Knowing the intricacies of your empire works to your advantage most certainly. But it is only an aide, not a necessity to execute your plan if that shines any light into the accessibility.But that's not the only draw. The game also has character, something incredibly difficult to do with regard to faceless nations. You are your king. You live life. Good things happen. Bad things happen. You never know exactly how things will turn out. Sometimes your king will live till 50. Sometimes it'll be 70. Maybe he'll get murdered or sick. Maybe he'll abandon having an heir for a life of celibacy. Or maybe he'll go completely insane. Your king, his family, and the relationships with his vassals is a very pivotal part of the game. Bribe, manipulate, persuade, it feels just like a political position when you're in charge of a large empire. It adds a layer of immersivity that maps of Europe simply don't have. The uncertainty of life is very real in this game.If you are someone who had been turned off from Paradox's other grand strategy games I would highly recommend picking this up. There are so many different things to do and unique ways to play in the intricate simulated world of Crusader Kings II. I'm utterly hooked on this game and can see myself putting 1000 hours in it with all the DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This game feels like an almost perfect Game of Thrones game where you play as Tywin Lannister, planning and scheming on taking over control of the world.Pros: Emphasis on family breeding and conquering new lands by marriage and assassination! This game is all about developing your family, its power and influence. You carefully arrange marriages. Firstly, to ensure your heirs would get the best genes. Secondly, to install your family members on thrones in neighbouring counties, duchies and kingdoms. This takes great patience, planning, and some luck as well. Often you will have to assassinate other rulers or their heirs to achieve this. By the way you'll learn weird ways the different inheritance laws work. Why is it important to install cousins, nephews and other kinsmen on thrones in other "provinces"? Because the same family name grants you an eternal military alliance and even lets you to join your domains easier in the future (with a marriage, of course). In dynasty we trust!Also, sometimes you will have to kill your own family members, or help your sons in impregnating their wives. All to ensure the only right line of succession :)Inner working of a kingdom, with sovereigns, vassals and their warsBeside the above you will of course raise armies and battle other rulers, but its mechanics in the game are somewhat simplified. Realism is amplified by the addition of factions; you may revolt against your sovereign along with other vassals, e.g. against an inheritance law, or to install certain person on the throne.Cons:Time consuming searching for bridesThe game interface is a bit coarse, although better than in the previous installment of the series. I mostly whine about the problematic in-game search engine for characters, used mostly to find brides and grooms. It should let you specify more options for the characters you seek. Instead, you can choose some basic options, and then you have to sort through a ton of people. Probably most of the play time I spend on searching, so it is an important feature. Fortunately, it's still not able to spoil the fun of managing your dynasty :)Bugs on Linux version The game is still buggy on Linux. Some players report that disabling the launcher they implemented months ago solves the problems, some don't. Recently my game would crash to desktop every several months, without any symptoms, so I had to switch to Windows to continue playing without constant whining.DLC plague – “hey, let’s add a bunch of new functions to the game, and put each in a different lovable payable DLC!” Paradox' greatest sin is its DLC policy. Most of them are simply NOT WORTH ITS COST. They usually add one significant function to the game. The latest - Way of Life - claims to add "hundreds of new events". I bought it, played it, and highly doubt it! Before you purchase any DLC, ask on the web which are definitely worth buying!Not enough of diversified music tracksThe music tracks for different culture groups are few but very atmospheric. Although, after 200 years no matter how great they are, listhening to them just becomes tedious. Of course most of them you have to purchase in separate DLCs...Conclusion:All in all, this is a perfect idea for a game, and an imperfect implementation of that idea, though the best (and only?) one I know. You love GoT and Tywin Lannister? Quickly buy it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Crusader Kings II is a Medieval kill-all-infidels-and-die-from-the-plague-em-up, and it's a pretty solid game by itself although I would strongly reccomend getting the following DLC:The Old Gods (because everyone needs a little human sacrifice in their lives)Way of Life (because you get to seduce your sister and become a crazy fanatic possessed by the devil but that's okay because you're a master boardgamer!)Legacy of Rome (because the pope can go suck on my Byzantine nuts)Sword of Islam (because kebab is stronk (until the pope decides to attack))and maybeRajas of India (because who doesn't want control over an IT Tech Support Empire)With that said, It must be said that this game has an insane learning curve curvier than yo' mama and the tutorial won't teach you anything. The way to learn to play is by checking out some let's plays on YouTube or by simply learning for yourself.This game's strong point is with it's RPG elements and the way the story of your dynasty plays out. The objective of the game is to make sure your dynasty survives until 1453 and getting as much prestige and piety along the way. You can play as any earl/duke/king/emperor from Europe to the Sahara to the Middle East to India to Eurasia from the mid 8th century (if you have the Charlemagne DLC) to 1453. You play as one person and when said person dies you continue playing as their heir, but if your heir is not of your dynasty or you don't have one, then it's game over. A sure way of getting as many heirs as possible is by being a♥♥♥♥♥♥and legitamising as many of your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s as you see fit, however this does lead to bitter rivalries among your children.Despite trying to keep your dynasty alive, there are no real goals and this is where the RPG elements shine through. You can play as an earl and work your way up through the fuedal system to king/emperor, you can expand your lands and become king or emperor, and my favourite is playing as Byzantium and setting my sights on restoring the Roman Empire and mending the great schism (which is why you need Legacy of Rome plus some other features it adds to Byzantium). You can also plot to kill people, ♥♥♥♥ your cousin, care for your family, ♥♥♥♥ your cousin, learn the secrets of the stars, ♥♥♥♥ your cousin, and you can ♥♥♥♥ your sister!If you're a history nerd like me you will have endless fun with CKII and if you're also into the Renaissance and early Industrial Era then you should also pick up Europa Universallis IV and get a converter so your CKII save can go directly into EUIV, which is nice.10/10 - would marry my sister again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Crusader Kings 2 is what one would consider a deep end grand strategy, where to suceed one will need to learn the game system thoroughly, and the execution of advance plays will only really occur once the player has emersed themselve in countless hours of gameplay. Although it has a military style, most of the gameplay is centred around intrigue, and the tactical aspects of warfare is not explored. It focus highly personal interaction between a liege lord and its vassals, and stability and advancement depends highly on one's ability manipulate, assasinate, and plot, with the end result being reinforced through open warfare. It is a very deep game worth exploring for those who fancy themselves as strategist. A draw back to the game is the extensive amount of DLC valuing up to $160, the concept of game content has been vastly commercialised, and many producers tend to sell great games in parts. In my mind the concept of DLC should just be as the term says, downloadable content, content made by producers to improve the dynamics of the gameplay should the player choose to download it. However it should not be charged. Or content that could be unlocked via gameplay, however payable to be unlocked if the player does not have the time to pursue such a path. Considering how most of the DLC does not add significant content to the game, and it could really only be considered extra spice, it should really come as a patch. What should be charged and payable by the players are expansion packs, by definition a package which changes the gameplay signinificantly, to the point where the game does not play the same. Such a significant incremental build up can reasonably be valued to atleast half the game's retail value, a good example for this is the Sims 3 series. To conclude, Crusader King 2 is a deep strategy game for fevent strategist. However, its dynamics has been mared with improvements to game via producers coming in as payable DLC as oppose to traditional DLC which is free of charge; and is the producers way of saying thank you for joining us. Still a great game, have sunk 450 hrs, would recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												One of my favorite games. This is a strategy/history game, based on Medieval Europe. Unlike other grand strategy games, you don't  control a country, but a single character, in control of a county, duchy, kingdom, or empire, between 1066 and 1453 AD. You don't directly control much, and must manage your court, and your demesne (counties you rule), for prestige. The game is primarily spent telling armies where to go (battles are automatic; you do not control them!), engaging in diplomacy with other leaders, constant conspiracy, and marrying your sons and daughters to wealthy nobles. It's quite a good game, with extremely unique mechanics, and I imagine it would be great on multiplayer! +Great, Original Gameplay, combines Civilization with The Sims.+Political Intrigue feels Engaging and Real+Great Soundtrack-Can be Tedious at Times, Particularly Marriages-DLC is greatly overpriced.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Graphics 7/10 It's a strategy game so you are not supposed to stay zoomed in really close. From a distance I guess the graphics look satisfying but when you zoom in they don't look that good.Gameplay 9/10Crusader Kings 2 is a game about the life of a king and his dynasty. It's a pretty difficult game on different levels. When it comes to war, it can get pretty hard. When I first got the demo sometime last year, I sucked so bad at the diplomacy and war. When I got the game for Christmas last year, I got better. I would recommend that you try as a count, then a duke, and then a king. If you are terrible at war, I would suggest you focus on other goals.Replay Ability 8/10I would say that replaying the game a few times would be fun but there is one problem. You play as characters who actually existed (there is a Wikipedia link for each char) and when you play the game at a certain time there are the same characters. Changing the time could work for a little bit but you still eventually run out of choices. There is a DLC called Ruler Designer where you can customize your character but there is a problem down below.DLC and Expansion Packs 5/10Imagine buying a pizza and all what you get is just one simple cheese pizza and when you want toppings to make a variety of tastes they ask you to give several dollars. Well, that's what the problem with DLC in this game is. There is even a DLC that costs 15$ when it does not even have enough content.Modding Community 8/10The modding community is good. There are some mods that do some well adding to the game like CK+. There are some mods that crash your game or threaten to do so. Overall I would recommend some mods. I would like it if they made an extended timeline mod or infinite timeline.Game Price 6/10So this is a game that has been around for 3 years and is still $40? At this point I'd say it should be $20.Multiplayer 8/10I am more of a single player person but the multiplayer in the game is fine.Bugs/Glitches 9/10The game runs very fine. If your event holder is filled with events, it could slow down your game. AI's do tend to act weird occasionally in a way I can't explain. But try not to worry about bugs.Audio 8/10The music is good even though it gets pretty annoying after a while. The only other problem is the death scream. It's so friggin annoying. But I remember seeing a mod that replaces it with a sad violin tune. I guess everything else is okay with audioFun 9/10 (This states my opinion on the game)I really like this game it's just so addicting. I like how it's basically you are basically making your own history so I would recommend it to anyone who likes grand strategy and especially medieval history.Rating: 77/100Tip: Don't play this while someone is behind watching you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												For me, this game is perhaps the most gripping medieval political simulation I've ever played. Hours upon hours of my life have been invested in this game, estimated more than 300 hours before I converted my copy to a steam copy (gamersgate gave me a steam code for it and all the dlc I had). Deep and engaging diplomacy that requires one to have a strategy, lest your short term gains be spoiled by a disloyal vassal, jealous relative... I once even had my ideal heir murdered by my second wife so the first son I had with her could be my heir. Plot your way to the top of feudal power and entrench your dynasty in a historical sandbox. With all the DLC available that enables the player to play lords of pagan, muslim and jewish faiths, the EU IV converter DLC that allows you to take a game from the end of the dark ages to the early 19th century; this game is an absolute must own for any lover of history and political simulations, or even people looking for a empire management game with rpg elements.20/10

												Its been an uphill battle getting my friends onto this game, and I completely understand why. The amount of information tossed at you puts old school text games to shame, A very specific but overloaded UI will take you a very long time to understand all the features, and 10x longer figuring out how everything influences everything else. The claims can be very shallow, and at a certain point I stopped giving a ♥♥♥♥ about royal blood lines and it became more of a breeding sim looking for the best traits, but at the end of the day if you take your time and have patience with this game you will have countless hours of fun. I know alot of people will want to rage quit the second they die and their empire falls apart because they didnt set up heirs properly, or when they lose a duel they should of won easily, but alot of that is the charm of the game just at its worst. Worth buying if your patient enough to learn to love it.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Totally boring, not worth buying at all.In all seriousness, Crusader Kings 2 is a great game hampered by Paradox's poor DLC scheme. The base game is definitely playable and definitely still fun, but you'll be missing out on many years of content that Paradox has unfortunately locked behind a paywall. Even without the DLC, you'll find yourself saying things like "I need to kill my second son to make sure my inheritance doesn't get split!" and other things that'll make your friends think you're a psychopath.Multiplayer sessions are incredibly fun as well, though the game lacks drop-in multiplayer, necessitating a save-and-load if someone needs to join.I would highly recommend this if on sale, as the game regularly goes on sale for at least 50% off, if not more. Otherwise, it's a fortune for all the DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												If I was only able to play one game for the rest of my life it would be this game.  One of the drawbacks of grand strategy games is that they have the tendency to feel mechanical and isolated.  CK2 is one of the few games in this genre that does not suffer from this problem.  Its RPG elements put a human quality to the game.  You have a character you choose a wife, you have kids and you raise them up.  Instead of staring at numbers or faceless hordes of identical troops you are dealing with family members and rivals who have a face and a name.  That being said the game still includes a heavy elements of classic grand strategy.  You can conquer the world, and become the biggest empire.  The diference in this game instead of being loyal to a country you are loyal to a dynasty and a family.  Your motivation is not nationalistic conquest but to secure your dynasty in the world.  This mixture of elements makes for an addicting experience and one that is unique on every playthrough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												I've played about 20 hours of the regular game and... its ok I guess. I prefer Victoria 2 or EU3 honestly.What makes this game simply amazing is its potential to be modded. Crusader Kings 2 hands down has the best mods out of any Paradox grad strategy game, and I'd argue that its a top 10 contender for modded games or games to enjoy with mods.My other 300+ hours have been in the Game of Thrones mod which is simply fantastic. If you're going to play this game, you have to try that mod at some point.My only complaint of this game compared to Vicky or EU is that its much more RNG heavy. I've found myself far too often stripped of meaningful control and have my nation fall apart to one or two silly events. This simply doesn't happen in the other grand strat games- you have more control of your nation in those.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Here we go... Finally I am reviewing a grand strategy game. First off, I just want to say that this game is definitely NOT for everyone. Due to the learning curve of the genre (more on that later), this game will inevitably have haters, but this is okay. Personally, I absolutely LOVE this game. Everything about it is just simply amazing. In this review, I will talk about pretty much everything that is important about the game.	First off, let's talk about the least impressive part of Crusader Kings II: the graphics. They are decent, and do the job. The map is more detailed than in any Paradox game before this (excluding Sengoku), and is actually pleasing to look at. The models of soldiers and your council members on the map aren't too great either, but once again they get the job done. There are map modes which essentially display information to the player through colors/words on the map, and these are incredibly useful. It should also be mentioned that the interface displays a lot of information, and can be a bit overwhelming for the player.	 Now, on to the good stuff. The music is simply incredible. I love video game music, and honestly I have never heard a soundtrack like this one before. If I made a person who wasn't a gamer listen to this music, they would never guess it was from a video game. It is hard reviewing music, so just Google the soundtrack. Paradox was awesome enough to upload the whole soundtrack to YouTube for your listening pleasure, so what are you waiting for? Also, Paradox included the soundtrack in the game's Steam directory, which was incredibly kind for them to do. Before moving on to the next topic, I should also mention that the main theme is simply incredible. It plays when the game loads and on the main menu. The first time you hear it, you will inevitably get goose bumps.	While the previous things add up to an amazing experience, the most important part of any game is its gameplay. Explaining the gameplay would literally take me all day, so I will sum it up in a few sentences. Essentially, you play as a feudal lord (either a count, duke, king or emperor) in the timeline of 1066-1453 (the starting date is pushed back to 867 if you have The Old Gods expansion). Yes, the game is long, and can last for over 30 hours easily, and with all of the DLC there are over 1000 different characters on the map of Europe and a bit of Africa and Asia you can play as, all with different dynasties and play completely differently. Also keep in mind that the game has completely random events, which means that every play through is different and unique in its own way. Also, this game is a sandbox: you make your own goals. You win by essentially getting to the end date, which is  rather easy to do, so you can almost do ANYTHING. One day your wife can become pregnant randomly. If you already have a son, you might want to plot to kill your wife so that the child isn't born, and therefore cannot become jealous and kill your heir to the throne. This is just one example out of many thing that will happen to you in Crusader Kings II. Honestly, CKII is the void of ethics in almost every single way. You can either be the nicest guy possible, or can be the cruelest ruler anyone has ever seen. The possibilities are nearly endless, and you can spend hundreds upon thousands of hours in the game. At the time of this review, I only have about 30 hours in the game, but I can definitely see myself playing hundreds of hours because I feel I have barely touched the surface of this game. While all seems good so far, the game has one major flaw: the difficulty curve. I came from Europa Universalis IV (another fantastic Paradox game), which has a much easier learning curve because the tutorial is amazing, so I was able to adapt in about 5 hours. For someone that has never played a grand strategy before, learning this game will take a lot of effort and time. The in game tutorial is terrible, and the player will have to read forums and watch videos on how to play. If you want my advice, the Crusader Kings subreddit (r/crusaderkings) has a great tutorial on it, and it is the shortest one, too. If you have a friend that knows how to play the game, I am sure they would be happy to teach you how to play. One more thing I should talk about is the DLC. There is a lot of DLC for the game, and if you can I recommend buying the Crusader Kings II Collection. It doesn't actually come with all the DLC, so the important ones that you will also have to buy are The Old Gods (pushes the starting date back and allows you to play as the Pagans), Rajas of India (adds Indian nations) and Sons of Abraham (adds Jewish nations). If you have Europa Universalis IV, you should also get the save converter which allows you to easily export your game to EU4, allowing for even MORE gameplay!tl;dr - Crusader Kings II is an amazing strategy game that is will keep you hooked for hours at a time. I'd highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												The complex social kingdom world domination game!  In reality this is a deep empire builder while with a steep learning curve, it's large array of tutorials really help to get the most out of whatever social position you find yourself in.  Building your family dynasty takes time effort, and sometimes a bit of forced luck.  Definitely a keeper for the future this is the most epic strategy game for all those who love the genre, better than EU series due to the social relationship model that drives the game. Historically based before the EU timeline, and savegames can continue into the new era with EU.While cheating helps you learn the game mechanics, infinite gold will only get you so far because, now with new 'iron-mode' the game has achievements and it forces you to stop cheating.. which is fine! Because in this game the enjoyment comes from the challenge and the defeats as much as the victories.Well rounded, long playlife, this game is truely epic, historically accurate enough to keep the gameplay plausible and all new DLC a must to collect.Strong recommendation to buy, hard to disappoint if you like strategy, depth and intrigue 98/100.

content:

												This is a rich, complicated game that sits at the intersection of many rich, complicated things: centuries-long empire building, tangled soap-opera relationships, and medieval role-play. There is always something going on, always something interesting to do; as with Sid Meier's Civilization, it's hard to find a good moment at which to stop playing—despite the fact that you control time in the game. Though its setting and complexity was intimidating at first (I'd suggest you watch playthroughs and tutorials on YouTube before starting), playing CKII is engrossing, rewarding, and results in stories you want to tell others.And I've yet to run it with any of the DLC expansions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												This is one of those few game that can't get a proper trailer. Why? Because it would be like trying to convey all the back-stabbing, scheming and plotting of the whole Game of Thrones or House of Cards into 2 minutes of video.That's what this game is about: Schemes, convenience marriages, assassination, eugenetics and vengeance, all carefully lined-up over several years, even decades of in-game time (hours and hours of gameplay), most of the time to see it all crumble under a low-handed AI political movement, or an obscure medieval succession law (like the one that says "the daugther with a son takes preference over the older, son-less daugther").There is war, battles and conquest, yes, but they are reduced to a bare minimum. The important part is your excuse to go to war: You need to have a motive, such as enforcing the claim of one of your nobles over a certain duchy currently owned by a rival king. The fun comes from get your hands on nobles who have that claim, for example, bribing your rivals heirs so that they'll come to your court and marry one of your daugthers.If you like political intrigue and a non-fantasy medieval setting, you can't go wrong with this game.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												I'm someone who's not easily entertained and doesn't have fun doing much of anything. I still had fun with this game though. It simplifies doing what would be a horrifying atrocity in any other context down to a math problem of navigating game mechanics. In the tutorial, I completely ignored what I was instructed to do, killed my brothers to become the king of Leon, Castille, and Galicia, and then killed my sister's husband before seducing and marrying her. I immediately died and the realm passed to my now one year old incest baby who was able to achieve the reconquista 400 years early as well as conquering half of north Africa before he died at the age of 80. The realm was split into three following his death, but it was cool because one of the sons worshipped satan so everyone was just kind of okay with him being executed.TL;DR : Good role-play elements coupled with interesting character interactions amount to a great game where you play as a medieval dynasty. However, the DLC policy can make the pricing a bit prohibitive, definitely wait for a sale if you're wanting to buy in.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												You can probably add about 200 additional hours to the time listed on my profile. I bought this recently after having a "review" (ahem) copy for a while. What can I say that hasn't already been said? This game is like a hybridrole-playing/grand strategy game. You are roleplaying as a dynasty during the middle ages, and your goal is to...well, do whatever the hell you want to do. Want to paint the map in your country's preferred color? Check. Want to reform the Roman Empire? Check. Want to invite nobles to parties, screw their wives, and then assassinate them? Check. Want to marry your sister and sire inbred heirs? Check. There are very few things you can't do in this game, with the notable exception of declaring war on someone without a valid cassus belli. In short, the world is yours for the taking. Just don't be surprised if a giant green blob decides to alter your plans for world domination. Deus Vult!
