number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												If you're looking for a heavily detailed strategy game to get lost in, then look no further. Crusader Kings 2 is like an advanced version of Risk (advanced to a ballistic extent!) You not only have to manage the land which your dynasty controls, but the crazy politics within your own family (they will assassinate each other to further their own interests, including you!) At the same time, you have to manage many nobles fighting over land titles, all while watching your enemy dynasties, while plotting your own next move. Eventually, one way or another, your character will die. You suddenly control your new heir. How well accepted he or she will be will depend upon their traits and skills. This is why you need to marry wisely and assign your heirs (and possible heirs) to the ideal tutors. Your son could turn out to be a brilliant strategist, or a raving lunatic! You might find yourself in the position of having to assassinate your own son in order to protect your dynasty.Literally everything you do in this game involves risk, followed by clever management over the complications which result. This is a game for obsessive personalities, or otherwise those who enjoy intellectual challenges. It easily consumes your time, be warned!My only complaint, and it's not a small one, is that if you allow the game to update automatically, your saved games might suddenly be obsolete without downloading the latest beta version! This happened to be recently, and even after downloading it I still do not have access to my saved games! I spent many hours and much effort building my prolific empire, only to lose all of my progress! It's frustrating enough for me to not recommend this game! But all things said and done, I've really enjoyed this game and the makers put such effort into it that I feel this error in judgment (or glitch) should be overlooked. Still...holy crap. Whatever you do, DO DISABLE 'Updates' under 'Properties' and then be cautious when/if you should decide to update it.

												First of all let me just say that this game is the best strategy game I have ever played. No other game in which you control a civilisation or nation etc can come even close. content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Totally boring, not worth buying at all.In all seriousness, Crusader Kings 2 is a great game hampered by Paradox's poor DLC scheme. The base game is definitely playable and definitely still fun, but you'll be missing out on many years of content that Paradox has unfortunately locked behind a paywall. Even without the DLC, you'll find yourself saying things like "I need to kill my second son to make sure my inheritance doesn't get split!" and other things that'll make your friends think you're a psychopath.Multiplayer sessions are incredibly fun as well, though the game lacks drop-in multiplayer, necessitating a save-and-load if someone needs to join.I would highly recommend this if on sale, as the game regularly goes on sale for at least 50% off, if not more. Otherwise, it's a fortune for all the DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This game feels like an almost perfect Game of Thrones game where you play as Tywin Lannister, planning and scheming on taking over control of the world.Pros: Emphasis on family breeding and conquering new lands by marriage and assassination! This game is all about developing your family, its power and influence. You carefully arrange marriages. Firstly, to ensure your heirs would get the best genes. Secondly, to install your family members on thrones in neighbouring counties, duchies and kingdoms. This takes great patience, planning, and some luck as well. Often you will have to assassinate other rulers or their heirs to achieve this. By the way you'll learn weird ways the different inheritance laws work. Why is it important to install cousins, nephews and other kinsmen on thrones in other "provinces"? Because the same family name grants you an eternal military alliance and even lets you to join your domains easier in the future (with a marriage, of course). In dynasty we trust!Also, sometimes you will have to kill your own family members, or help your sons in impregnating their wives. All to ensure the only right line of succession :)Inner working of a kingdom, with sovereigns, vassals and their warsBeside the above you will of course raise armies and battle other rulers, but its mechanics in the game are somewhat simplified. Realism is amplified by the addition of factions; you may revolt against your sovereign along with other vassals, e.g. against an inheritance law, or to install certain person on the throne.Cons:Time consuming searching for bridesThe game interface is a bit coarse, although better than in the previous installment of the series. I mostly whine about the problematic in-game search engine for characters, used mostly to find brides and grooms. It should let you specify more options for the characters you seek. Instead, you can choose some basic options, and then you have to sort through a ton of people. Probably most of the play time I spend on searching, so it is an important feature. Fortunately, it's still not able to spoil the fun of managing your dynasty :)Bugs on Linux version The game is still buggy on Linux. Some players report that disabling the launcher they implemented months ago solves the problems, some don't. Recently my game would crash to desktop every several months, without any symptoms, so I had to switch to Windows to continue playing without constant whining.DLC plague – “hey, let’s add a bunch of new functions to the game, and put each in a different lovable payable DLC!” Paradox' greatest sin is its DLC policy. Most of them are simply NOT WORTH ITS COST. They usually add one significant function to the game. The latest - Way of Life - claims to add "hundreds of new events". I bought it, played it, and highly doubt it! Before you purchase any DLC, ask on the web which are definitely worth buying!Not enough of diversified music tracksThe music tracks for different culture groups are few but very atmospheric. Although, after 200 years no matter how great they are, listhening to them just becomes tedious. Of course most of them you have to purchase in separate DLCs...Conclusion:All in all, this is a perfect idea for a game, and an imperfect implementation of that idea, though the best (and only?) one I know. You love GoT and Tywin Lannister? Quickly buy it!

												I came to this game from EU4, which I adore. Both games have their strengths, EU4 as a Grand Strategy/Map painting game, CKII as a slower, more intimate killing experience. I don't recommend picking up one just because you like the other, though they do both share the same high quality I've come to expect from Paradox.I've been having a lot of fun playing the game so far, and I'm very satisfied with my purchase. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Playing with history is always fun, and with Crusader Kings II, players get a whole lot of depth into managing a slice of Europe--but with much left to the imagination.CK2 is, by far, one of the most engrossing grand strategy games. Not only is there the standard war and conquest, but CK2's intrigue system is also extremely entertaining. It's also particularly enjoyable to arrange royal marriages so that, somewhere down the line, you suddenly inherit a bunch of land and then poof: you're a Petty King. For me, the fun in CK2 isn't micromanaging your state. It's about creating a world within your head with characters whose fates are in the hands of the game.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Playing cooperative Crusader Kings II is like sitting down with your friends to play Let's Pretend. It's an endless gold mine of interesting stories, amusing decisions, and surprise events. The learning curve is very steep as far as normal game standards go, but there are lots of good learning resources online, and once things click, the experience is very rewarding.CK2 is enjoyable when played solo, but play it with friends if you can. You'll never know how entertaining it is to tell the story of your character's pilgrimage to Mecca until you actually do it. Leave your son under your friend's tutelage and get ready for some horror stories about how he's bringing up the child. This game serves up the drama like nobody's business.It's amazing and very, very entertaining. Highly recommended.

Instead of dying heroicly and letting his son take over, he actualy survived and gained the trait "maimed" and "incapable". My king now sits on his throne drooling and staring vacantly ahead while my Spymaster, who happens to be a deceitful hedonist and a hunchback, is helping himself to my titles...Man, I love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												A truly brilliant game.Ive spent over 250+ hrs and most of that spent playing as the duchy of yorkshire, being the proud yorkshire man i am. CKII, unlike many strategy games, is more about the legacy you leave behind. one minute your the Duke of York the next you ascend the throne of England itself. just as your getting comfortable the the pope calls a crusade and being the good catholic, you raise your banners and take 10,000 troops to the holy lands, after much blood shed and death you win through and are granted the crown of jerusalem...... you hand out the hard won titles, retaining the best for your own family. A year later it all changes, your assassinated (by who knows), your son is too young to rule, and thus recieves a relationship penalty with your vassals, they do mot like weak rulers. civil war breaks out. a jihad is called and your far flung kingdoms are under siege. you loose your foreign conquests unable to defend them, you loose your crown of England, and your duchy is taken..... your left with a single county...... but always ready to react, to rebuild, to take revenge you bide your time for the next bout of turmoil.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This game is big. I mean, it is huge. If you are worried it has too much for your liking, you are quite probably right. But then again, as individuals, we are known to acquire tastes that we might not first envision having and that is actually a nice thing; it keeps our experience of life fresh.CKII is one of my acquired tastes. My strategy background is basically age of empires and warcraft. I never really liked the concept of games that give you a big schematic map, to mess around with abstract numbers and statistics to guide your empire. I always liked the rather personal, down-and-dirty action of RTS and the hability to arrange buildings and troops in creative ways aligned to my aesthetical likings. I have never played a game like Civ, because turns+maps really seemed to take away everything I actually liked about strategy games. I, rather inadvertently, started to enjoy some of the more "abstract" strategy games through the Total War series. I bought it because of the real time battles and never really intended to play the campaigns due to the turn based quality of it. Only after I finally lost interest on the general purposeless quick battles I begun to play a grand campaign just to give my battles some meaning and, what can I say; I actually begun to enjoy the turn based genre almost as much as the RTS of my childhood. When I first learned about CKII I wasn't very sure about playing a game without any real time battles and troop commanding I  grew up with. To jump head-on on a game that was pure number-crunching (in my opinion at the time) was more akin to a leap of faith. I really only bought the game because it was medieval and I like all things medieval; so why not give it a try, I thought. How happy I am I did.Yup, the game is pure map view, no real time battles (not in a AOE or Total War sense) and no little units to order around building things, but it is still one of the most personal, immersing and satisfying experiences I ever had with a game. How Paradox Interactive managed to do that is no short of pure genius. You do not play as some god-like ruler who wills something into existence, rather, you play as character on a world full of similar characters with all sorts of aspirations, ideas and skills. You are guiding not a nation, but your estate and your family through a very dramatic time in history where everything could be lost with badly arranged marriage. You will feel like some medieval Godfather, looking out for your family  (dynasty) and making decisions that most of the time will get some of the members angry at you, but all in the greater interest of kingdom and your dynasty. Its not a game where you loose your capital and you loose, or where they kill you and game over. It is a game where, wherever someone with your blood is alive, there is a chance that you can build everything from scratch; provided you are cunning enough. It is this focus on individual characters and their traits that make the game so personal and immersing. It is not uncommon to actually feel good when your heir is a very skilfull administrator to continue guiding the empire after your demise, nor it is unheard of people actually making some serious soul-searching after murdering digital babies in order to inherit someone elses kindgom due to lack of heirs.Bottom line is: the game is huge, it is overwhelming at first and visual panache is not its thing. If you are looking for something other than that, do buy this game and give it an honest chance. It is quite probable that you will play nothing else for some good 40 hours after things really get going and you are totally absorved by all the intrigue, plots and political chaos this rich virtual medieval europe throws at you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												So when I first played this game, I had no idea what I was doing. But I carried on and picked things up as I played and it started getting good. I got this for quite cheap and the DLC for much cheaper when they went on sale and it gives you so much choice for who to play as in the world. (One thing that I don't like about the character creation is how limiting it can be with the +/- factors, it'd be best to only put the cap on if you wanted to play Ironman mode). But what I like is that there's always something going on in the world, and that all the little decisions you make can come back to stab you in the back, and how each individual person has their own agenda and how some much is interlinked, it's really not as hard as you think once you play a short while, you can always look at a let's play on youtube or something like that too if you're still stuck. It's really weird to watch history unfold differently, like Norway fending off William of Normandy for the English throne, the Byzantine Empire expanding into Eastern Europe and even to Africa and watching the Norse take over Scotland, Ireland and Wales; every game is different, as is every character. There's some great high's in this game, like reforming a heretic or pagan religion, establishing a new kingdom or empire, winning a huge civil war and watching neighbours get torn apart whilst you just take what you want from them, but there's also lows, like being raided, your own children trying to kill you, dangerous factions in your realm and ambitious neighbours. But, you gotta take it how it comes in this game and deal with it as best as you can, one day you'll have finally pleased all your vassals and united your lands and everything's good, then you die from depression. Boom. You're the 6 year old girl that inherited your fathers throne and you've got vassals eyeing up your lands and wanting independence and you've gotta get it sorted before the ultimatium letters arrive. There's also a tonne of really great mods on the workshop and online, like Lord of the Rings, The Elder Scrolls and Game of Thrones that turn it into literally a huge DLC. You can even name your children and holdings to whatever you want. Can't say I've played any other game that lets you imprison a new born baby or blind an old woman ;D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												Out of all the Paradox games -- this one is probably the most creative. Sometimes playing HOI or EU, I do wonder about the people, technically, guiding my world, what they're like, what they're up to and this game is a near-perfect, like, perfect iteration of that -- only in Medieval times. The gameplay concept is so good because it's so true. Commonly in history, it's really only a handful of people that actually steer where all of this goes --and the strings, both overt and covert, that pull them in all directions-- you play all of that. The politics, religious interactivity, the wars of all kinds: petty sucession disputes to all-out, globe-spanning Crusades/Jihads  -- and all the day-to-day stuff any person could find themselves involved with: decadence, love and romance, raising children, making friends and killing said-children so your preffered heir reaches the throne...normal stuff -- all of this is rolled together in one of Paradox's most impressive games to date.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												Paradox are well known for their ambitious scope when it comes to making games and what experience they have at doing it too.  CK2 is certainly no exception and their best yet in my opinion.  I love the medieval world as a historical setting so for me, this makes CK2 the best game by Paradox yet.It is a true mammoth challenge that has endless possibilities.  Admittedly, the mechanics and controls are complex and take a while to getting used to but once you get your head around it, it's remarkably straightforward.  For those critics out there who say CK2 is overly complicated, may I suggest it's not the game for you for there is no way to create a game of such incredible depth without some initial complexity.  However, if you have the patience to overcome a few difficult hours of learning the ropes, then the rewards are infinite and the stories you can create are truly fantastic, funny, horrific and unforgettable.The DLC has added even greater depth and variety to an already marvellous game and the variety of Mods available are fantastic too with some notable highlights being a Game of Thrones and Elder Scrolls mod.This game certainly appeals to a certain type of gamer and won't be for everyone but if it's your kinda game, then get stuck in and say goodbye to countless hours of your life as you chart the highs and lows of your feudal characters and try to create a house to equal the Borgias!

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												As an avid fan of grand strategy games, this is the one i would recommend to get if you are new to the genre. To me Crusader Kings II is a game about creating interesting stories. I'll elaborate:The most interesting moments in this game usually are so random and unexpected, that when you tell other people who play CK2 they will be genuinely interested and intrigued by them. It really feels like anything and everything can happen. It is total chaos. Sometimes EVERYTHING goes wrong, for instance your heir turns out to be an ugly midget homosexual who inherits the Holy Roman Empire and everyone hates him so much that the Holy Roman Empire just falls apart. Learning curve wise it is a lot simpler than the EU franchise or god frobid, Hearts of Iron, but i feel that speaks more to the complexity of other grand strategies. It will stil take your at least a week to get most of the mechanics down. It might even take longer. This leads to the final part of my review - the expansions. This game features a plethora of great expansions that truly change the pase of the game. They add more interesting mechanics and make the game even more interesting, . I'd recommend getting the entire shebang of major expansions as a bundle when it's on sale. It's definitely worth it. Overall i think this is a great game and it gets even better when you play with friends. If you like complex strategy games and empire management, i think you will love this. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												As far as grand strategy games go, it's hard to beat Crusader Kings II. The scope, replayability, and emergent narrative are the best in genre, bar none.The base game allows you to start in 1066 or later. When you start, you will select a character of Count, Duke, King, or Emperor level. Difficulty varies by the specific situation that your chosen character begins with; the game can become extraordinarily difficulty, or very easy based on how many vassals/hostile neighbors/raiders/hordes you'll have to face.The basic gameplay consists of making decisions about your dynasty (marriage, murder, education, etc), managing your holdings (cities, temples, castles), politicking (gaining positions of prestige, arranging political marriages and alliances, placating vassals), and making war (pressing your claims, participating in Holy Wars/Crusades, fending off raiders.)Each of the above systems forms part of the mosiac that you will paint with your characters through the generations. When your character dies, you will hopefully have an heir with which to continue your dynasty; you will then play as your heir, and so on... for several hundred years.The game's pace is somewhat slow - you'll spend years arranging marriages, fabricating claims, and gathering strength to press those claims. Your armies will take time to move from place to place via land or sea. You will need to think at least two steps ahead and put the pieces in place for the coming years, and generations, so that your dynasty can rise to greatness.Map control isn't the end-all, be-all of this game; rather, the specific decisions, maneuvering, and exploits of your family are. If you want detailed battles, like Total War, this is not the game for you: combat is largely abstracted into troop types (light infantry, heavy infantry, archers, light cavalry, heavy cavalry, special units), their moral, their commanders, and the terrain on which you are fighting. Once a battle has begun, your only real choice is whether or not to attempt to retreat (usually a bad idea.) Combat takes place in real-time, and can take several days of in-game time to resolve.Notes on some of the DLC that I own:-Charlemagne: Brings the start date back to 769; this is a lower-tech beginning compared to the standard 1066 start date. This allows you to create custom kingdoms and empires. Highly Reccommend.-The Old Gods: Allows you to start in 867. If you want to play a badass pagan viking, this is the start for you. Highly Recommend.-Legacy of Rome: A Byzantine Empire-focused DLC pack that introduces more events, allows the restoration of the Roman Empire, and mending of the Schism. Most importantly, it enables retinues across all factions - these are standing, professional armies. Highly recommend.-Way of Life: Allows you to make more life-choices for your current character as you play. Highly recommend it.-Horse Lords: Allows you to play nomadic steppe peoples. Makes the Silk Road a factor. Moderately recommend.-Sons of Abraham: More Holy orders, more religion based events. Moderately recommend.-Sunset Invasion: Aztecs invade you late in the middle ages. Can be interesting, but not a common choice among the community.There are dozens of unit packs, portrait packs, heraldry packs, and music packs. I recommend the specific versions of these for the faction you're playing, if you want immersion.All in all, Crusader Kings 2 is one of the most polished, engrossing, and interesting grand strategy games I've ever played. It really is a Game of Thrones simulator (and there's even a Game of Thrones mod available if that's your flavor.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Crusader Kings II is a very entertaining game. While actively managing and (hopefully expanding!) your nation you must  also be prepared for the future in several ways-most notably you must have an heir. Marraiges are very important and often vital to a nation's security and success. Firstly marraiges with foreign princesses or powerful nobility provide strong alliances. Additionally, your descendants may be able to pursue the claims of the spouse marrying into your dynasty, if the right conditions occur. However, you must besure to evalute the traits of a wife/husband, not just their background because marrying a character with severe defects such as slow or imbecile, can ruin a dynasty's plans for several decades.The different time periods, regions, and rulers you can play as provide a lot of variety. With paid DLC, you can play any character ruling in 769, 867, or anytime between 1066 and 1337. These characters' families can be played up until 1453. Also with the appropriate DLC, you can play as a character of any of the in-game religions. This means chacaters located from Scandanvia to India, and Mongolia to Mali. Even without any extras, you can play almost any Christian character between 1337 and 1453.While the game is complicated enough to take some getting used to, after a few hours you should be able to get the hang of it. So don't let the learning curve keep you away from the game! Besides, if you ever have questions about almost any aspect of the gameplay, information is avalibleonline-especially at the game's Wiki (<http://www.ckiiwiki.com>). If you do end up purchasing the game, different strategies and situations should be enjoyed to their fullest extent!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Good game for anyone interested in grand strategy. While the battles in the game literally consist of assigning commanders to flanks and watching the numbers of each side drop, the depth of every other aspect of the game more than makes up for that area. To be honest, with enough skill and manipulation (say, manipulating people off a balcony or over a cliff in a carriage) of other characters you could probably get away without fighting a single battle and end up with a sizeable realm.Like other Paradox grand strategy titles, this one has a particular focus: characters. CKII is much less about the lands than the people who rule them, which can make the game a challenge from beginning to end. It doesn't matter if you're the King of France if you're a new incompetent person who everyone hates! This is both a benefit and a hindrance, and make for much more interesting gaming. With one character, you might be leading Crusades and expanding your realm: a sudden death and you're fighting tooth and nail to hold onto your titles.Another good aspect is the scale. The number of characters playable, from 1066 to the 14th century, is virtually endless. This gives the game great replay value, and lower ranks like Dukes are stillvery interesting to play provided you make use of the full range of backstabbing ploys and traitorous acts available to you in various forms.The only issue I have is the prevalance of DLC, required to play groups like Muslims, Pagans and Republics. This means that in order to get the full CKII experience, you do have to stump up a lot more than the £30 original price.Overall, good game, well worth the money, excellent replay value; don't go expecting explosive action, though. The best (and worst) of CKII is hidden under the cloak, so to speak.

												The game is great.  Prepare to spend countless hours trying to figure it out but once you do the game becomes amazing and offers a unique experience each time you play. Its a great game and can be found in a bundle pack for a good price.  Paradox keep up the good work.

												I'm someone who's not easily entertained and doesn't have fun doing much of anything. I still had fun with this game though. It simplifies doing what would be a horrifying atrocity in any other context down to a math problem of navigating game mechanics. In the tutorial, I completely ignored what I was instructed to do, killed my brothers to become the king of Leon, Castille, and Galicia, and then killed my sister's husband before seducing and marrying her. I immediately died and the realm passed to my now one year old incest baby who was able to achieve the reconquista 400 years early as well as conquering half of north Africa before he died at the age of 80. The realm was split into three following his death, but it was cool because one of the sons worshipped satan so everyone was just kind of okay with him being executed.TL;DR : Good role-play elements coupled with interesting character interactions amount to a great game where you play as a medieval dynasty. However, the DLC policy can make the pricing a bit prohibitive, definitely wait for a sale if you're wanting to buy in.

Posted: January 17, 2016
												Crusader Kings II. A game that perfectly combines Strategy and RPG together. Whether you'd like to start out as a petty king of Wales, or a sheikh of a Muslim caliphate- (DLC's may be needed unfortunately), this game is very intriuging and fun with every one of your actions having a knock-on effect that could affect you later on in the game. Though I sometimes struggle to expand out of my tiny county in France, the game has a very ambitious and exciting atmosphere, with all sorts of likely scenarios coming face to face with you. Whether a traveller from the far east, or a request from the King of Castille asking for your daughters hand, or even needing to bring up children in the way you may see fit, every single choice will cause a consequence, whether good or bad.Sometimes you have to stick around and wait for something to happen, but in the meantime I tend to arrange my childrens marriages and education as well as send gifts and my councillers on various missions across the known world. I am still learning about the game and the new possibilities I could undertake, but in the past 3 weeks, I have played under different titles in the known world and made different choices and characters in each one. Let me explain more, you can create your own council, deploy armies and arrange marriages and education and even choose to imprison or assassinate somebody, when you grow more powerful you can remove "Duke" and plant in "King" and eventually.. "Emperor". You can create alliances or enemies, choose what to do with people and even banish or execute them, the game has a vast amount of decisions and possibilities which I am still discovering every time I play this game again. Do I recommend this game? Yes, but it depends on your likes and interests. If you're a fan of medieval European/Middle Eastern history as well as strategic thinking, you will enjoy this creation. Thank you for reading my review and decide what you think. Good day/night ladies and gentlemen.Deus Vult!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												This is a game about Iteration.If you like attempting a process/workflow, seeing the results and then trying to do it again but better than this game is for you.I say this because I work for a tech company, love my job, and see a mirror of what I do at work in this game - only it's much more fun!  This is a developer's game.This game has many layers - you will not understand everything.  The idea is actually that you don't.  The devs want you to react to what happens from an emotional standpoint and the game will respond in a way that actually makes sense.Want to be an awesome Barbarrian King and conquer the world?  Go ahead!  Oh, you died and now are playing as your spoiled son?  Will the bloodthirsty, barbarian generals your father put in power respect and obey you?  I highly doubt it.  Maybe next time you'll arrange for one of those generals to be your heir insted.After nearly 1400 hours logged into this game I can say it is the best gaming investment I've ever made.  Their are hundreds of starting locations and each one has different nuances that you will only learn through trial and error until you get to whatever you consider perfection.  Even when you achieve what you consider perfection you will look back at that playthrough and realize countless mistakes you could fix the next time around.My adivce on playing this game is to start with the western religions, then india, then the middle east, and finailly the tribal religions.  This will progress your learning of the game in a stable way and also present ever increasing challenges.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												I have played an inordinate amount of this game. If you like Civ and like diplomacy with lots of other nations and like shifting maps, then this is a great buy. The combat isn't great and the interface is horrifically unintuitive due to the complexity of the game. You need to invest time up front to lose a couple of two hour games to learn what the heck you're supposed to be doing at any point, but once you do, you find one of the deepest and most rewarding games out there.Immense amounts of fun to scheme against others, get involved in or suppress civil wars, arrange marriages, attempt to mentor and breed good traits into your kids, and grow as a county/duchy/nation/empire. Huge amounts of fun just to see what the rest of the world gets up to on its own, far away from you. Different cultures and religions play quite differently from one another, which adds to the replay. It's fun to keep large countries or empires from fracturing, which keeps the game engaging even after you are larger than your rivals in the world.Lots of additional content makes for a fun game, but it's preposterously expensive as a whole. Wait for it to go on deep discount, as it does at least every time that a new expansion is released, and you'll get more than your money's worth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Crusader Kings 2 is a dynastic family simulator set in the middle ages and is a game that gets incedibly complex very quickly. The game has a steep learning curve, so only buy if you are prepared to spend a few hours learning the game. The game has a lot of DLC, but Pardox's DLC policy is pretty good. Each major DLC release accompanies a major patch which includes some features present in the DLC. In addition, in multiplayer, everyone connected to the host will have access to the same features present on the DLC active on the host, ex: My friend connects to me, I have Old Gods active and he doesn't, He has access to the Old Gods features. By default you can play as a Christian (both Catholic and Orthodox) landowner, or even a vassal of a land owner. Muslim and Pagan rulers are locked behind DLC becasue they are mechanicly different in many ways. DLC I would recomend:Sword of Islam (If you want to play as a Muslim, if not don't bother)Legacy of Rome (Retinue!)The Republic (Republics!)The Old Gods (Earlier Start Date, Pagans)If you like complex, historicly theamed games set in the middle ages, I would recomend. If not then this isn't for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This game is a prime example of the type of game that requires you to earn your fun. The game's mechanics, while not entirely inaccessible, require a lot of learning to truly understand, but once you have a firm grasp of the game's mechanics it's by far the most amazing medieval strategy sandbox out there, with lots of potential not only for conquest and expansion but also for emergent narrative and role-play. Unlike many other grand strategy games, the game gives its various characters a lot of personality, so you're not only playing the expansion of a dynasty but getting to engage with each of your dynasty members on a personal level.If you like strategy games, this is a must have. The opportunity cost of needing to learn its mechanics is totally worth it.

												This is the sort of game where you sit down figuring you'll play a gimmick character for a few years just to see how things shake out, only to wake up from a daze realizing it's 50 years and several real-time hours later, you're the viking merchant prince of the Irish republic, you've sacrificed at LEAST a dozen people to Odin, you've raided the British countryside so often you've got frequent♥♥♥♥♥♥and-pillage miles, you have a growing monopoly on trade in the north, your son won't stop plotting to kill you, Scotland has been created and destroyed from rebellions about five times, that jackass neighbor with the prime coastline cities still won't die so you can take advantage of the inevitable succession crisis, the East and West Frankish empires have somehow switched places from all the coup attempts, you've erected a runestone declaring how huge your♥♥♥♥♥♥♥is, and you're still on your first ruler.If that sounded like your type of game, this game will devour your spare time if you get past the learning curve, which, while not insignificant, is easily the most accessible of any of Paradox's games. The DLC is mostly cheap portrait and song packs, with the main DLCs giving access to factions the massive patches that came with them overhauled. I'd wait for a big if you want to snatch up most of the DLC, but if you REALLY like the sound of one they're almost all worth full price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												Crusader Kings II is a grand strategy. Let my stress the word "grand." This game requires investment. Not just a monetary investment, but the investment of your time. Its a game that will take quite a long time to learn, let alone master. But in Crusader Kings II, is one of the richest, and deepest grand strategy experiences in a video game of all time. In Crusader Kings 2 you play as an individual during a year of your choosing, I believe anywhere from 866 AD to around 1499, plotting for more power in a Medieval Court, Game of Thrones style. The game is riddled with depth and intrigue, and you're going to have to be willing to get your hands dirty if you want to make it to the proverbial top of the pile. Did I say get your hands dirty? I meant filthy. You're going to have to do some heinous, treacherous things if you want to end up at the top. You can't really trust anyone - not even your own flesh and blood in this one. You may have fathered good ol' Johnny for 19 years, but Johnny is rather ambitious, and will take you out of the spotlight if it means he can have his spot at the throne. It's ruthless.Crusader Kings II is a game where you can send your brother to his death atop the sands of Syria by the hands of Jihadists, bang his grieving wife, make her bare your children, and then plot the murder of the little runts too. Oh, and you get to secretly arrange plots against people you don't like, get everyone else in on it, and then pull a Gaius Julius Caesar-esque everyone-run-up-and-collectively-stab-Henry-to-death type of thing. It's a great game, and if you have the time and effort to invest into it, I suggest you purchase it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This game is honestly one of my favorite games of all time. Keep in mind the fact that I like history more than the average person, and I love this kind of game. If you like constant action, it might not be the best choice. But the amazing thing about this game is that it has the ability to make you amazing with some of the best traits, then you have a daughter that is an imbecile, ugly, club-footed, and has a hunchback. It is capable of keeping you interested and constantly interacting with one or more features in the game. For example, one play through I started as a count in Ireland, which in the game is probably the easiest spot to start for beginners (Not much happens so you have time to adjust things and learn the game to a point where you are comfortable). As this count in Ireland, I expanded my one county into a duchy, which is an even greater title and provided me with a lot of happiness and wealth. But then, my half-brother decided to call a revolt, saying he should be in control of the duchy. I went to war and lost, and he ended up throwing me in the darkest deepest dungeon possible (I still kept one county, which I was suprised about, seeing as he wanted to kill me) When in this dungeon, I contracted typhoid fever, and my brother decided to put me on house arrest. My youngest son randomly broke me out, and I went back to my county. I had married off my daughters, and at the time my allies couldn't help with the revolt my brother called on me. So I decided enough was enough, and declared war. Scotland, Mercia, and Wessex came down with their armies (Which to me at the time was a very huge amount of men) And we decimated my brother. I regained my throne, and began raising troops. I took my army to war against the rest of the single counties, seeing as I had lost a large amount of my life to the dungeon. I took enough land (80% of the Kingdom of Ireland) to create the kingdom. As soon as I made it, I passed away. My oldest son took over the majority of my kingdom, while the duchy went to my youngest (Still in the same country). Being a new character (My oldest son) I decided it was time to expand the kingdom I had made. I fought until I reached scotland, killed my sister to end the alliance, and then declared war and took it. I had so much power, that I wanted to make the Empire of Britannia to match how I felt. I did exactly that, and became the Emperor. However, after some time of ruling the Empire, a foreign country wanted my land, so we went to war. I had over half the amount of troops he had (At least I thought I did) and I felt extremely confident I was going to prevail. Little did I know that the Emperor of the HRE didn't like me. I didn't know the reason, until I saw that he was the previous king of Scotland, and his father was the Emperor of the HRE before me. So now I was facing a 10k+ army included with the 4k coming from another country. They killed my army instantly, all of my land was sieged and burnt, and my children and siblings were all arrested and died from disease. I had nothing after so long that I actually felt a real anger building. It was the first time in a long time a game had brought emotion so real into my heart. That is when I realized how good this game was. It is so amazing, it is able to upset you, but at the same time bring happiness and satisfaction when you destroy your enemies. You can call Jihads as the Caliph of Islam, you can join crusades for the holy sites in the world, you can rule or be ruled. So many opportunities in this game, and all of them bring good or bad feelings. Oh, and about my story, my character ended up being excommunicated by the pope, and I was assassinated.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Crusader Kings 2 is an epic Strategy game where you play as a family of characters to develop and expand your kingdom. This game is heaps of fun, with friends and by yourself because the RPG elements of your character, that combine marvelously with historical events, as well as building and expanding your kingdom into a medieval power! The game is also complex, and the research that went behind it is amazing. Different cultures, religions, customs, make the game rich in diversity and alot of fun.Overall, the best game I have in my Steam library :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												The greatest "Grand Strategy" game ever produced. It doesn't exist a game which achieves this quality, historical reference and complexity.I played it more than 1'100 hours and I'm far away to get tired of playing Crusader Kings II and I'm very far away of having played all the interesting kingdoms, clans or religions. Each game differs so much from the last one. The dynasty mustn't die out - to marry the right wife is essential in order of a successor and strategic alliances. Subordinated nobility aspires as much my crown as legitimated successors or relatives. Where is the greatest danger? A rising neighbour, the  superior mussulmans, the mongolian horsemen, a more and more powerful subordinate, a second wife, who prefers her son as successor instead of the first ones, maybe an intrigeur who has already started an assassination in order to achiev his political goals? Fortunately I have my counsellors - but can I really trust them or are they already involved in a complot against me?? There exist much more aspects.It's not always easy to locate the risks - everything can change from one day to the other. This are medieval times. And if I loose my crown I'm the one, among other rivals, who aspires it...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												I have played an inordinate amount of this game. If you like Civ and like diplomacy with lots of other nations and like shifting maps, then this is a great buy. The combat isn't great and the interface is horrifically unintuitive due to the complexity of the game. You need to invest time up front to lose a couple of two hour games to learn what the heck you're supposed to be doing at any point, but once you do, you find one of the deepest and most rewarding games out there.Immense amounts of fun to scheme against others, get involved in or suppress civil wars, arrange marriages, attempt to mentor and breed good traits into your kids, and grow as a county/duchy/nation/empire. Huge amounts of fun just to see what the rest of the world gets up to on its own, far away from you. Different cultures and religions play quite differently from one another, which adds to the replay. It's fun to keep large countries or empires from fracturing, which keeps the game engaging even after you are larger than your rivals in the world.Lots of additional content makes for a fun game, but it's preposterously expensive as a whole. Wait for it to go on deep discount, as it does at least every time that a new expansion is released, and you'll get more than your money's worth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Crusader Kings II is maybe the finest, most in-depth grand strategy game I have played. It brings the usual Paradox level of detail to the medieval age. The game itself takes place between the mid 11th and late 15th centuries, though the Old Gods expansion pushes that range wider, by providing an alternate starting date at the middle of the 9th century.I called CK2 a grand strategy game above, but it would be more accurate to call this game a dynasty simulator. You will play not as a nation, but a medieval ruler. You can start low as a count or high as an emperor, the end goal is the same: ensure the prosperity of your dynasty through diplomacy, intrigue and conquest. You can play as virtually any noble of medieval europe from the rank of count all the way to kings and emperors. Ever wanted to see if you can unite the world under the banner of Iceland? Well.. here is your chance to see.Victory and defeat are a little different in this game. You might start out as a king and have your brother knock you from your throne. In other games, this would mean you lost. In CK2 it merely means, that you are now a mere duke, or count, depending on your other titles. Don't make the mistake of thinking this game to be easy however. While it is hard to "lose" in the classical sense (the only way to do that is to lose all titles OR have no valid heirs - leading to the end of your dynasty), it also takes both skill, cunning and luck to "prosper" in the medieval ages.So what are you waiting for? Grab the game and start building that empire.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I don't know that the English language is deep enough to properly heap the praise upon this game that it truly deserves. The replayability is phenomenal, the stategy is incredibly deep and involving, and there are literally too many ways to play the game for me to list them without writing a novel. My friend plays the game like a geneticist, trying to breed the perfect ruler. I play the game constantly trying to spread whatever religion I'm playing, because it's obviously the only true religion.With hundreds of playable characters and hundreds of different ways to play, I can see myself playing this for thousands and thousands of hours before I get bored of it. Heck, look at how much I've played already. Download this game, download the six important expansions (Ruler Designer, Sword of Islam, Legacy of Rome, The Republic, The Old Gods, Sons of Abraham) and then decide how you want to play! Conquer the world? Have one of your children elected Pope? Mend the Great Schism in the Christian Church? Establish the Jewish nation of Israel? That's just a tiny little bit of what you can do in Crusader Kings, and I can't recommend this enough!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I've been playing this game for around 2 years at this point, and its endless expansions and countless possibilities keep me coming back time after time. Some of the stories that I've vicariously lived through playing Crusader Kings II have been incredible - the 74 year long dynasty of a father who assassinates his brothers to unite a kingdom, only for that kingdom to crash and break upon his death, leaving it in the hands of three young sisters - his daughters - who go on to relive their fathers' legacy; each one plotting to kill the other in the name of uniting the kingdom once more.That time when all of England was Norway. When all of France was England. When half of Europe was the Aztec empire, or, the time that I reunited Portugal through diabolical scheming, assassination attempts and intrigue in bucketloads.I've recently got into modding CK2, as well, and although slightly daunting at first, it is relatively comprehensive to tinker around with. I've yet to complete a mod; however have had fun poking around in the game engine to create my own (non-canon) religion and set up various event strings. A must for any modder.Get this game, you won't regret it. If you are not familiar with the complex nature of Paradox games, do go through the tutorial and do read forum guides; you'll get a lot more out of it. I look forward to seeing what comes next! Thank you, Paradox!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This game feels like an almost perfect Game of Thrones game where you play as Tywin Lannister, planning and scheming on taking over control of the world.Pros: Emphasis on family breeding and conquering new lands by marriage and assassination! This game is all about developing your family, its power and influence. You carefully arrange marriages. Firstly, to ensure your heirs would get the best genes. Secondly, to install your family members on thrones in neighbouring counties, duchies and kingdoms. This takes great patience, planning, and some luck as well. Often you will have to assassinate other rulers or their heirs to achieve this. By the way you'll learn weird ways the different inheritance laws work. Why is it important to install cousins, nephews and other kinsmen on thrones in other "provinces"? Because the same family name grants you an eternal military alliance and even lets you to join your domains easier in the future (with a marriage, of course). In dynasty we trust!Also, sometimes you will have to kill your own family members, or help your sons in impregnating their wives. All to ensure the only right line of succession :)Inner working of a kingdom, with sovereigns, vassals and their warsBeside the above you will of course raise armies and battle other rulers, but its mechanics in the game are somewhat simplified. Realism is amplified by the addition of factions; you may revolt against your sovereign along with other vassals, e.g. against an inheritance law, or to install certain person on the throne.Cons:Time consuming searching for bridesThe game interface is a bit coarse, although better than in the previous installment of the series. I mostly whine about the problematic in-game search engine for characters, used mostly to find brides and grooms. It should let you specify more options for the characters you seek. Instead, you can choose some basic options, and then you have to sort through a ton of people. Probably most of the play time I spend on searching, so it is an important feature. Fortunately, it's still not able to spoil the fun of managing your dynasty :)Bugs on Linux version The game is still buggy on Linux. Some players report that disabling the launcher they implemented months ago solves the problems, some don't. Recently my game would crash to desktop every several months, without any symptoms, so I had to switch to Windows to continue playing without constant whining.DLC plague – “hey, let’s add a bunch of new functions to the game, and put each in a different lovable payable DLC!” Paradox' greatest sin is its DLC policy. Most of them are simply NOT WORTH ITS COST. They usually add one significant function to the game. The latest - Way of Life - claims to add "hundreds of new events". I bought it, played it, and highly doubt it! Before you purchase any DLC, ask on the web which are definitely worth buying!Not enough of diversified music tracksThe music tracks for different culture groups are few but very atmospheric. Although, after 200 years no matter how great they are, listhening to them just becomes tedious. Of course most of them you have to purchase in separate DLCs...Conclusion:All in all, this is a perfect idea for a game, and an imperfect implementation of that idea, though the best (and only?) one I know. You love GoT and Tywin Lannister? Quickly buy it!

content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												Crusader Kings II does a great job of creating adicting stratagy in a very realistic medieval setting. You start with a map of Europe, Asia, and North Africa, and choose and lord from count or earl to emperor.  Many of the possible choices are based on real historical char. The game spans the life of the char, and hundreds of years of heirs. The combat is simulated, but the game is so deep overall that it makes up for it in a ton of other ways. Also there is some great mods for it such as the Game of Thrones mod that is the best GOT game out there as this is the perfect base game for it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Crusader Kings II is one of the best grand strategy games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. The game has beautiful graphics, execellent gameplay mechanics, an engine that is heads above other competitors, and challenge that keeps bringing players back for more. Add on the dozens and dozens of modifications and DLCs this game brings Grand Strategy to a whole new level. This being said, it is worth mentioning that there is somewhat of a learning curve and the instructions, at least for me, seemed more difficult and confusing than simply jumping in to the game. As well, some of the events and other parts of the game are difficult to fully appreciate without knowledge of the time period. Another personal desire/qualm is the fact that one cannot play as the Papacy, even though you are allowed to play as such powerful characters as the Caliphs of the Near East. It would add a whole new level of replayability. All in all a magnificent game and a must own if you enjoy the period.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												The only Paradox game I've played so far, yet I recommend it wholeheartedly. Crusader Kings is a strategy game that focuses on the characters rather than the nation-states; and that changes the dynamics completely. It's the most "humanistic" strategy game I've played, where plots, backstabbing and power-mongering is rampant. Trying to keep your dynasty alive, and your realm together, is some of the best fun I've ever had. Give Crusader Kings ago, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I loved this game, but due to the battle changes and 'coalition/defensive pact' changes in conclave, as well as bugs that have persisted for over a year (The worst of which is when a revolt leader dies they'll just get their own independant country instead of folding back into yours), and repeated dlc thats weak on content I can no longer recommend it.Paradox seems invested in their vision of nofun mechanics that don't make the game more challanging, just more tedious (shattared retreats, hosts, defensive pacts, as well as a thousand tiny things that have been in the game for forever like being unable to end a revolt when a province is occupied for an enemy when an ai can totally do that),Steam says I have 700 hours in this game,  I'd played close to double that since I didn't play with steam open when I started, and the last 100 hours of so have been me desperatly trying to overlook all the problems that have been introduced combined with the problems that have always been there that I looked past because the rest of the game was solid.I don't want crusader kings to be europa universalis, and I don't want to play a game that is STILL a buggy mess years after release.EDIT: As of reaper's call the game now has custom setup options at game start that allow you to customise how your game works including turning off defensive pacts and shattered retreats without disabling ironman/achievements. This, along with other quality of life additions (such as pillage being a toggle now holy♥♥♥♥♥♥thank you paradox finally) means that I am now happy to reccomend this game again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												10/10Owing to the succession laws of my country, a technicality prevented my ascension to absolute power over the land. Fearing the backlash from the nobility, I was unable to turn the influence I inherited from my merchant father, whom my mother married "Matrilinealy", into a physical act of power in the form of an armed coup. Also, owing to the cultural convictions of the populace, armed rebellion was a distinct probability, indeed built in to their constitution as a check against Tyranny.Upon mulling this over, I hoped to find an etymological kink in my alarming realization that I AM a "Tyrant". While I couldn't rid myself of the label, I did notice that in the Greek tradition, while a "Tyrant" IS someone who achieves power outside of the methods a society has deliberately created, the negative connotation we experience was not necessarily (although, admittedly, often enough) felt by them. Indeed, when a Tyrant was welcomed and appreciated, it was during a time where the current system was not functioning. If I could capture that word, and guide it properly through it's emotional course, I started thinking that I might be able to channel the best and worst definitions of that word in a manner that serves my needs.Thus, I sent my Chancellor to sow dissent in the regions of the empire with the strongest religious tendencies, warning of affiliations between the Emperor and Islam, confident that the difficulties in disproving such a connection makes proving them with factual evidence unnecessary. Between assignments, he labored to please god find some interpretation that will allow me to pursue my aims with a semblance legitimacy.My Marshal was sent to repress rebellions in territories that were under no threat of doing so, with instructions to warn the populace against the imminent threat of an Islamic uprising secretly backed by an Emperor who wants to disarm it's citizens. By militarizing locals in the name of justice against Tyrant Emperor, he will be in a better position to evaluate where and how many weapons are being stored.My Court Chaplin was sent, alongside gifts of money I just happened to want to donate, to the local religious leaders to demonstrate the support my efforts afforded their congregations in the form of masses of passionate, scared, angry zealots, and that reciprocation would be mutually beneficial.My Spymaster was sent around the land to spread rumors that the Emperor, actually, was not at all legitimate on the same grounds that I actually am not. I have a game I like to play where I accuse someone of something I know they are innocent of that I may see what genuine denial of guilt looks like, especially if it is something that I am guilty of committing or plan to commit. When he dismissed the accusations as "beneath his dignity", he gave me leave to do the same when the time came to overtly assert myself. Regarding the issue itself, enough of the populace believes our Emperor is as illegitimate as I am in fact that it shouldn't be regarded seriously now.My Steward was sent to collect taxes in the poorest regions in my grasp, with instructions to apologize for having to collect but their Emperor insisted they do so.Now, to let the damage fester, I will continue to fight the version of my Emperor that my minions have created, and declare victory when thwarted and claim credit for anything positive done by the Emperor, especially if I did not support it, and preemptively call hypocrite anywhere I engage in hypocrisy.Wish me luck! Awesome game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												In CK2 you control a county/duchy/kingdom, assign your own council, propose marriages for your courtiers, develop your regions, ally or go to war with your neighbours, venture on crusades/jiihads, buy mercenary armies... and this is just the normal part of the game.But CK2 is not just your regular strategy game. In this game, it's all about your dinasty! You marry per convenience in order to form better alliances, you plot against vassals that have claims on your lands... sometimes even against your own family, you murder your wife and children if the heir is not your own blood, you assassinate opponents or friends as needed, fabricate claims on lands, instigate other kingdom's vassals to rebel against their lieges, execute, free or ransom prisoners, get maimed on battles and become a useless peon, die of syphilis or other nasty diseases, get assassinated by your own brother/uncle/mother in a plot conjured by your own spymaster, allies will turn their back on you and join your rivals when you most needed them, you will rise slowly and steadily and then lose everything because you were either too greedy or just because you died naturally without being able to set the right strategy to give continuity to your dinasty, popes will excommungate you or give you gold for your contribution against infidels... and countless of other situations that make this game pretty unique.If you want something different and special, this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2013
												Plotting to murder your uncle, King of Bohemia, has never been more fun! CKII is a grand strategy game without any clear goals except for those you set for yourself. Take control of a mayor of minor family in medieval Europe and see how history plays out. I advise to role-play a lot and make decisions based on the traits of your character, since it will make for some "interesting" situations which will provide new challenges. It's a great improvement over CK1 in nearly every aspect, and especially concerning the interface: it might very well be the most accessible game Paradox has ever made, although the learning curve is still quite steep. Expansions are also well worth it, since they allow you to play previously unplayable factions. Also highly recommended for fans of Game of Thrones, since the politics in this game remind me a lot of those books/show (and what do you know: there is actually a GoT mod :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Crusader Kings II is one of the best strategy games ever.  I have been a fan of strategy games since the glory days of the mid 1990's, but I have not played a strategy game more than this one.  It has a fine balance of playing with politics and war that no other game has.  I love how there is no main goal for any particular playthrough, besides ensuring the survival of your dynasty.  You can choose any random area and play as that areas main character and their dynasty.  Unlike the Total War games and games like Civilization, there are no cheap moments where you can be allied with someone and then the next turn get attacked out of nowhere.  You have to have a legitimate reason for your actions in this game and more than anygame, I look forward to the fallout of mistakes I make.  I highly recommend this to anyone who is a strategy fan.  There is a bit of a learning curve, but once you understand how the game works, it is pretty awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Where to begin... Forgive the long story, because my explanation as to why it is such a great game can only be described by the stories that are created when you play, as so many others who have posted theirs would likely agree.All right. I'm a lowly count in Poitiers. The year is 786. I married a greek woman by the name of Daphne 16 year ago, and had 5 sons with her. All was well. I had two counties and life was beautiful. My wife and I were hoping to have a little girl soon, but we were patient. I had my eyes set on a county to the north, Thouars, and I had my Chancellor working on a loophole to allow me to lay claim to it. Everything was going great! However, this happiness could not last. It was after the birth of my 5th son, Berenguie, that a series of... Interesting events began.He was born in 779 and by God the boy was displaying some very strange behavior even as an infant. The courtiers said he started laughing uncontrollably after he was cut with a sharp knife and was bleeding everywhere, and the other children said he was making creepy buzzing noises when he was around. He began to scare the courtiers (and myself, to be honest) so I called for the Court Chaplain, Aldebert of St. Savin. He then informed me that the child was a spawn of the Devil and that my wife, Daphne, "Had congress" with the devil. Daphne did not confess, but she never tried to deny it either. I had no choice but to disown the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child (for he was Satan's, not my own!) and imprison the witch. I had to keep the child though... He has no inheritance, but still must be cared for.That event occured around 781. So after a a year or so of mourning (and actively trying to repair the damage that a wife who cheated on me with the devil and gave birth to his demonic spawn in a bloody Catholic community caused) I remarried, and now, and for the past four years, Daphne and Berenguie are still causing me untold sorrow: My second son woke in the night screaming, foaming at the mouth with a swollen, blood-shot eye muttering to himself about "a little monster" stabbing him in the eye, all while little Demon Berenguie was happily striding around as if nothing happened... While me and all of my vassals and courtiers feared the kid even more.And my ex-wife? Yeah I had her imprisoned, supposedly, but when I went to execute her for her part in all of this, she wasn't there and when I looked her up, her location was "Unknown." Great. a demon child stabbing my heirs and a witch who is in love with me is somewhere doing God only knows what... Then I found out what she was up to.When my new wife left on a spiritual trip for several days, Daphne poked her ugly head back in while she was gone and there I was, back in her arms. Of COURSE she was now married to some guy over in Italy, and ABSOLUTELY she became pregnant after our little romantic rendevous! So I'm now stressed to the max, guilt eating away at me over and over so I desperately try to have her, and the unborn child, killed before it comes back to bite me square in the rear end. Months go by, no luck. She has the child... And it's a girl! I call off the plot to have her killed. The entire time Daphne and I were married her one "Ambition" was to have a daughter. That gave me pause, not to mention I already have 6 sons (Including the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ demonspawn) and that's my first and only daughter. Call me a softy but I couldn't kill them now. But it doesn't stop there, no sir. Daphne's new husband comes all the way to Poitiers to confront me about the affair! I'm given one last chance to break off the affair with my lover: and I tell him to go screw himself, I'm not ending it. He storms back, likely thinking of ways to get me back that involve alll kinds of murder, but I'm a couple steps ahead: I've already plotted to kill him, with his own wife no less (who is disturbingly happy about assisting me).So now I'm waiting on the death of that Italian prick so I can take back my lover!  And I get a message saying my second son, Abbon who is now 14, was found dead in his bed, his face frozen in a terrified grimace. No noticeable damage to his body, his face was pale with a streak of blood running down his cheek and it looks like he died of fright. As for Berenguie? The 10 year old who just lost his brother? He's once again acting happier than normal without a care in the world.Now it's not over yet, I'm still in this game waiting to see how it unfolds, but all of this happened in about two hours of gameplay. All random. And so much more can happen too. Please play this game. If you like strategy/simulation type games, which I'm assuming you do or you wouldn't be here reading this at all, buy this game.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Paradox grand strategy game. Does anything more need to be said? Well, I guess I'll say a little anyway. If you ever wanted to lead a Medieval dynasty from the dark ages to the early Renaissance, and conquer half of Europe (and maybe a chunk of Africa and the Middle East) along the way, this is the game for you. With constantly added features, I find myself coming back to this game and leading another dynasty over and over again. The cons: It's hard to keep up with how often they add new content. But is that really that much of a negative? If you're like me, and will play a campaign once every few months or so, then it will simply make every new game fresh. Just visit Paradox's forums to see if there is going to be a new update soon before starting. I've lost a couple of playthroughs midway through because I've started shortly before a major patch and I've got auto-update on Steam.

												Whether playing as a feudal King in Western Europe, or as a small time lord in the Middle East, Crusader Kings 2 brought Paradox Interactive into the spotlight. It's a fantastic game with a timeline that'll allow hours of play, that combined with the actual variety of characters and times to start in it allows a wide range of replayability. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I've been playing this game for around 2 years at this point, and its endless expansions and countless possibilities keep me coming back time after time. Some of the stories that I've vicariously lived through playing Crusader Kings II have been incredible - the 74 year long dynasty of a father who assassinates his brothers to unite a kingdom, only for that kingdom to crash and break upon his death, leaving it in the hands of three young sisters - his daughters - who go on to relive their fathers' legacy; each one plotting to kill the other in the name of uniting the kingdom once more.That time when all of England was Norway. When all of France was England. When half of Europe was the Aztec empire, or, the time that I reunited Portugal through diabolical scheming, assassination attempts and intrigue in bucketloads.I've recently got into modding CK2, as well, and although slightly daunting at first, it is relatively comprehensive to tinker around with. I've yet to complete a mod; however have had fun poking around in the game engine to create my own (non-canon) religion and set up various event strings. A must for any modder.Get this game, you won't regret it. If you are not familiar with the complex nature of Paradox games, do go through the tutorial and do read forum guides; you'll get a lot more out of it. I look forward to seeing what comes next! Thank you, Paradox!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This game feels like an almost perfect Game of Thrones game where you play as Tywin Lannister, planning and scheming on taking over control of the world.Pros: Emphasis on family breeding and conquering new lands by marriage and assassination! This game is all about developing your family, its power and influence. You carefully arrange marriages. Firstly, to ensure your heirs would get the best genes. Secondly, to install your family members on thrones in neighbouring counties, duchies and kingdoms. This takes great patience, planning, and some luck as well. Often you will have to assassinate other rulers or their heirs to achieve this. By the way you'll learn weird ways the different inheritance laws work. Why is it important to install cousins, nephews and other kinsmen on thrones in other "provinces"? Because the same family name grants you an eternal military alliance and even lets you to join your domains easier in the future (with a marriage, of course). In dynasty we trust!Also, sometimes you will have to kill your own family members, or help your sons in impregnating their wives. All to ensure the only right line of succession :)Inner working of a kingdom, with sovereigns, vassals and their warsBeside the above you will of course raise armies and battle other rulers, but its mechanics in the game are somewhat simplified. Realism is amplified by the addition of factions; you may revolt against your sovereign along with other vassals, e.g. against an inheritance law, or to install certain person on the throne.Cons:Time consuming searching for bridesThe game interface is a bit coarse, although better than in the previous installment of the series. I mostly whine about the problematic in-game search engine for characters, used mostly to find brides and grooms. It should let you specify more options for the characters you seek. Instead, you can choose some basic options, and then you have to sort through a ton of people. Probably most of the play time I spend on searching, so it is an important feature. Fortunately, it's still not able to spoil the fun of managing your dynasty :)Bugs on Linux version The game is still buggy on Linux. Some players report that disabling the launcher they implemented months ago solves the problems, some don't. Recently my game would crash to desktop every several months, without any symptoms, so I had to switch to Windows to continue playing without constant whining.DLC plague – “hey, let’s add a bunch of new functions to the game, and put each in a different lovable payable DLC!” Paradox' greatest sin is its DLC policy. Most of them are simply NOT WORTH ITS COST. They usually add one significant function to the game. The latest - Way of Life - claims to add "hundreds of new events". I bought it, played it, and highly doubt it! Before you purchase any DLC, ask on the web which are definitely worth buying!Not enough of diversified music tracksThe music tracks for different culture groups are few but very atmospheric. Although, after 200 years no matter how great they are, listhening to them just becomes tedious. Of course most of them you have to purchase in separate DLCs...Conclusion:All in all, this is a perfect idea for a game, and an imperfect implementation of that idea, though the best (and only?) one I know. You love GoT and Tywin Lannister? Quickly buy it!

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												While this game does have it's problems, as does any game, it contains within it a certain charm. Yes, the multiplayer is very glitchy and the game has a tendancy to change versions (That you're running without closing the game) causing your games to disconnect mid-multiplayer, but I find it has a certain quality that is missed with other simulation games of the type. The flexability of the ways you can play, the core fact that it's a game about politics and less about war (although that is an important part), and simply because of the in-depth details the game contains about every single character just makes the game so great. It is anything but easy and takes many attempts and a lot of practice to gain any actual sense of achievment but when you get to that point, there are few greater feelings to a true lover of managment/simulation/political games. I would play, and do play it, over and over again.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2013
												This is a rich, complicated game that sits at the intersection of many rich, complicated things: centuries-long empire building, tangled soap-opera relationships, and medieval role-play. There is always something going on, always something interesting to do; as with Sid Meier's Civilization, it's hard to find a good moment at which to stop playing—despite the fact that you control time in the game. Though its setting and complexity was intimidating at first (I'd suggest you watch playthroughs and tutorials on YouTube before starting), playing CKII is engrossing, rewarding, and results in stories you want to tell others.And I've yet to run it with any of the DLC expansions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												For me, this game is perhaps the most gripping medieval political simulation I've ever played. Hours upon hours of my life have been invested in this game, estimated more than 300 hours before I converted my copy to a steam copy (gamersgate gave me a steam code for it and all the dlc I had). Deep and engaging diplomacy that requires one to have a strategy, lest your short term gains be spoiled by a disloyal vassal, jealous relative... I once even had my ideal heir murdered by my second wife so the first son I had with her could be my heir. Plot your way to the top of feudal power and entrench your dynasty in a historical sandbox. With all the DLC available that enables the player to play lords of pagan, muslim and jewish faiths, the EU IV converter DLC that allows you to take a game from the end of the dark ages to the early 19th century; this game is an absolute must own for any lover of history and political simulations, or even people looking for a empire management game with rpg elements.20/10
