number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												I strongly recommend this game to everyone. It doesn't matter what your strategy preference is, this game is perfect and will bring at the best and worst in all of you. Look at how much i have played this game, i don't get much time to play games as i am at University but when i do this is the game i go to. The game is a Grand Strategy game which means you do not take control of battles, instead you are in control of the state, deciding its politics and making sure that you become a pre-eminent power in Europe. Now that doesn't sound that as unique as the other games paradox have made, but as well as a grand strategy this is an RPG. First of all the RPG elements are not like Mass Effect or Skyrim, they are event based which means you decide how certain events go and see where it takes you. You can become a benevolent ruler who is just and kind, or you can become a intricate web weaver, assassinating rivals and killing siblings. You can even become insane or/and possessed!Now there is A LOT of DLC for this game and that can put you off. But this has not been pulled from the game (well most of it hasn't), instead they have been developed after the main game came out and add a variety of RPG enhancements and events. They also enable you to play different religions and cultures. The DLCs i would recommend are:Sword of IslamLegacy of RomeOld GodsSons of AbrahamWay of LifeCharlemagne They are all the major expansions except for Raja's of India and Republics which i found were a bit lacking and can be left out without any major changes. All the other Dynasty shield packs and song packs are totally optional (although if you are going to buy one song pack buy the Old Gods one).This game is worth full price and will give you hundreds of hours of game content and will give you an experience you will never forget. Also if you are unsure then wait for a steam sale and get the game and the major expansions for an incredibly cheap price!

												Get this one.This game is a Grand Strategy game where you lead anything from a minor county to the Holy Roman Empire to victory. Except there is no end-goal besides the goals you set yourself. The only way to end the game is a) lose or b) reach the end-date.I personally love starting out as a count in Norway, and strive for the welfare of Norway or the Empire of Scandinavia. content:
Posted: May 4, 2012
												Easily Paradox's most accessible to date. Despite this ease of access the game  is deceptively deep. A game of characters, where empires and kingdoms merely present the background; where the goals are inherently  personal, and can include merely trying to usurp a minor barony to establishing your family's hegemony over Europe.  A game where you won't blink an eye at murdering your incompetent family members, scheming rivals, and the occasional anti-pope, all in the name of "the realm." A game where marrying off  your club-footed, inbred children to lowly lords to secure their allegiance is met with much praise. Totally awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Crusader Kings 2 was my first entry into the greand strategy genre, and after 100 hours of conquest, domination, politics, civil strife, heartbreak, victory, and defeat, I can safely say that CK2 is my favorite game of the year. When you start out, the game seems too hard, overly frustrating, and not worth anyone's time. The tutorials don't help at all, and everything will go wrong without you knowing anything about how. At this point, please take my advice... KEEP GOING. I have never had so much fun losing in a game, and the sense of discovery when you figure this game out is some of the greatest moments I've had in gaming. Another great thing about this game is that it actually gets you interested in the time period! I can't tell you how many times I've paused the game and went to look up a character or country. So if you want a game with a terrible learning curve that turns into a wonderous experience, CK2 will serve just fine.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I don't know that the English language is deep enough to properly heap the praise upon this game that it truly deserves. The replayability is phenomenal, the stategy is incredibly deep and involving, and there are literally too many ways to play the game for me to list them without writing a novel. My friend plays the game like a geneticist, trying to breed the perfect ruler. I play the game constantly trying to spread whatever religion I'm playing, because it's obviously the only true religion.With hundreds of playable characters and hundreds of different ways to play, I can see myself playing this for thousands and thousands of hours before I get bored of it. Heck, look at how much I've played already. Download this game, download the six important expansions (Ruler Designer, Sword of Islam, Legacy of Rome, The Republic, The Old Gods, Sons of Abraham) and then decide how you want to play! Conquer the world? Have one of your children elected Pope? Mend the Great Schism in the Christian Church? Establish the Jewish nation of Israel? That's just a tiny little bit of what you can do in Crusader Kings, and I can't recommend this enough!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												The heathen king of Norway became infatuated with his concubine spy-mistress, who after becoming too old to bear children and set aside surprised the court by bearing the king an illegitimate daughter. Recognized by the king as one of his own, the daughter was accepted into the court and tutored by the best brilliant minds at the king's disposal.The once loyal spy-mistress and mother did not live to see her daughter's coming of age, pacing peacefully in sleep at an old and tender age. The king, distraught at his lover's death could no longer rule as vibrantly as he once did, suffering from a violent and seemingly endless depression. The Gods brought him no joy, nor the thunderous clash of steel and sword and the victories of his sons in battle.Tragedy struck yet again as the king's oldest and heir to the great, sprawling heathen kingdom of Norway fell in battle against the catholic dogs. Broken and plagued by wrath, the king set his second son on the path of vengeance, only to lose him in an outbreak of illness amongst the populace.With his heir's dead, the king could only look towards the daughter of his now lost lover. Plagued by his depression and with no interest in any woman, the king appointed the girl as his successor; the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a once great spy-mistress and his only remaining child.When the daughter finally passed from girlhood into womanhood, so much like her mother was she, that the king's heart once again ignited with passion. The fog cleared from his mind at the very sight of his daughter and the demons of depression no longer maintained their hold on him.Crusader Kings II -- The Medieval Soap Opera Game

At first you won't understand it, but just try fooling around and soon you will learn how to play, when you do, you will have one of the best games in the world in your hands!In this game you play as a character from a dynasty, there is no objectives, you can do your own, like, making your dynasty rule all the realms in the world, play as a different and dying religion and try to make it the world religion, all sorts of stuff.While you are playing you have to manage your character and his relations to others, you will have your spouse, your children, your vassals, their families... You can plot to kill everyone, you can cheat on your wife, maybe you married her because of her family but she is ugly! You could fall in love with you cousin... if you are Zoroastrian you can even marry your sister, heck, you can marry your mother! I think this game became my favorite game ever, play it if you like strategy and roleplaying!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												One of the best, most addicting games on Steam. Short of Civ V and Skyrim, I think this is the game I have clocked the most hours on on Steam. You can make the game challenging for yourself, or just see what kind of crazy alternative history scenarios you can create. The expansions (the DLC that cost a bit more than the others) have crazy value and the other dlc you can buy is just nice toppings if you care about what they have. I myself have mostly bought the songpacks, because I love the music they bring, but you can enjoy the game entirely without the packs. The expansions unlock more play options in the game, so I highly recommend you get them at least after you've played the game for a bit, as they are complete gamechangers.Heck, if there's a deal like I'm seeing right now for winter sales, pay a little extra for the CKII Collection and get most of the stuff cheap. Right now the base game is 9,99€ and the collection, which includes at least four expansions and a lot of content packs is 19,99€. What a deal! That said, the base game is certainly worth the full price too.What better review for the game than to give some real stories of great moments?1. One of my earliest crazy alternate history scenarios was this: I started as the King of Scotland. Eventually I ended up (through intrigue and deceit) being married to the Empress of Byzantium (one of the most prestigious positions in the historical setting). This of course resulted in my daughter becoming Queen of Scotland and Empress of Byzantium.2. With the Legacy of Rome expansions you can achieve one of the most rewarding things you can ever do in gaming. You can start off as a count in the Byzantine Empire and slowly make your way to becoming Emperor. You'd think that'd be enough, but no. You can then proceed to invade Jerusalem, Alexandria and other holy lands thus restoring the Pentarch and making Orthodoxy the de facto form of Christianity, allowing you to outright turn Catholism into a heresy! But wait, there's more. You are Emperor of Byzantium, also known internally as Rome. It's time to make everyone accept you as the Emperor of Rome. How? Reclaim the old areas, invade Rome and recreate the Roman Empire! First Rome, then the world.3. The Empire of Scandinavia!

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												2 Words. Simply awesome.I played the first Crusader Kings and loved it. It had weak spots, a lot of them but it was my first grand strategy game. And it got me into the genre. It led to countless hours of Europa Universalis 2 and EU 3.And then CK2 was announced, i couldn't wait to get my hands on the game and had so much fun with it starting as a tiny count back in Switzerland and become the Emperor of the HRE or be a Viking and Inavde the Coastlines. It's a Sandbox and you can do what you want and then add to it the countless possibilies of the Modding Comunity. I played as Rob Stark in the brilliant game of Thrones Mod and won the War for the North.The graphics are okay for a Strategy Game, but you won't get happy with a game like CK2 if you are looking for fancy grahics! The Soud effects are nice and the Music, too. If you played any part of EU or Victoria, you'll love CK2 because it adds a lot of character.Because its about the characters, not just the country.

Posted: October 4, 2014
												I'm a sandboxer, so I like the soft-moddability of the game. Plus, I get to learn a little history and geography along the way. My biggest project that I would love to figure out is to be able to create a "minor title" like prince, but have it show as the title for vassal kings. My goal is to incorporate the "missing" noble ranks into the existing ones in the game.My plan would be to make it so a Baron that holds 2 or more baronies w/o holding a higher title would be Viscount (primary title); Counts that hold 2 or more counties w/0 holding a higher title would be Marquis (primary title), and vassal kings would instead be Grand Duke (if not of your dynasty) or Archduke (if from your dynasty) of (primary kingdom title). If this could be done in a mod, or better yet incorporated into the regular game, I would be THRILLED.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												The heathen king of Norway became infatuated with his concubine spy-mistress, who after becoming too old to bear children and set aside surprised the court by bearing the king an illegitimate daughter. Recognized by the king as one of his own, the daughter was accepted into the court and tutored by the best brilliant minds at the king's disposal.The once loyal spy-mistress and mother did not live to see her daughter's coming of age, pacing peacefully in sleep at an old and tender age. The king, distraught at his lover's death could no longer rule as vibrantly as he once did, suffering from a violent and seemingly endless depression. The Gods brought him no joy, nor the thunderous clash of steel and sword and the victories of his sons in battle.Tragedy struck yet again as the king's oldest and heir to the great, sprawling heathen kingdom of Norway fell in battle against the catholic dogs. Broken and plagued by wrath, the king set his second son on the path of vengeance, only to lose him in an outbreak of illness amongst the populace.With his heir's dead, the king could only look towards the daughter of his now lost lover. Plagued by his depression and with no interest in any woman, the king appointed the girl as his successor; the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a once great spy-mistress and his only remaining child.When the daughter finally passed from girlhood into womanhood, so much like her mother was she, that the king's heart once again ignited with passion. The fog cleared from his mind at the very sight of his daughter and the demons of depression no longer maintained their hold on him.Crusader Kings II -- The Medieval Soap Opera Game

content:
Posted: January 17, 2013
												Intrigue. Incest. Murder. Murder of inocent babies. Murder of entire families. War. More intrigue. And then more War. People who think action games are violent don't know what they are talking about - Crusader Kings II is one of those games where you will committ ATROCITIES in the name of Lord and Land, and personal gain. And it happens to be a Grand Strategy game, with a lot of micromanaging and little action going on. I can grant you, it's not for everyone. It has little action, and requires a lot of imaginaton and roleplay (like the old text-based adventures like Zork) since the storyline resolves around text Events. And by storyline I mean Do Whatever You Can/Want, that being Let's Retake Spain as the Spanish, or Invading Europe and wipping christiany out of it as the Muslims. It's pretty fun to see the Roman Empire reform under your banner, even more if you happen to be a filthy pagan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Easily one of the best and most immersive games I have ever played. It spans almost 400 years of extremely well researched medieval history, which only gets ahistorically derailed when the player jumps in and starts changing things. The results can be LEGEN- wait for it- DARY. For instance, as Emperor of Byzantium (the almost universally beloved Emperor Joe the Cruel), I married my heir off to the childless Queen of Rus (who I put on the throne by murdering her father and brothers; she wasn't as grateful as one might imagine). She immediately started sleeping with generals and priests and giving birth to illegitimate children, almost faster than I could eliminate them. Realizing my son was a screwup unfit to succeed me, I had him and his wife killed as soon as they had a son, who inherited half of eastern europe at the ripe old age of 12 days. While grooming my young despot to succeed me, I remember my rivalry with a couple of childhood bullies of mine, so 30 years after the fact, I have the two men excommunicated, imprisoned, thrown in the oubliette, and beheaded. The same fate awaits everyone who shares thier blood. Then my wife dies, leaving my firstborn son to inherit Croatia, and my second born to inherit Hungary. They immediately go to war. Desparate to reunite my family's empire into a line of succession, I declare war on my first born son as a front  to arrest him. He kills my second born in battle, and I capture my firstborn and behead him (lauging maniacally, of course). And when I finally kick the bucket, I proceed to play as the most powerful man in the world: my five year old grandson. Half the world wants me dead, the other half wants to disempower me, and I just learned to walk. From here, I coud send my army of 60000 men east, to reunite the holy lands and prove my supremacy over the arabian superpower, or west, to lay waste to the Holy Roman Empire and with it, Papal influence over western Europe. But first, I have power to consolidate, ambitious vassals to thwart, civil wars to fight, and in-laws to assassinate. The possibilities are literally endless.This game taught me that what every other grand strategy game lack, the greatest divide between games and reality, was characters. The sheer number of characters, amount of unique chartacterization, and incredible degree to which that affects gameplay and the course of history is staggering. The driving force of the game's epic stories so rarely has as much to do with countries, armies, and rescources. Much more often, it will be individuals, and thier personalites, and the interpersonal relationships they develop that decide the course of history. The way you develop characters, from decisions you make raising your children, and the personal decisions you make throughtout your life (excellently implemented game mechanics btw), will determine your friends, enemies, piety, culture, battles, triumphs, and possibilities.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2012
												If I had to identify the major roadblock to me enjoying grand strategy titles, it is the inevitable surging creep of the game getting harder and harder to manage as the game goes on. I'm not saying this is bad for everyone, but I find it hard to enjoy a game that is actively trying to destroy everything I've built and done for the past several hours. Imagine if you had to maintain your builds in minecraft against decay.Crusader Kings II is my #1 Grand Strategy title and one of my favorite game of all time because the gameplay doesn't have the difficulty creep. From the very moment you get vassal counts to the end game where you control entire kingdoms spanning Europe, the management of your Kingdom remains more or less the same, just increasing in quantity. Instead of having to constantly deal with everything trying to collapse around you whenever you want to expand, you face the same trials you've always faced. For me, it allows both an immersive, somewhat challenging, time-consuming experience, but without the intense frustration found in similar titles.As for the positives of the game, you not only get to rule a growing realm, becoming more and more powerful and facing the changing political situation of the map year after year, but you get to play a character and his family, worrying about keeping everyone happy so they all go along with your grand vision of world conquest. The mechanics of battle are a tad simplistic, but there is more than enough to keep you occupied as you avoid river crossing and trying to find the appropriate terrain to defend on, all the while trying to occupy your enemies lands and preventing him from doing the same to you. Religion plays a major part of the game, whether you are a Christian, Muslim, Pagan, or Jew. Keeping yourself from being excommunicated or avoiding high decadence is always a challenge for the most experienced player.If you're looking for a Grand Strategy title having been frustrated with the genre for its overly challenging difficulty curve, I'd recommend CKII in a hearbeat. Perhaps not right for every gamer, it's still a fantastic title and if you are remotely interested in Grand Strategy, Management Games, or History, you should pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Very accessible grand strategy game and a great place to start if you want to get into the genre. You can get lost in the narrative of your dynasty, a narrative that you directly influence over limitless generations. The fact that you play as a distinct ruler that has to deal with betrothals and assassinations and heirs and politics, not to mention his own morality and relationships,  is what sets this game apart from other grand strategy titles. The modding community is wonderful; if you ever get tired of the base game, there are several functional overhauls available. The learning curve is somewhat steep but I am confident that almost anybody can "get into it" after a few play session, and it is certainly worth the learning.This game is one of my favorite games and I absolutely recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2013
												My play time on this on steam compared to every other game I have in my library speaks volumes as to what I think of this title. With the Old Gods expansion a game I thought was the greatest, deepest, most immersive strategy title Ive ever played has somehow become greater, deeper and more immersive. There's simply nothing else like it. Its essentially a politics, intrigue, sociology and general human interaction simulator set during the middle ages that comes closer to emulating real world human relationships, interactions and politics than any other game Ive ever played. Over 300 hours in and Im still getting new things from this game. Its staggeringly good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												You see how much time I played this game. 7.5 hours. And I only know the basics. I have started this game like any other that allows this: Let's assassinate EVERYONE who doesn't like me. That way, I have found out a lot about the diplomacy; looking at why people like/hate me and looking at options other than just assassinate. I have spent only like 10 mins reading about the tips/starts on CK II and the most useful thing I found was: Start at the tutorial island (Ireland), becuase there isn't a lot going on there. Other than that, I couldn't be bothered to go through the in-game tutorials: I prefer to unpick the game by myself, so even after 100 hours of gameplay I can still find something new, something cool. Although I only played 7.5 hours, I can already recommend this game with my heart. And especially now, that it is on humblebundle. I have paid £3.39 for it and it is one of the better games I bought (along with M&B Warband with Napoleonic Wars). Shortly: GET IT IT'S EPIC
